In conclusion, views on the scrutiny of Muslims are strongly divided along political and demographic lines, with those who prioritize terrorism as a national issue being more likely to support greater scrutiny of Muslims.

Americans' perceptions of the government's effectiveness in reducing terrorism has declined significantly, reaching the lowest point since the 9/11 attacks [4]. This is highlighted by the across-the-board drop in ratings of government efforts against terrorist threats [7]. ![Positive ratings of government efforts against terrorism have decreased across party lines from 2001 to 2015.](image1). Compared to early 2015, assessments have become more negative across the political spectrum [12]. ![Positive ratings of government efforts against terrorism have decreased across party lines from early 2015 to late 2015.](image1). This negative sentiment is also reflected in the increasing concern that government anti-terror policies haven't gone far enough [8]. ![Concern that anti-terror policies have not gone far enough has increased from 2004 to 2015.](image7). Furthermore, terrorism is increasingly seen as a major national problem, with mentions rising significantly compared to the previous year [10]. ![The percentage of Americans citing terrorism as the most important problem has increased significantly from December 2014 to December 2015.](image8).

These perceptions vary across demographic groups. Older and less educated Americans tend to give the government lower marks for their terrorism reduction efforts [1, 9]. ![Older age groups are less likely to rate government efforts against terrorism positively.](image3). Conversely, individuals with postgraduate degrees hold more positive views [3].

Politically, significant divides exist. Republicans are more likely to cite terrorism as a critical national issue compared to Independents and Democrats [6]. ![Republicans are more likely than Democrats and Independents to mention terrorism as a top problem.](image4). While Democrats were the only partisan group with a majority still rating the government positively, even their ratings have fallen [12].

In conclusion, public perception of government efforts against terrorism has worsened, with notable differences across age, education, and political affiliation.

Based on the survey, Republicans and Democrats diverge significantly in their perspectives on terrorism, while economic issues show less pronounced partisan differences in terms of being considered top national problems.  Republicans are considerably more likely to prioritize terrorism and national security as critical issues [9].  Specifically,  41% of Republicans cite terrorism, defense, national security, or ISIS as the nation's most pressing problem, compared to only 23% of Democrats [9].

This partisan gap is further illustrated in the perceived importance of problems facing the nation.  ![Image7 shows that terrorism is a significantly bigger concern for Republicans (24%) compared to Democrats (16%), with a R-D difference of +8.](image7) As shown in image7, terrorism is a significantly bigger concern for Republicans compared to Democrats.  While terrorism ranks high for Republicans, economic issues also register as concerns across both parties, though not to the same extent as terrorism for Republicans.

Furthermore, views on the government's handling of terrorism reveal a stark partisan divide.  Republicans have become increasingly critical of the government's efforts to reduce terrorism threats [5, 6].  ![Image1 shows that Republican's positive ratings of government efforts against terrorism have decreased significantly from 95% in 2002 to 27% in 2015.](image1) Image1 illustrates this trend, showing a dramatic decline in Republican positive ratings of government anti-terrorism efforts, especially when compared to Democrats who maintain a higher positive rating [6].  This divergence is also evident in image2, where only 27% of Republicans rate the government's efforts as "very/fairly well," while a majority of Democrats (64%) hold a positive view. ![Image2 shows that only 27% of Republicans rate government efforts against terrorism as very/fairly well, while 64% of Democrats hold this view.](image2)

Regarding economic issues, while image7 indicates the economy is a concern for both Republicans (7%) and Democrats (6%), the partisan difference (R+1) is minimal compared to terrorism (R+8).  This suggests that while economic issues are acknowledged by both groups, they do not represent the same level of partisan divergence as terrorism in terms of being identified as a top national problem.

In conclusion, the survey reveals a significant partisan divide where Republicans prioritize terrorism and national security more prominently than Democrats, and are also more critical of government efforts against terrorism.  In contrast, while economic issues are recognized as concerns across both parties, they do not exhibit the same degree of partisan differentiation as terrorism in being considered top national problems.

Based on political affiliation, there are differing views on the importance of terrorism and the government's handling of it. Republicans are more likely to consider terrorism a critical issue compared to Democrats and Independents [6].  For instance, 41% of Republicans cite terrorism, defense, national security, or ISIS as the nation's most important problem, while fewer Independents (28%) and Democrats (23%) share this view [6]. This partisan divide in prioritizing terrorism is further highlighted in image7, which shows that terrorism is mentioned as a top problem by 24% of Republicans, 16% of Democrats, and 18% of Independents.

![Terrorism is considered a more important issue among Republicans compared to Democrats and Independents.](image7)

In contrast, Democrats are more inclined to believe the government is handling the threat of terrorism adequately, though positive ratings have declined across all political groups [5].  As shown in image1 and image3, Republicans consistently exhibit lower approval ratings for government efforts in combating terrorism compared to Democrats and Independents, particularly during the Obama administration.

![Republicans have consistently lower approval ratings for government efforts against terrorism compared to Democrats and Independents.](image1)

Image6 further illustrates this point, revealing that only 27% of Republicans rate the government's performance in reducing terrorist threats as "very/fairly well," compared to 64% of Democrats and 44% of Independents.  This suggests that Republicans, who view terrorism as a more pressing issue, are also more critical of the government's approach to mitigating this threat.

![Republicans are less likely than Democrats and Independents to rate the government's effort against terrorism positively.](image6)

In conclusion, Republicans prioritize terrorism as a national problem more than Democrats or Independents, and this heightened concern correlates with a more negative assessment of the government's effectiveness in addressing terrorist threats.

Independent voters present a nuanced perspective on government regulation, differing from the more polarized views of Democrats and Republicans.  While Republican-leaning independents align with Republicans in favoring smaller government, they show some divergence on economic fairness.  Republican-leaning independents largely advocate for a smaller government that offers fewer services, with a significant majority (78%) preferring this approach [9]. This preference is nearly identical to Republicans, where 74% favor a smaller government [6]. This is further illustrated in the image, showing that 78% of Republican leaners prefer smaller government, and only 17% favor bigger government providing more services, mirroring the sentiment of Republicans  ![Republican leaners prefer smaller government providing fewer services](image3).

However, on the issue of economic fairness, Republican-leaning independents differ from Republicans.  While a majority of Republicans (63%) believe the U.S. economic system is fair to most Americans, GOP leaners are more divided, with 49% finding it fair and 46% considering it unfairly favors powerful interests [12].  This contrasts with Democrats and Democratic leaners, who overwhelmingly believe the economic system unfairly favors powerful interests [3, 4].  A large majority of Democrats (85%) and Democratic leaners (81%) share this view [3].  The image also corroborates this, showing that 81% of Democratic leaners believe the economic system unfairly favors powerful interests, a stark contrast to the divided view of Republican leaners and the more positive view of Republicans ![Democratic leaners believe the economic system unfairly favors powerful interests](image2).

In contrast to the Republican preference for smaller government, Democratic-leaning independents, like Democrats, generally favor a larger government [6].  However, overall, independents are not unified in their views on government size and business regulation, showing division on these issues [8]. This is reflected in the data, where independents are almost evenly split on preferring a smaller (47%) versus bigger government (44%) and are also divided on whether government regulation is necessary to protect the public interest (48%) or does more harm than good (43%) ![Independent voters are divided on government regulation and size](image3).

In summary, independent voters, particularly those leaning Republican, share the Republican preference for smaller government but exhibit more nuanced and less certain views on economic fairness compared to both Republicans and Democrats.

The unfavorable view of both major parties has undergone changes over time among independents and varies across different independent subgroups.  Intense dislike of the opposing party has surged among independents leaning towards either Republican or Democratic parties over the past two decades [3]. This trend is mirrored in the increasing percentage of leaners from both sides holding very unfavorable opinions of the opposing party from 1994 to 2018 [5].

![The percentage of independents who are unfavorable to both parties, favorable to one party and unfavorable to the other, and favorable to both parties from 1994 to 2018.](image7)

However, the percentage of independents with negative views towards *both* parties has seen a decrease in recent years, declining from over a third in 2015 [8].  Despite this recent dip, a significant portion of independents still hold unfavorable views of both parties.

![The percentage of different groups including independents, leaners, and partisans who are unfavorable to both parties.](image5)

Interestingly, independents who do not lean towards either party are the most inclined to have negative opinions of both parties [4, 11].  A considerable $37\%$ of non-leaning independents hold unfavorable views towards both the Republican and Democratic parties [4].  In contrast, independents who lean towards a party, while also showing increased negativity towards the *opposing* party, are less likely to dislike *both* parties [1, 2].  The vast majority of independents actually lean towards one of the two major parties [6].

In conclusion, while unfavorable views towards both parties among independents have fluctuated, especially decreasing recently, those who do not lean towards a party are consistently more likely to view both parties unfavorably compared to those who lean.

Over the past two decades, negative views of the opposing party have increased among both Republicans and Democrats, as well as independents who lean towards either party [7]. This trend is particularly evident in the surge of intense dislike for the opposing party among partisans and leaners [5].  ![Line graphs showing the trend of unfavorable views towards Republican and Democratic parties among different political groups from 1994 to 2018.](image6)
As shown in image6, the percentage of Republicans, Democrats, Republican leaners and Democratic leaners who view the opposing party unfavorably has increased significantly since 1994. For example, the share of Democratic-leaning independents with a very unfavorable opinion of the Republican Party has more than quadrupled between 1994 and 2018 [4].  Currently, high percentages of both Republican and Democratic identifiers and leaners hold unfavorable views of the opposing party, with $87\%$ of Republicans and $88\%$ of Democrats viewing the opposing party unfavorably [2].

Independents who do not lean toward either party are more likely to have unfavorable views of both parties [1], with $37\%$ holding unfavorable views towards both [12]. However, this percentage has declined in recent years from a high of $36\%$ in 2015 [9]. In contrast, only $12\%$ of Americans feel favorably toward both parties [3].  ![Bar chart showing the percentage of different political groups with favorable or unfavorable views towards Republican and Democratic parties.](image7)
Image7 indicates that among independents, $28\%$ hold unfavorable views of both parties, while $15\%$ view both parties favorably.  A significant portion of Americans, about two-thirds, view one party favorably while holding an unfavorable opinion of the other [3].

In conclusion, unfavorable views toward the opposing party have increased significantly over the past two decades across all political affiliations, and while a notable portion of independents view both parties unfavorably, this has decreased recently, with most Americans expressing a favorable view towards one party and unfavorable view toward the other.

Based on surveys conducted by the Pew Research Center, there is a notable partisan divide in the United States regarding perceptions of China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak.  Republicans are significantly more critical of China's response compared to Democrats [5, 9, 12].  Specifically, Republicans are more inclined to view China's initial handling of the outbreak in Wuhan as contributing to the global spread of the virus [10].  This is evident in the survey data, where 82% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents believe China did a bad job handling the coronavirus, compared to 54% of Democrats and Democratic leaners.  ![Bar chart showing that 82% of Republican/Lean Republican think China's pandemic response is bad, compared to 54% of Democrat/Lean Democrat](image1)  Furthermore, Republicans are about twice as likely to say China did a *very* bad job in their coronavirus response [9].  This critical view extends to policy preferences, as Republicans are also significantly more likely to favor holding China accountable for its role in the outbreak, even if it damages economic relations between the U.S. and China [11, 12].  In contrast, while Democrats also hold negative views of China and are critical of their coronavirus response, this criticism is less pronounced than among Republicans [12].

In conclusion, Republicans are considerably more critical of China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak and are more inclined to prioritize holding China accountable even at the expense of economic relations, whereas Democrats, while also critical, express these views with less intensity.

From the survey conducted between June and July 2020, there are significant differences in perceptions of China's handling of COVID-19 between Republicans and Democrats.  Republicans are considerably more critical of China's handling of the pandemic than Democrats [8]. A larger percentage of Republicans (73%) believe that China's initial response to the coronavirus outbreak in Wuhan greatly contributed to the global spread of the virus, compared to Democrats (38%) [2].

![Around three-quarters of Americans say the Chinese government’s initial handling of the coronavirus outbreak in Wuhan contributed either a great deal or a fair amount to the global spread of the virus.](image2)

This partisan divide is further highlighted by the fact that 82% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents say China has done a bad job dealing with the coronavirus, compared to 54% of Democrats and Democratic leaners [4].  Republicans are also about twice as likely to believe China has done a "very bad job" (61% vs. 30%) [4].

![Republicans and Democrats have different views on whether China has done a bad job in handling coronavirus outbreak.](image8)

Over time, unfavorable views of China have increased among both Republicans and Democrats, particularly sharply in 2020.  While both parties have become more critical, the gap between Republican and Democratic views has widened [8].  As shown in the graph, the percentage of Republicans with an unfavorable view of China has consistently been higher than that of Democrats, and this difference became more pronounced in 2020.

![The percentage of unfavorable views of China among Republican/Lean Republican has been consistently higher than that of Democrats/Lean Democrat from 2005 to 2020.](image4)

In conclusion, Republicans hold a more critical view of China's COVID-19 response compared to Democrats, and this negative perception has increased significantly for both groups over time, with a widening partisan gap in recent years.

Americans hold significantly different views on China's role in the coronavirus outbreak and the approach the U.S. should take in its relationship with China, often varying along political lines. A large majority of Americans are critical of China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak, with around two-thirds stating that China has done a bad job [4].  This includes a notable percentage, 43%, who believe China has done a *very* bad job [4].  This negative perception has increased over time; in 2020, 68% of Americans rated China's handling of the outbreak as "bad," a significant rise from 53% in 2019, as visualized in the increasing trend line for "bad" ratings. ![Line chart showing the increase of Americans who say China has done a bad job dealing with the coronavirus outbreak from 2019 to 2020.](image1).  Most Americans, approximately three-quarters, believe that the Chinese government's initial response in Wuhan contributed either a great deal (51%) or a fair amount (27%) to the global spread of the virus [9].

Partisan differences are evident in these views. Republicans are considerably more critical of China compared to Democrats.  A substantial 82% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents believe China has done a bad job handling the coronavirus, compared to 54% of Democrats and Democratic leaners [11].  Furthermore, Republicans are about twice as likely to say China has done a *very* bad job (61% vs. 30%) [11]. This partisan gap is also reflected in the belief that China's initial handling is to blame for the global spread; 73% of Republicans think China's early actions contributed a great deal to the spread, compared to 38% of Democrats [9]. ![Bar chart showing Republicans are more likely than Democrats to say China has done a bad job dealing with the coronavirus.](image2).

When it comes to U.S.-China relations, opinions are divided on how to proceed. Half of Americans believe the U.S. should hold China responsible for its role in the outbreak, even if it damages economic relations [3], [7].  In contrast, 38% think the U.S. should prioritize strong U.S.-China relations, even if it means overlooking China's role [3].  Republicans are twice as likely as Democrats to favor holding China accountable, even at the cost of worsening economic ties (71% vs. 37%) [3].  Overall, there's a trend towards wanting to get tougher with China, as illustrated in the increasing line representing this sentiment over the years. ![Line chart showing increasing percentage of Americans who think the U.S. should get tougher with China.](image6).  This growing desire to be tougher on China aligns with the increasing percentage of Americans who view China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak negatively.

In conclusion, Americans largely view China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak unfavorably and a significant portion believes China is to blame for the global spread, with these critical views being more pronounced among Republicans, influencing a desire for a tougher stance in U.S.-China relations.

American perceptions of China have undergone a notable shift, particularly concerning China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic and the broader relationship between the U.S. and China. A significant majority of Americans hold a negative view of China, with this sentiment intensifying since 2018 and further exacerbated by the pandemic. [11]
![Line chart showing unfavorable views of China increasing over time, especially post-2018](image8)

A key factor driving this negative perception is the widespread belief that China mishandled the COVID-19 outbreak.  Around two-thirds of Americans perceive China as having done a bad job dealing with the coronavirus outbreak. [8]
![Bar chart showing 64% of Americans think China did a bad job handling COVID-19](image1)
Furthermore, a substantial majority also attributes blame to the Chinese government's initial handling of the outbreak for the global spread of the virus. [8]
![Bar chart showing 78% of Americans blame China for global spread of COVID-19](image5)

This negative assessment of China's COVID-19 response is strongly correlated with unfavorable views of the country overall. [7]  In fact, those who believe China handled the pandemic poorly are significantly more likely to have an unfavorable view of China. [7] Moreover, this perception of blame is linked to considering China not just as a competitor, but as an enemy of the United States. [10]

It's important to note that these critical views are not uniform across the American population.  Republicans are significantly more likely than Democrats to hold negative views of China and to criticize China's handling of the coronavirus. [4, 6]
![Horizontal bar chart comparing Republican and Democrat views on China, showing stronger negative views among Republicans on COVID-19 handling, blame, and overall favorability](image2)
![Bar chart showing unfavorable views of China broken down by party, with Republicans significantly more unfavorable than Democrats](image4)
![Bar chart comparing Republican and Democrat views on China's COVID-19 handling](image7)
![Line chart showing trends of unfavorable views by party, with Republicans consistently more unfavorable and a sharper recent increase](image3)

Despite the strong criticism and desire to hold China accountable for its role in the pandemic [3], Americans are somewhat divided on how to balance economic relations with China. While a slight majority lean towards prioritizing a strong economic relationship, a significant portion favors getting tough on China, even if it means worsening economic ties. [3] This reflects the complex interplay between holding China accountable and maintaining economic stability in the U.S.-China relationship.  [2]  Overall, the U.S.-China economic ties are viewed as being in bad shape by a large majority of Americans. [12]

In conclusion, American perceptions of China have sharply deteriorated, largely due to the widespread belief that China poorly handled the COVID-19 outbreak and is to blame for its global spread, contributing to a more negative overall view of China and straining the broader U.S.-China relationship, with notable partisan divides in these perceptions.

Negative perceptions of China among Americans have significantly worsened over time, reaching historic highs in recent years [8].  This negative trend is evident across all age groups, but older Americans consistently hold more unfavorable views.  As shown in the graph, negative views of China have increased from 53% in 2019 to 68% in 2020.

![Negative views of China increased from 2019 to 2020.](image1)

Notably, Americans aged 50 and older express substantially more negativity towards China compared to younger demographics [5].  This disparity is further illustrated in the provided chart, where the percentage of unfavorable views is highest among the 50+ age group and lowest for the 18-29 group.

![Unfavorable views of China are highest among older age groups and have increased over time for all age groups.](image2)

Moreover, a partisan gap exists, with Republicans holding considerably more negative views of China than Democrats [1]. This political divide has widened since 2012, with a much larger increase in unfavorable views among Republicans compared to Democrats [2].  The following graph demonstrates the widening gap in unfavorable views between Republicans and Democrats from 2005 to 2020.

![Unfavorable views of China are higher and have increased more sharply among Republicans compared to Democrats.](image3)

Overall, negative perceptions of China have increased dramatically among Americans, with older individuals and Republicans exhibiting the most unfavorable views, and these negative sentiments have grown more pronounced over time across both age and political divides.

Americans' unfavorable views of China have dramatically increased in recent years [3, 10].  This negative sentiment has reached historic highs, with approximately three-quarters of Americans holding an unfavorable view, marking the most negative reading in fifteen years of surveys [10, 12].  This represents a significant surge, nearly doubling since the spring of 2019 and increasing by 26 points since 2018 [4, 10].

![Line graph illustrating the trend of unfavorable views of China among Republicans and Democrats from 2005 to 2020, showing a sharp increase recently.](image2)

Examining age demographics, older Americans, particularly those aged 50 and above, consistently express more negative views of China compared to younger age groups [5].  While unfavorable views are rising across all age brackets, the intensity is notably greater among older demographics [5, 7].

![Bar chart displaying the percentage of unfavorable views of China across different age groups and political affiliations, highlighting higher unfavorable views among older age groups.](image6)

Politically, Republicans consistently exhibit more unfavorable views of China than Democrats, a trend observed over the past fifteen years [1].  Although negative views are on the rise within both parties, the increase has been more pronounced among Republicans, leading to a widening partisan gap [8, 9].  Both Republican and Democrat opinions have become increasingly negative in recent months [8, 9].

Ultimately, unfavorable views of China have substantially increased across all demographics in the United States, with older Americans and Republicans consistently holding more negative opinions, and these negative views have intensified notably in recent years.

Views on China differ significantly across age groups and political affiliations, and these views have become increasingly negative over time.  Americans aged 50 and older hold substantially more unfavorable views of China compared to younger age groups [6].  For example, only 6% of those 50 and older see China as a partner, while roughly a quarter of those aged 18 to 29 hold this view [11].  Conversely, older Americans are nearly three times more likely to view China as an enemy compared to their younger counterparts [11].

![Older Americans are more likely to have unfavorable views of China, and this trend has been increasing over time.](image2)

This age gap in unfavorable views is visually represented in the increasing percentages over the years, especially for the 50 and older demographic.  Regarding political affiliation, Republicans consistently hold more negative views of China than Democrats [4].  Currently, 83% of Republicans have an unfavorable view, compared to 68% of Democrats [4].

![Republicans are more likely to have unfavorable views of China than Democrats, and this gap has widened in recent years.](image1)

The image illustrates that the gap between Republicans and Democrats regarding unfavorable views has widened, particularly in recent years.  Over time, negative opinions of China have sharply increased [1].  Unfavorable views are at a record high, with 73% of Americans holding such views, marking the most negative reading in the past 15 years [7].  This represents a significant increase of 26 points since 2018 [7].  The percentage of Americans with a *very* unfavorable view has also nearly doubled since spring 2019, reaching a record high of 42% [3].

In conclusion, unfavorable views of China are more prevalent among older Americans and Republicans, and these negative views have substantially increased across all demographics in recent years.

Americans’ negative views of China have increased significantly over time, reaching historic highs in recent surveys [5, 12].  ![Unfavorable views of China have reached historic highs](image12)  This trend is evident across different demographics, but varies by age and political affiliation.

Older Americans consistently hold more negative views of China compared to younger age groups [1, 7].  For example, while only a quarter of 18- to 29-year-olds see China as a partner, a much smaller percentage of those 50 and older share this view [1].  In fact, older Americans are nearly three times more likely to view China as an enemy compared to their younger counterparts [1].  ![Older Americans have a more negative view of China](image7)  This disparity is further illustrated in the latest surveys, where unfavorable views among those 50 and older are substantially higher than those under 30 [7].  This trend of increasing negativity among older Americans has become even more pronounced in recent months [10].

Examining political affiliations, Republicans consistently exhibit more unfavorable views of China than Democrats, a pattern observed for the past 15 years [9].  ![Republicans have more unfavorable views of China than Democrats](image9).  However, it's important to note that negative sentiment towards China is on the rise among all partisan groups [4].  Both Republicans and Democrats are increasingly critical of China, particularly concerning its handling of the coronavirus pandemic [6].  Despite this shared negativity, the level of criticism and desire for tougher policies are more pronounced among Republicans [6].  The gap in unfavorable views between Republicans and Democrats has also widened recently [8].  ![Trend of unfavorable views of China among Republicans and Democrats](image2)

In conclusion, negative opinions of China in the U.S. have surged across all demographics, with older Americans and Republicans consistently expressing the most unfavorable views, although negative sentiment is growing across all age and political groups.

Americans are highly critical of China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak, with approximately two-thirds stating that China has done a bad job [8]. Older Americans are particularly critical of China's pandemic response [5].  Americans ages 50 and older are substantially more negative (81%) than younger age groups [6].

![Older Americans aged 50 and above are more likely to have unfavorable views of China compared to younger age groups.](image5)

This trend is also reflected in views on China's handling of the coronavirus, where 73% of those ages 50 and older find fault in China’s pandemic response, compared to lower percentages in younger age groups [10].

![Older Americans are more critical of China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak compared to younger age groups.](image4)

Politically, Republicans are significantly more critical of China's handling of the coronavirus than Democrats [9]. A large majority of Republicans (82%) say China has done a bad job, compared to a smaller majority of Democrats (54%) [10]. Republicans are also much more likely to believe China’s early handling of the pandemic contributed a great deal to its spread [7].

![Republicans are more likely than Democrats to believe that China has done a bad job handling the coronavirus outbreak.](image8)

This partisan divide is not new; Republicans have consistently held more unfavorable views of China than Democrats for the past 15 years [11].  Negative views towards China have increased among both Republicans and Democrats in recent months, widening the gap between the parties [2].  The percentage of Republicans with unfavorable views is notably higher at 83% compared to 68% for Democrats [11].

![Unfavorable views of China are higher among Republicans and have increased more sharply in recent years compared to Democrats.](image3)

In conclusion, perception of China's COVID-19 handling and general unfavorable views are more pronounced among older Americans and Republicans compared to younger demographics and Democrats, respectively, reflecting a pre-existing and widening partisan gap in opinions towards China.

Americans' perceptions of China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic vary significantly across age groups and political affiliations. Older Americans are more critical of China's pandemic response compared to younger age groups [5, 6, 12]. For example, 73% of Americans aged 50 and older find fault in China’s pandemic response [12]. This is further illustrated in the following image, which shows that older age groups are more likely to rate China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak as "bad".

![Older Americans are more likely to rate China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak as bad, with 73% of those aged 50 and older holding this view compared to 54% of 18-29 year olds.](image2)

Politically, Republicans are considerably more critical than Democrats [5, 6, 7, 12]. A substantial gap exists between Republicans and Democrats in their unfavorable views towards China, with Republicans showing a 15 percentage point higher unfavorable view than Democrats [4].  Notably, 82% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents believe China has done a bad job dealing with the coronavirus, compared to 54% of Democrats and Democratic leaners [12]. This partisan divide is also evident in the view of holding China responsible, where Republicans are about twice as likely as Democrats to support holding China accountable even at the cost of worsening economic relations [7].

In conclusion, older Americans and Republicans hold more critical views regarding China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic than younger Americans and Democrats.

Political affiliation significantly shapes foreign policy preferences in both the U.S. and Germany. In the U.S., Republicans and Democrats prioritize different foreign policy partners, although both agree on the UK as a top ally [2]. Republicans favor Israel more than Democrats, as shown by $26\%$ of Republicans considering Israel a key partner compared to only $9\%$ of Democrats. Democrats, on the other hand, place greater importance on Canada and Mexico [2].  ![Republicans favor UK and Israel as foreign policy partners, while Democrats prefer UK, China, Canada and Mexico.](image8)  However, views on Germany as a partner are similar across party lines in the U.S. [2, 3].

In Germany, political leaning also influences partner preferences, although less dramatically than in the U.S. Supporters of CDU/CSU, SPD, and Greens all prioritize France as a top partner, followed by the U.S. [7].  ![German CDU/CSU supporters are more willing to cooperate with the U.S. than Greens and SPD supporters.](image3)

Regarding cooperation, Americans generally desire more cooperation with European allies, but Germans are less inclined to seek closer cooperation with the U.S. [5].  Americans express a stronger desire for increased cooperation with Germany ($69\%$) than Germans do for cooperation with the U.S. ($50\%$) [8].  ![Americans are more inclined to want to cooperate more with Germany than Germans are to cooperate more with the U.S.](image4)  Democrats in the U.S. are more supportive of greater cooperation with Germany compared to Republicans [12]. Similarly, within Germany, CDU/CSU supporters are more inclined to favor greater cooperation with the U.S. than supporters of the Greens and SPD [12].

Political affiliations in both the U.S. and Germany influence their foreign policy partner preferences and desired levels of cooperation, with some divergence in priorities between and within each nation.

Americans and Germans show notable differences in their preferences for increased cooperation with Russia and China.  Germans are significantly more inclined towards greater collaboration with Russia compared to Americans [3].  This is highlighted by the fact that Germans are almost twice as likely as Americans to favor increased cooperation with Russia [3].  Conversely, when it comes to China, Germans are more inclined to prefer a closer relationship with the U.S. over China, whereas Americans are more divided in their preference between Germany and China [8].

![Germans are more likely than Americans to want to cooperate more with Russia and China, while Americans are more likely to want to cooperate more with Germany.](image1)

Political affiliations in both the U.S. and Germany play a role in shaping these preferences. In the U.S., Republicans are more inclined towards cooperation with Russia compared to Democrats [3, 4].  Conversely, Democrats are more likely to favor cooperation with Germany [9].

![Democrats in the U.S. are more likely to favor cooperation with the U.S. compared to Republicans, while CDU/CSU supporters in Germany are more likely to favor cooperation with the U.S. than Greens and SPD supporters.](image2)

In Germany, supporters of the CDU/CSU party demonstrate a greater inclination for cooperation with the U.S. compared to supporters of the Greens and SPD [9].  These partisan differences reveal that political ideology influences views on international cooperation in both nations.

In summary, Germans are more open to cooperating with both Russia and China compared to Americans, and political party affiliations in both countries affect these preferences, with conservatives in the U.S. and CDU/CSU supporters in Germany showing more favorable views toward Russia, while liberals in the U.S. and Greens/SPD supporters in Germany prefer cooperation with the U.S. and Germany respectively.

In both the U.S. and Germany, political party preferences significantly shape attitudes towards international cooperation. In the U.S., partisan lines are evident in the preference for close ties with either Germany or Russia. Democrats are more inclined towards Germany, with about two-thirds (66%) favoring closer relations, whereas Republicans are more divided, with 31% preferring Russia compared to 57% who prefer Germany [1].
![Democrats are more inclined towards Germany for close ties, while Republicans are more divided between Germany and Russia.](image6)

This partisan divide extends to cooperation with Russia. Republicans in the U.S. are more likely to favor greater cooperation with Russia (41%) compared to Democrats (32%) [11]. In Germany, however, the preference for cooperation with the U.S. varies across party lines. Supporters of the CDU/CSU in Germany show a greater willingness to cooperate with the U.S. than those who support the Greens and the SPD [6].
![Germans from CDU/CSU are more willing to cooperate with the U.S. than supporters of Greens and SPD.](image6)

Ideological leanings further influence these attitudes.  Conservative Americans and Germans on the right are more likely to view Russia favorably, while liberals and those on the left tend to favor the UN and EU [8].  This divide is more pronounced in the U.S. than in Germany [8].
![Ideological divides in both US and Germany influence views on Russia, UN and EU.](image5)

When it comes to China, the partisan differences are less explicitly detailed in the provided quotes, but it is mentioned that younger Americans are more likely to favor closer ties with China over Germany [5].  Germans, however, show a stronger preference for a close relationship with the U.S. over China [9].  Americans are more divided in their preference between Germany and China [9].
![Americans are almost equally divided in preference between Germany and China, while Germans prefer US over China.](image2)

Political party preferences in both the U.S. and Germany play a crucial role in shaping attitudes towards cooperation with countries like Russia and China, often reflecting broader ideological differences and foreign policy priorities within each nation.

Conservative Americans and Germans are more inclined to view Russia favorably, while liberals in both countries are less inclined to do so [6]. In the U.S., there are partisan differences in preferences for close relationships with Russia or Germany. Democrats are more likely to prefer close ties with Germany, with about two-thirds expressing this preference, while Republicans are less so at $57\%$. Conversely, Republicans are more inclined to favor close relations with Russia, with $31\%$ preferring this, compared to $21\%$ among Democrats [3].

Increased cooperation with Russia is more favored by Republicans in the U.S. ($41\%$) than Democrats ($32\%$) [8].  ![Republicans are more likely to view Germany as a less favorable partner compared to Democrats in the U.S.](image3) In Germany, supporters of CDU/CSU are more willing to cooperate with the U.S. than those who support the Greens and the SPD [11]. ![CDU/CSU supporters in Germany show higher percentage in favor of greater cooperation with the U.S. compared to Greens and SPD supporters.](image6)

In conclusion, political affiliation influences attitudes toward cooperation with Russia, with conservatives in both the U.S. and Germany showing more favorable views towards Russia compared to liberals.

Americans and Germans hold contrasting perspectives on the world's leading economic power.  Americans are inclined to believe that the United States holds the top position, whereas Germans are more likely to consider China as the leading economic power [4]. For example, half of Americans identify the U.S. as the world's leading economic power, while over half of Germans believe China holds this position [3].

![Half of Americans name the U.S. as leading economic power, while roughly half of Germans name China as leading economic power.](image8)

This difference is visually represented, where a much larger percentage of Germans (53%) compared to Americans (24%) view China as the leading economic power. [3].

Furthermore, opinions diverge regarding international entities. Germans generally hold more positive views of international organizations such as the EU compared to Americans [6].  This is especially evident in their views on the EU.

![Germans hold more positive views on EU, Russia, China, UN, and NATO than Americans.](image2)

As shown, Germans have a significantly more favorable view of the EU compared to Americans.  Roughly seven-in-ten Germans view the EU favorably, while only about half of Americans share this sentiment [6].

In summary, Americans and Germans have different views on the leading economic power and international relationships, with Americans favoring the US and showing less enthusiasm for the EU compared to Germans who are more inclined to see China as the economic leader and hold more positive views towards the EU.

Americans and Germans hold differing perspectives on international organizations and economic powers, influenced by various factors such as ideology and geographical location [1, 2, 3].  Germans generally view international bodies more favorably than Americans, especially concerning the European Union (EU) [10].

![Germans have more favorable views towards EU compared to Americans](image5)

While approximately 70% of Germans hold a positive view of the EU, only about half of Americans share this sentiment [10]. This divide is further illustrated in the context of economic power, where a significant disparity exists in the perception of which nation holds the leading position [7].

![Germans are more likely than Americans to consider China as the top economic power](image1)

As shown in the image, half of Americans believe the U.S. is the world's leading economic power, whereas over half of Germans consider China to be the economic powerhouse [7, 8]. In contrast, views on the United Nations (UN) and NATO are more aligned, although Germans still tend to rate these organizations more positively than Americans [1].

![Ideological differences impact views on international organizations and Russia in both countries](image6)

Ideology plays a significant role in shaping these perceptions in both nations [2, 11].  As depicted in the image, ideological divides are evident in both American and German views of the UN, EU, and Russia, with conservatives in both countries holding more favorable views of Russia and less favorable views of the UN and EU compared to liberals [11]. Furthermore, geographical factors within Germany also contribute to differing viewpoints, particularly concerning Russia and the EU [4].

![Germans in former East Germany view Russia more favorably and EU less favorably than those in former West Germany](image2)

Germans residing in former East Germany exhibit a greater favorability towards Russia and a less favorable view of the EU compared to their counterparts in former West Germany [4]. These differences in views are further contextualized by the broader political landscape, marked by turbulent periods in American-German relations, which shape public attitudes towards bilateral relations and security policies [6, 9].

In conclusion, Americans and Germans diverge in their views on international organizations and economic powers due to a combination of ideological differences, geographical factors within Germany, and the broader political context of American-German relations.

Americans and Germans hold different views on the necessity of military force. Americans are more likely to believe in the necessity of military force to maintain global order [5, 9], with a significant 78% agreeing with this statement, compared to only 47% of Germans ![78% of Americans agree that military force is sometimes necessary to maintain order, while 47% of Germans agree.](image8). This difference is further highlighted by their contrasting opinions on NATO obligations, where Americans show greater willingness to use military force to defend a NATO ally against Russian aggression, an idea less supported in Germany [10].

When it comes to defense spending, Americans are increasingly inclined to maintain the current spending levels of their European allies, marking a shift from 2017 when a larger percentage favored increased spending [3]. This change is visually represented in the trend of American opinions on allied defense spending from 2017 to 2019 ![The percentage of Republicans and Democrats who think European allies should increase defense spending from 2017 to 2019](image1). In Germany, public opinion is divided on whether to increase or maintain their national defense budgets [7], and these views have also evolved since 2017, as depicted in the trends of German opinions on defense spending ![The percentage of Americans and Germans who think European allies and Germany should increase, keep the same, or decrease defense spending from 2017 to 2019](image6).

Despite these differences in security and defense perspectives, younger generations in both the U.S. and Germany share more positive views on the U.S.-Germany relationship [4, 11].  Specifically, 82% of young Americans (ages 18-29) perceive the relationship as good, compared to 73% of those 65 and older. Similarly, in Germany, 40% of young people hold a positive view of relations, whereas only 31% of older Germans agree ![Percentage of people in different age groups in US and Germany who say relations are good](image3).  Overall, Americans tend to view the relationship more favorably than Germans, although positive perceptions are increasing in the U.S. and decreasing in Germany over time ![Percentage of people in US and Germany who say relations are good or bad from 2017 to 2019](image2).

In summary, American and German perceptions differ on the necessity of military force and defense spending, with Americans generally more supportive, while younger people in both nations hold more positive views of the U.S.-Germany relationship.

Americans and Germans have notably different opinions regarding military intervention and defense spending, particularly on security issues [6].  Americans are more inclined to believe in the necessity of military force to maintain global order compared to Germans [3].

![Americans are more likely than Germans to consider military force necessary for maintaining world order.](image3)

For instance, while a significant majority of Americans believe military force is sometimes necessary, only about half of Germans agree [3]. This difference extends to the context of defending NATO allies; Americans are more willing to use military force to defend a NATO ally against Russia, whereas Germans are equally divided on this issue [11].

![Americans are more inclined to agree that the U.S. should defend NATO allies from Russia, compared to Germans.](image3)

Furthermore, there is a divergence in how each nation perceives the importance of the U.S. military presence in Germany. Americans consider these bases crucial for their national security to a much greater extent than Germans do [8].

![Americans view US military bases in Germany as more important for US security than Germans do.](image2)

Concerning defense spending, Americans are less convinced of the need for European allies to increase their defense budgets.  In contrast, Germans are split on whether to increase or maintain their current defense spending levels [2, 9].

![Views on defense spending differ between Americans and Germans, with Americans leaning towards maintaining current European ally spending and Germans divided on increasing or maintaining their own.](image5)

In conclusion, American opinions lean towards a more interventionist military approach and are less supportive of increased defense spending by European allies, whereas German opinions are more reserved on military intervention and divided on defense spending.

Defense spending opinions in both America and Germany have seen shifts and partisan divides over recent years.  While a stable, relatively small percentage in both nations believes European countries are overspending on national defense [1], opinions diverge when it comes to increasing defense budgets.

![Americans and Germans show a decrease in the percentage who believe European allies should increase defense spending from 2017 to 2019, while Germans are divided between increasing or maintaining their own defense budgets.](image1)

As visualized in the bar chart, from 2017 to 2019, there's been a decrease in Americans who think European allies should increase defense spending, from $45\%$ down to $35\%$ [3]. Similarly, the percentage of Germans wanting to increase Germany's defense spending rose from $32\%$ in 2017 to $40\%$ in 2019, yet a significant portion still prefers to maintain current levels [8].

![Republican support for increased European defense spending has decreased from 2017 to 2019, although it remains higher than Democrat support.](image2)

Within the U.S., partisan divides are evident, particularly regarding the desired level of European defense spending.  Republicans are more inclined than Democrats to advocate for increased defense spending by European allies, although this Republican inclination has decreased by 14 percentage points from 2017 to 2019 [9].

![German CDU/CSU voters are more likely to favor increased defense spending compared to SPD and Greens voters.](image6)

Germany also exhibits partisan differences in opinions on defense spending.  Supporters of the CDU/CSU are more inclined to favor increases in defense spending, while Green party supporters are more skeptical, with only $28\%$ supporting increased spending [11]. SPD supporters fall in between, with $41\%$ favoring increased spending [11].

In summary, both American and German opinions on defense spending have evolved since 2017, with a general trend of decreasing support for increased European defense spending in the US, while Germans are divided on increasing or maintaining their own budgets, and partisan divides exist in both countries, influencing these perspectives.

In both the United States and Germany, public opinions regarding national defense spending have shifted between 2017 and 2019.  Initially, in 2017, around half of Germans were satisfied with their country's defense spending, but by 2019, they became divided on whether to increase or maintain current levels [3].  ![Germans are divided on increasing or maintaining defense budgets in 2019, while in 2017 half were content with current spending.](image4) Similarly, in the U.S., there was a change in perspective. In 2017, $45\%$ of Americans believed European allies should increase defense spending, but by 2019, this shifted, with half of Americans preferring spending levels to remain the same [7]. ![In 2019, 50% of Americans think European allies should keep the same defense spending, while in 2017, 45% thought they should increase it.](image4)

Partisan divisions are evident in both nations. In Germany, supporters of the CDU/CSU are more inclined to favor defense spending increases compared to supporters of the Greens, with SPD members falling in between [1]. ![CDU/CSU supporters are most in favor of increasing defense spending in Germany, followed by SPD, and then Greens.](image8)  In the U.S., Republicans are more likely than Democrats to support increased defense spending in Europe; however, this support among Republicans decreased by 14 percentage points from 2017 to 2019 [12]. ![Republican support for European defense spending increase decreased from 2017 to 2019, while Democrat support remained relatively stable.](image3)

Overall, views on national defense spending in both America and Germany have evolved from 2017 to 2019, with partisan divides influencing these perspectives within each country.

In both the U.S. and Germany, political affiliations significantly shape opinions on increasing defense spending. In the U.S., Republicans are more inclined to favor increased defense spending in Europe compared to Democrats [2]. However,  support for European allies increasing their defense budgets has decreased among Republicans from 2017 to 2019, and a similar but smaller decline is observed among Democrats [2]. This trend of decreasing support for increased defense spending is visually represented across both Republican and Democrat leaning groups in the U.S. ![Support for European allies to increase defense spending has decreased among both Republicans and Democrats from 2017 to 2019.](image7).

In Germany, partisan differences are also evident. Supporters of the CDU/CSU are generally in favor of increasing defense spending, while Green party supporters are more hesitant, and SPD supporters fall in between [9].  This is further illustrated in the data showing the percentage of voters from different German parties who believe Germany should increase its defense spending, with CDU/CSU having the highest percentage and Greens the lowest ![Percentage of voters from CDU/CSU, SPD and Greens parties in Germany who believe Germany should increase defense spending.](image4).

Examining the change over time, there has been a general decrease in Americans who believe European allies should increase defense spending between 2017 and 2019 [2]. Similarly, image data indicates trends in opinions on defense spending in both the U.S. and Germany from 2017 to 2019, though specific trends for Germany are less clearly detailed in the provided quotes ![Trends in opinions on defense spending in the U.S. and Germany from 2017 to 2019.](image8).

Political affiliations in both the U.S. and Germany strongly influence opinions on increasing defense spending, with Republicans and CDU/CSU supporters being more in favor, and there has been a trend of decreasing support for increased defense spending in the U.S. between 2017 and 2019.

In Germany, age significantly influences the perception of U.S. military bases. Younger Germans, particularly those aged 18 to 29, are more skeptical about the necessity of these bases for their national security, with approximately six-in-ten believing they are not important. Conversely, older Germans, aged 65 and above, hold a different view, with $61\%$ considering U.S. military bases crucial for Germany's defense [10]. This age-based divergence is visually represented, showing a clear trend where younger generations are less inclined to see the bases as important compared to their older counterparts. ![Younger Germans are less likely than older Germans to view U.S. military bases as important for German security.](image8)

In the United States, political affiliation plays a role in views on foreign policy partners. While both Republicans and Democrats consider the UK a vital partner, Republicans show a greater inclination towards Israel as a foreign policy partner compared to Democrats [9].  Democrats, on the other hand, place greater emphasis on Canada and Mexico as important partners.  Despite these differences, both Democrats and Republicans generally agree on Germany's importance as a foreign policy partner, ranking it fifth [9].  This partisan breakdown in foreign policy priorities is illustrated, highlighting the different countries favored by each political group. ![Republicans prioritize Israel more, while Democrats favor Canada and Mexico as foreign policy partners, but both rank Germany as fifth.](image1)

However, when it comes to the U.S. military presence in Germany, there's a partisan divide in the U.S., yet support remains generally high across both Republican and Democrat supporters [12].  Americans overall tend to perceive U.S. military bases in Germany as more critical for U.S. security than Germans perceive them for their own security [8].  While there are differing opinions based on political affiliation and nationality, a considerable level of support for the U.S. military presence in Germany exists within both American political groups.

In conclusion, age in Germany and political affiliation in the U.S. are factors that contribute to differing perceptions on the importance of U.S. military bases in Germany and the prioritization of foreign policy partners.

Partisan affiliation significantly shapes views on both the U.S.'s handling of international issues and its global engagement. Republicans are notably more critical of China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak compared to Democrats [4]. For instance, a large majority of conservative Republicans believe China did not handle the crisis well [4]. Conversely, when evaluating the U.S.'s response to the pandemic, opinions diverge sharply along party lines.  ![Conservative Republicans are particularly critical of China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak.](image4) While most Democrats criticize the U.S.’s response, a similar proportion of Republicans praise it [11]. Liberal Democrats are especially critical, with $81\%$ viewing the U.S.’s handling of the outbreak as only fair or poor, compared to just $22\%$ of conservative Republicans [12].

Regarding global engagement, Republicans generally prefer the U.S. to focus on its own domestic problems and allow other nations to manage independently [7].  ![Republicans predominantly believe the U.S. should focus on domestic issues rather than helping other countries.](image5) In contrast, over half of Democrats believe the U.S. should assist other countries with their problems [3]. This view is even stronger among liberal Democrats, with $64\%$ supporting international assistance, compared to $44\%$ of conservative and moderate Democrats [3].

Education level shows a mixed influence. While education level does not significantly alter opinions on China's handling of the pandemic [2], it does correlate with views on U.S. global engagement and handling of the disease. More educated Americans are more critical of the U.S.’s handling of the coronavirus [10] and are more supportive of the U.S. helping other nations with their problems [6].

In summary, political affiliation, particularly ideology within parties, strongly dictates views on both the U.S.'s handling of international issues and its global role, while education level primarily influences opinions on the U.S.'s approach to global engagement and its own pandemic response, but not on the assessment of other countries' handling of international issues.

Americans' perceptions of the U.S. and China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic are significantly shaped by their political affiliations, but less so by their educational backgrounds when it comes to China.  There is a wide partisan gap in how Americans evaluate the U.S.'s response to the coronavirus, while views on China's handling are more consistently negative across political lines, though with partisan nuances. [5, 9]

![Democrats are more critical of the US response, while Republicans are more praising of the US response to COVID-19.](image6)

As shown in the image, Democrats are significantly more critical of the U.S.'s response, with only $27\%$ rating it positively, compared to $71\%$ of Republicans. [6, 7] This partisan divide is evident when evaluating the U.S.'s performance, with approximately three-quarters of Democrats critical and a similar share of Republicans praising the country's handling. [7] However, when it comes to China, while majorities across political affiliations express criticism, Republicans are notably more likely to hold a negative view than Democrats. [9] Conservative Republicans are particularly critical of China's handling, with eight in ten holding this view. [9]

![Older Americans are more critical of China's handling of the pandemic.](image2)

Interestingly, education has a limited impact on opinions regarding China's pandemic response, as majorities across all educational groups express criticism. [1] However, higher education levels correlate with increased criticism of the U.S.'s handling of the pandemic. [10] More educated Americans, particularly those with postgraduate degrees, are more inclined to rate the U.S.'s response poorly compared to those with less education. [10]

In conclusion, political affiliation strongly influences Americans' views on the U.S.'s COVID-19 response, creating a significant partisan divide, while educational background has a more nuanced effect, primarily impacting perceptions of the U.S.'s, but not China's, handling.

Political affiliations significantly impact how individuals perceive the U.S. and China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic.  Americans are divided along partisan lines regarding their own country's response to the outbreak [3].  ![Americans are divided along partisan lines in assessing the US response to coronavirus; Republicans are more likely to rate it good or excellent, while Democrats are more critical](image3)  For example,  $71\%$ of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents believe the United States has done a good or excellent job, while only $27\%$ of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents share this positive view [3]. This partisan divide is clearly visualized, showing a stark contrast in approval ratings between Republicans and Democrats for the U.S.'s handling of the pandemic.

Conversely, when evaluating China's response, while majorities across political affiliations believe China did not handle the pandemic well, Republicans are significantly more critical than Democrats [9].  ![Most Americans view China's coronavirus response as only fair or poor, with Republicans holding a more negative view than Democrats](image8)  Conservative Republicans are especially likely to hold a negative view, with eight in ten expressing this sentiment [9].  Despite the general criticism of China, the partisan gap is evident, with Republicans holding a considerably harsher view compared to Democrats.

The partisan gap is particularly wide when it comes to evaluations of the U.S.'s handling compared to other countries [10].  ![Americans' views on coronavirus response by party affiliation, showing partisan differences in evaluating US, UK, Italy, South Korea, Germany and China](image7)  While partisan differences exist in views of other countries' responses, they are less pronounced than those concerning the U.S. and China [11].  This suggests that political affiliation acts as a strong filter through which Americans judge the responses of both the U.S. and China to the COVID-19 pandemic.

In conclusion, political affiliation strongly influences perceptions of both the U.S.'s and China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic, with Republicans and Democrats exhibiting significantly different viewpoints on both countries' responses.

Based on political affiliation, there are significant differences in how Americans perceive the U.S.'s ability to learn from other countries regarding the coronavirus outbreak. Democrats are considerably more inclined to believe that the U.S. can learn a great deal from the international response, contrasting sharply with Republicans who are less convinced of the value of learning from abroad [5]. Specifically, a large majority of liberal Democrats believe the U.S. can learn a great deal from other nations, while only a minority of conservative Republicans share this view [8].

Those who believe the U.S. can learn from other countries tend to have a less positive assessment of the U.S.'s current handling of the pandemic [1].  For instance, individuals who think the U.S. can learn from foreign countries are less likely to rate the country's handling of the outbreak as excellent or good, compared to those who think the U.S. cannot learn much from overseas [1]. This perspective is visualized in ![Those who think the U.S. can learn from other countries are less likely to rate the U.S.'s handling of the outbreak as excellent or good](image5), which shows that among those who think the U.S. *can* learn from other countries, only 44% rate the U.S. response positively, compared to 63% among those who think the U.S. *cannot* learn.

This partisan divide extends to trust in international organizations.  ![Trust in information from WHO and EU is divided along political lines, with Democrats showing much higher trust compared to Republicans](image3) highlights the stark contrast in trust levels across political lines, especially concerning the WHO and EU.  Liberal Democrats overwhelmingly express trust in information from the WHO, while conservative Republicans show significantly lower levels of trust [2].  Similarly, Democrats are more likely than Republicans to view the WHO as having done a good job in handling the global pandemic [4].  Overall, majorities of Americans express trust in information from the European Union and WHO [12], as seen in ![Majorities of Americans trust information from the EU and WHO](image1), where 62% trust the EU and 59% trust the WHO at least a fair amount. However, this general trust obscures the deep partisan divisions in these views [10].

In summary, Democrats are more likely than Republicans to believe the U.S. can learn from other countries' responses to the coronavirus, and this belief is associated with a less favorable view of the U.S.'s handling of the pandemic.  Furthermore, trust in international organizations like the WHO and EU is significantly divided along partisan lines, with Democrats exhibiting much higher trust compared to Republicans.

Americans are divided on whether the U.S.’s international influence will strengthen, weaken, or remain the same after the coronavirus outbreak [4].  Partisan divides are evident, with Republicans more inclined to believe U.S. influence will strengthen, while Democrats are more likely to anticipate a weakening [1].

![The image shows that Republicans are more optimistic about the U.S.'s future influence, while Democrats are more pessimistic, and those with higher education are more likely to predict a decrease in influence.](image1)

Education also plays a role, as those with higher education are more inclined to believe U.S. influence will recede [10].  For the European Union, majorities across both parties anticipate its international influence will remain largely unaffected by the pandemic [3].

![The image shows that most people believe EU influence will remain about the same after the pandemic, while opinions are more split for the U.S. and more lean towards decreased influence for China.](image5)

In contrast to the US and EU, half of Americans believe China’s global influence will decrease after the coronavirus outbreak [12], with a notable partisan divide; Republicans are more likely to foresee a decline in China's influence compared to Democrats [6]. Older Americans are also more inclined to predict a decrease in China's global influence [6].

In conclusion, views on the future international influence of the U.S., EU, and China differ significantly based on political affiliation and education level, with partisan divides particularly pronounced in perceptions of the U.S. and China, and education level influencing views on U.S. influence.

Predictions regarding the global influence of the U.S. and China after the coronavirus outbreak differ across various demographic and political groups. A significant portion of Americans anticipates a decrease in China's global influence following the pandemic [6].

![Most people think China's global influence will be less or about the same after the coronavirus outbreak.](image7)

Specifically, half of Americans believe that China will have less influence on the world stage after the coronavirus outbreak [7].  This view is more pronounced among certain groups, with partisan and age divides emerging [11].  Republicans are significantly more likely than Democrats to predict a decline in China's global clout, and older adults are more inclined than younger adults to share this expectation [12].

![Older adults and Republicans are more likely to predict that China will have less global influence after the coronavirus outbreak.](image8)

In contrast, American opinions on the U.S.'s global influence post-pandemic are more divided [8].  While a portion believes the U.S.'s international standing will be strengthened, an equal share anticipates a weakening, and a considerable number foresee no change [8]. Partisan divisions are also apparent in these predictions, with Republicans being about twice as likely as Democrats to believe the U.S.'s international influence will be strengthened, while Democrats are four times more likely to expect a weakening [3].

![Democrats and people with postgraduate degrees are more likely to think the U.S. will have less influence in world affairs after the coronavirus outbreak.](image5)

Furthermore, education levels correlate with predictions about U.S. influence, as Americans with higher education are more likely to anticipate a decline in the country's global role [9]. Predictions about the global influence of the U.S. and China after the coronavirus outbreak are shaped by partisan affiliation, age, and education level, revealing distinct perspectives across different groups.

Americans generally hold a negative view of China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak, with nearly two-thirds expressing disapproval [9]. This negative sentiment is further highlighted by the fact that unfavorable opinions of China have been on the rise [3].

![Nearly two-thirds of Americans believe China handled the coronavirus outbreak poorly.](image3)

However, significant partisan divisions exist in these perceptions. Republicans are considerably more critical of China's handling of the outbreak compared to Democrats [2]. Conservative Republicans are particularly likely to believe China did not handle the crisis well, with eight-in-ten holding this view [2].

![Conservative Republicans are significantly more likely than liberal Democrats to say the U.S. has done an only fair or poor job dealing with the coronavirus outbreak.](image5)

Looking ahead, many Americans anticipate a decline in China's global influence following the pandemic [3].  Specifically, half of Americans believe China will have less influence in world affairs [11].  Yet, this expectation is also subject to partisan divides. Republicans are more inclined than Democrats to predict a decrease in China's international clout [5].

![Half of Americans believe China will have less influence in world affairs after the pandemic.](image7)

In conclusion, Americans largely view China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak negatively and anticipate a decrease in China's future global influence, with pronounced partisan differences where Republicans hold more critical and pessimistic views compared to Democrats.

Partisan views regarding the U.S.'s role in solving global issues and its international influence differ significantly, especially when considering the impact of the coronavirus outbreak.  A notable partisan divide exists on whether the U.S. should focus on domestic problems versus engaging in international affairs [2].  In 2020, a substantial $62\%$ of Republicans believed the U.S. was doing "too much" to address global challenges, a view shared by only $26\%$ of Democrats, highlighting a significant partisan gap that has widened since 2013 [7].

![Republicans increasingly believe the U.S. does too much to solve world problems, reaching 62% in 2020.](image1)

This partisan divergence is further illustrated in views about American influence post-coronavirus.  Republicans are considerably more likely than Democrats to anticipate a strengthening of U.S. international influence due to the crisis, while Democrats are much more inclined to foresee a weakening [4].  The survey reveals stark partisan divides concerning the coronavirus outbreak and its global implications [9].

![In 2020, 62% of Republicans/Lean Republicans think U.S. does too much in solving world problems, while 26% of Democrats/Lean Democrats share this view.](image3)

Looking at the trends from 2013 to 2020, the percentage of Republicans believing the U.S. does "too much" in addressing global problems has generally increased, whereas the percentage of Democrats holding this view remains considerably lower and fluctuates [image1, image3]. Conversely, the view that the U.S. is doing "too little" has seen a decrease across both parties over the years, especially among Republicans [image7].

![The percentage of people who think U.S. does too little in solving world problems has decreased from 2013 to 2020.](image7)

Furthermore, when asked about specific actions, such as whether the U.S. can learn from other countries regarding coronavirus response, a partisan gap emerges.  In the context of the coronavirus, $60\%$ of Democrats believe the U.S. can learn a great deal from other nations, compared to only $28\%$ of Republicans [10].  In general, concerning whether the U.S. can learn a great deal from other countries about slowing the spread of coronavirus, there is a partisan divide, with Democrats being more open to the idea than Republicans [image6].

![Partisan divide exists on whether the U.S. can learn from other countries about slowing the spread of coronavirus, with Democrats being more agreeable than Republicans.](image6)

In conclusion, partisan views regarding the U.S.'s role in global problem-solving and its influence after the coronavirus outbreak are significantly divided, with Republicans increasingly favoring a reduced U.S. role and anticipating maintained or strengthened influence, while Democrats are more inclined to support international cooperation and foresee a potential decline in U.S. influence.

There are significant partisan divisions in American views on both the US's ability to learn from other countries regarding the coronavirus and its broader role in global affairs.  While a majority of Americans believe the U.S. can learn from other countries about slowing the spread of coronavirus [6], this view is not uniform across party lines.  Democrats are much more inclined than Republicans to believe the U.S. can learn a great deal from other nations [11]. For instance, $60\%$ of Democrats think the U.S. can learn a great deal, compared to only $28\%$ of Republicans [11]. This partisan gap is further illustrated in survey data, where $67\%$ of liberal Democrats believe the U.S. can learn a great deal from other nations, while only $25\%$ of conservative Republicans share this view [5].

![Democrats are more likely than Republicans to think the U.S. can learn a great deal from other countries about slowing the spread of coronavirus.](image5)

This partisan divide extends to perceptions of the U.S.'s handling of the pandemic and its global influence.  A large majority of liberal Democrats ($81\%$) assess the U.S.'s handling of the coronavirus outbreak as only fair or poor, while a much smaller percentage of conservative Republicans ($22\%$) hold the same view [3].  Furthermore, liberal Democrats are significantly more likely to believe that the pandemic will diminish America's global standing, with $56\%$ holding this belief, compared to only $8\%$ of conservative Republicans [3].  These partisan differences highlight a fundamental divergence in how different political groups perceive the U.S.'s role in the world and its capacity to learn from the international community during a global crisis.

In conclusion, partisan views significantly diverge on the U.S.'s ability to learn from other countries and its role in global affairs during the coronavirus pandemic, with Democrats being more open to international learning and more critical of the U.S.'s handling of the crisis and its global impact compared to Republicans.

Overall, Americans are divided on whether the U.S. should prioritize its own problems or help other countries with theirs [4]. A majority, $60\%$, believe the U.S. should focus domestically, while $39\%$ think the U.S. should assist other nations [4].

![Bar chart showing 60% of total respondents believe the U.S. should deal with its own problems and let other countries deal as best they can, while 39% believe the U.S. should help other countries deal with their problems.](image6)

However, political affiliation significantly influences these views.  A large majority of Republicans favor the U.S. dealing with its own problems [11]. In contrast, Democrats are more divided, although more than half believe the U.S. should help other countries [6]. This difference is further pronounced by ideology within the Democratic party, with liberal Democrats more likely to support international assistance than conservative and moderate Democrats [6].

![Bar chart showing that 76% of Republican/Lean Republican believe the U.S. should deal with its own problems, while 53% of Democrat/Lean Democrat believe the U.S. should help other countries deal with their problems.](image6)

Educational attainment also plays a role. Individuals with higher education levels are more inclined to support the U.S. helping other countries [3]. Postgraduates are the most supportive, while those with less education are more likely to prefer the U.S. focusing on its own issues [3].
