However, increased awareness does not lessen worry.  ![People who have heard a lot about automation express similar levels of worry compared to those with less awareness.](image1)  Worry remains substantial across all awareness levels; around three-quarters of Americans, regardless of their awareness, express worry about machines taking over human jobs [5, 11]. This suggests that even as people become more informed and potentially see some benefits, concerns persist.

Looking at expected outcomes, Americans generally anticipate more negative consequences than positive ones [7].  ![Americans are more likely to expect negative outcomes like increased inequality and difficulty finding purpose than positive outcomes like economic efficiency or better jobs when machines take over human jobs.](image6)  A significant 76% expect greater economic inequality, and 64% foresee people struggling to find meaningful activities [4, 9].  Conversely, only 25% believe automation will lead to many new, better-paying jobs [12].

In conclusion, while greater awareness of automation increases the perception of its realism and somewhat boosts enthusiasm, it does not diminish worry, and Americans predominantly expect negative societal and economic outcomes from widespread automation.

Public opinion on workforce automation policies reveals partisan differences and widespread agreement on limiting machines to dangerous jobs. Democrats are significantly more inclined than Republicans to support universal basic income and national service programs when automation threatens jobs [1, 7, 12].  ![Democrats are more supportive of guaranteed income and national service programs compared to Republicans.](image6) This partisan gap is evident in the support for a universal income (Democrats at 77% vs. Republicans at 38%) and a national service program (Democrats at 66% vs. Republicans at 46%) [12].

However, when it comes to limiting machines to dangerous or unhealthy jobs, there is broad consensus across party lines.  A vast majority of Americans, irrespective of political affiliation, favor restricting machines to dangerous and dirty jobs [1].  ![A large majority of Americans favor limiting machines to dangerous or unhealthy jobs, with strong favorability at 47%.](image1)  Specifically, 85% of Americans support policies that primarily confine robots and computers to jobs that are dangerous or unhealthy for humans [3].  This policy enjoys strong favor even among those who tend to oppose government intervention in job and income support, with only 3% strongly opposing it [6, 9].  This indicates a strong public desire for machines to handle hazardous tasks, a sentiment that transcends political divides.

In conclusion, while Democrats and Republicans diverge on policies like universal basic income and national service programs in response to automation, there is strong bipartisan support for limiting machines to dangerous and unhealthy jobs.

Political affiliation and education levels significantly shape public opinion on government obligations to displaced workers and the limitations on automation in businesses.

Partisan affiliation strongly influences views on government responsibility for workers displaced by automation. Democrats are considerably more inclined to believe that the government should support these workers, even if it necessitates tax increases [4].  Specifically, 65% of Democrats feel the government has this obligation [4].

![Democrats are more likely than Republicans to believe the government is obligated to care for workers displaced by automation, with 65% of Democrats holding this view compared to 30% of Republicans.](image8)

In contrast, Republicans predominantly believe that individuals should be responsible for their own financial well-being, even in the face of widespread job automation [4]. A substantial 68% of Republicans hold this view [4]. This partisan divide is also evident in support for policies like guaranteed income and national service programs, which are favored more by Democrats than Republicans [11].

![Democrats show higher support for guaranteed basic income and national service programs compared to Republicans in the context of job displacement due to automation.](image6)

Education level presents a different pattern of influence. While opinions on government obligation to displaced workers are broadly similar across different education levels [6], views on limiting automation in businesses diverge significantly [6]. Individuals with lower educational attainment are much more supportive of placing limits on the number of jobs businesses can automate. Fully 70% of those with a high school diploma or less favor such limits, compared to only 41% of those with a four-year college degree [6].

![Individuals with lower levels of education are more in favor of limiting the number of jobs businesses can replace with machines, with 70% of those with high school diplomas or less supporting this compared to 41% of college graduates.](image8)

In summary, political affiliation creates a strong divide on the perceived obligation of the government to support workers displaced by automation, while education level primarily influences opinions on limiting the extent to which businesses can automate jobs.

Based on political affiliation, Americans hold varying views on policies concerning workforce automation and job displacement.  Notably, Democrats are more inclined than Republicans to support governmental intervention to aid workers displaced by automation [4, 7, 9]. For example, a significant majority of Democrats (65%) believe the government has an obligation to care for workers displaced by automation, even if it necessitates tax increases. In stark contrast, a similar percentage of Republicans (68%) advocate for individual financial responsibility, even amidst widespread job automation [3].

![Democrats are more likely to believe the government has an obligation to take care of displaced workers, while Republicans are more likely to believe individuals should take care of themselves.](image1)

This partisan divergence is further illustrated in the context of specific policies.  Democrats show considerably stronger support for a universal basic income (77% vs. 38% of Republicans) and a national service program (66% vs. 46% of Republicans) in scenarios where machines significantly reduce human jobs [4, 9]. These disparities are visually represented, highlighting the clear partisan divide on these particular policy proposals.

![Democrats show more support for guaranteed income and national service programs compared to Republicans in the event of widespread job losses due to automation.](image6)

Despite these partisan differences, there are areas of alignment.  Both Democrats and Republicans show comparable levels of support for limiting automation to dangerous or unhealthy jobs, and for placing general limits on the number of jobs businesses can automate [4, 9, 11].  This suggests a bipartisan consensus on certain boundaries for automation in the workforce.

In conclusion, political affiliation is a key determinant in shaping American opinions on policies related to workforce automation and job displacement, particularly regarding the role of government intervention and specific support programs like universal basic income and national service, although some consensus exists on limiting automation in certain contexts.

People's attitudes toward technology and automation in the workforce are notably different depending on their education level. Workers with less education are less optimistic about technology's impact on their careers.  For example, only $38\%$ of workers with a high school diploma or less believe technology has made their jobs more interesting, and just $32\%$ feel it has increased their career opportunities [12]. In stark contrast, college graduates are significantly more likely to report positive impacts, with $64\%$ finding their work more interesting and $53\%$ seeing increased career advancement due to technology [2]. This disparity highlights that technology is viewed as a much more positive force by those with higher education [8].

![College graduates are more likely to agree that technology has made their work more interesting and increased their opportunities for advancement compared to those with a high school diploma or less.](image5)

Furthermore, age plays a role in the direct experience of automation's impact. Younger adults, specifically those aged 18 to 24, are more likely to have already experienced job displacement or reduced pay due to automation [3].  As shown in the graph, younger adults are more likely to have experienced job loss due to automation than older age groups.

![Young adults aged 18-24 are more likely to report having lost a job due to automation compared to other age groups.](image4)

In conclusion, attitudes towards workforce automation and technology's impact are significantly shaped by both education level and age, with higher education correlating with more positive perceptions and younger age groups reporting more direct negative impacts.

Workers have diverse opinions on the effects of technology in the workplace, and these opinions are often shaped by their level of education.  Individuals with higher education are more inclined to view technology as a positive influence in their professional lives, while those with less education may not share this optimistic view [11].  For example, workers with college degrees are significantly more likely to agree that technology has made their work more engaging and opened doors for career advancement [9].

![Bar chart comparing perception of technology impact on work interestingness and career advancement across different education levels.](image1)

As shown in the chart, a substantial 64% of college graduates believe technology has made their work more interesting, compared to only 38% of those with a high school diploma or less. Similarly, 53% of college graduates feel technology has boosted their career opportunities, while only 32% of those with a high school diploma or less agree [9]. This educational divide in perception highlights that the benefits of workforce technologies are not uniformly distributed, often favoring those with higher educational attainment [2].  In contrast, workers without a college education are less likely to perceive technology as a positive force in their jobs [1].

Overall, perceptions of workforce automation and technology's impact are significantly different across education levels, with higher education generally correlating with a more positive outlook.

Workers hold varied perspectives on how technology impacts their jobs and careers, with educational attainment playing a significant role in shaping these views [2, 10]. For those with higher education, technology is often seen as a positive catalyst, enhancing job interest and opening doors for career progression [1, 6].  ![Bar chart showing that 53% of workers feel technology has made their work more interesting](image1).  Indeed, a large segment of the workforce acknowledges that technology has generally made their work more engaging [7], with approximately half feeling it has increased job interest [3].  However, a notable educational divide exists; college graduates are significantly more likely to report that technology has made their work more interesting (64% compared to 38% of those with a high school diploma or less) [5]. ![Bar chart showing the percentage of workers who believe technology has made their work more interesting and increased career advancement opportunities, broken down by education level](image5).  Similarly, technology is perceived by many as a driver of career advancement [7], with nearly half of workers believing it has boosted their career opportunities [3].  ![Bar chart showing that 46% of workers feel technology has increased their opportunities for career advancement](image4).  Again, this positive view is more pronounced among college graduates, with 53% seeing increased career opportunities versus only 32% of those with a high school education or less [5].  Conversely, workers without a college education are less likely to view technology favorably in the workplace [12], and a smaller percentage find their jobs more interesting or see enhanced career prospects due to technology [11].  When examining specific technologies, a majority of workers report positive impacts from tools like word processing software (70%), smartphones (67%), and email (60%) [10]. ![Bar chart showing the positive impact of different technologies on workers' careers](image6).  In conclusion, education levels significantly influence workers' perceptions of technology's impact on job interest and career advancement, with higher education generally associated with more positive views, and specific technologies are mostly seen as beneficial.

Social media platforms elicit a range of emotional responses from their users, with amusement and anger being commonly experienced [1]. While a significant portion of users encounter content that evokes anger, a similar proportion also experiences amusement [2]. In fact, the most common emotion felt by social media users is amusement, with $88\%$ reporting encountering amusing content and $44\%$ doing so frequently [5].

Notably, emotional experiences on social media vary across age groups. Younger adults are more likely to frequently encounter content that amuses them compared to content that makes them angry. Specifically, $54\%$ of younger adults report frequent amusement, while $27\%$ report frequent anger. In contrast, older adults experience amusement and anger at more comparable rates, with $30\%$ frequently amused and $24\%$ frequently angered [6].  ![Younger adults are more frequently amused by social media content compared to older adults](image8).

Furthermore, younger adults are more prone to feeling lonely due to social media content compared to older adults. $15\%$ of users aged 18-29 frequently feel lonely, while only $4\%$ of those 50 and older share this experience [7]. This suggests that while amusement is a dominant positive emotion, negative emotions like loneliness are more pronounced among younger demographics [8].

Across all age groups, amusement is the most frequently felt emotion on social media, followed by anger, connectedness, inspiration, depression, and loneliness. ![Amusement is the most frequently experienced emotion on social media](image7).

In conclusion, amusement is the most frequently experienced emotion across all social media users, but emotional responses and their frequency vary significantly across different age groups, with younger adults experiencing amusement more often but also being more susceptible to negative emotions like loneliness.

Social media platforms evoke a range of emotions in their users, with notable differences across age groups. Younger users, in particular, frequently report feeling amused while using these platforms, but they are also more susceptible to feelings of loneliness and depression [1].

![Younger social media users frequently feel amused, lonely, and depressed.](image3)

This is further illustrated by data showing that younger adults (ages 18-29) are twice as likely to encounter amusing content compared to content that makes them angry [4]. Conversely, older adults (ages 65 and older) experience amusement and anger at more comparable rates [4].

![Younger adults are more frequently amused than older adults on social media.](image5)

Interestingly, while the frequency of encountering anger-inducing content is similar across age groups, loneliness is more pronounced among younger adults on social media [6].  A significantly higher percentage of 18- to 29-year-olds report frequently feeling lonely due to social media content compared to older age groups [6]. In terms of content types, users frequently encounter posts that are overly dramatic or exaggerated, and people making accusations without full information [12].

![Social media users frequently see dramatic posts and arguments.](image1)

In general, social media users report seeing a mix of behaviors, with roughly half observing an equal balance of kindness and bullying [2], and a considerable portion frequently encountering deceptive behavior [image7].

In conclusion, younger adults using social media experience amusement more often but also face heightened feelings of loneliness and depression, while users across age groups are commonly exposed to dramatic, argumentative, and sometimes negative content.

Social media platforms elicit varied emotional responses and expose users to a spectrum of behaviors, with differences observed across age groups and genders. While amusement is a commonly felt emotion [6], experienced by 88% of users, younger adults (18-29) are more susceptible to feelings of loneliness from social media content, with 15% reporting frequent loneliness compared to only 4% of those 50 and older [7]. This age-related difference in loneliness is visually supported in  ![Percentage of age groups feeling lonely on social media](image3), which shows younger age groups reporting higher percentages of feeling lonely. In contrast, older adults are less frequently amused by social media content [7].

Gender also plays a role in how behaviors are perceived on social media. Men are about twice as likely as women to notice deceptive content [9], as shown in ![Gender differences in perceiving deceptive behavior on social media](image6), where a larger percentage of men report frequently seeing deceptive behavior. However, the majority of both genders perceive an equal mix of deceptive and truth-correcting behaviors [9].

Furthermore, users frequently encounter negative content and behaviors.  Majorities of social media users often see drama, exaggeration, and people jumping into arguments without knowing all the facts [3, 10].  Specifically, 58% of users frequently encounter overly dramatic posts, and 59% see people making accusations or starting arguments prematurely, as illustrated in ![Frequency of encountering dramatic and argumentative content on social media](image5).

In conclusion, emotional experiences and perceptions of behavior on social media differ across age and gender, and frequently encountered content often includes drama, exaggeration, and arguments.

Social media users' experiences differ across age groups and genders in terms of emotions and encountered behaviors. Younger users report feeling amused more often but also experience loneliness and depression more frequently [4].  Older age groups, particularly those 65+, report feeling amused less frequently compared to younger age groups like 18-29, while the feeling of loneliness also increases among younger demographics. ![Younger users are more frequently amused, but also lonely and depressed on social media, compared to older users who are less frequently amused or lonely.](image8)

Regarding gender, men are slightly more likely to encounter mean or bullying content, with 29% reporting this, compared to 19% of women. Conversely, women are slightly more inclined to see kind or supportive behavior [9].  However, the majority of both genders perceive an equal mix of supportive and bullying behaviors. ![Men are more likely to see bullying content, while women are more likely to see kind content, but most see a mix.](image7)

Furthermore, social media users commonly encounter specific types of posts. Overly dramatic or exaggerated posts and posts featuring accusations or arguments without full facts are seen frequently by 58% and 59% of users, respectively [8].  These types of posts are encountered more often than posts that teach something new or posts that are misleading. ![Overly dramatic posts and argumentative posts are frequently seen by social media users.](image3)

Different age groups and genders experience varying emotions and encounter different behaviors on social media, with common post types including dramatic content and arguments.

Men and women exhibit some differences in their perceptions of online behaviors on social media platforms. Men are slightly more inclined to perceive negative behaviors such as bullying and deception.  For instance, a larger percentage of men (29%) than women (19%) report frequently seeing mean or bullying content [2]. This difference is visually represented, showing that 29% of men compared to 19% of women perceive more bullying behavior online ![Men are more likely than women to see bullying behavior online](image4).  Similarly, men are about twice as likely as women to report seeing deceptive behavior on social media (24% vs. 13%) [12].

Despite these differences in perceiving negative behaviors, the majority of both men and women agree that they encounter a mix of both positive and negative behaviors on social media.  Approximately 52% of men and 56% of women say they typically see an equal mix of supportive and bullying behaviors [2]. Moreover, a significant majority of both genders, 58% of men and 67% of women, perceive an equal mix of deceptiveness and attempts to correct misinformation [12].  Overall, around half of social media users (54%) perceive an equal mix of mean/bullying and kind/supportive behaviors [9, 11].

In addition to these perceptions of behavior, a large proportion of social media users frequently encounter certain types of content.  Specifically, dramatic or exaggerated posts are a common sight, with 58% of users reporting seeing this type of content frequently [1].  Similarly, 59% of users frequently see people making accusations or starting arguments without verifying facts [1].  These findings highlight the prevalence of dramatic and argumentative content on social media platforms, with a large majority of users encountering such posts regularly [6]. This is further illustrated by data showing that 58% of users frequently see overly dramatic or exaggerated posts ![Dramatic and exaggerated posts are frequently seen on social media](image2).

In conclusion, while men are somewhat more likely than women to perceive negative behaviors like bullying and deception on social media, the majority of both genders experience a mix of positive and negative interactions.  Furthermore, a significant majority of social media users frequently encounter dramatic or exaggerated content, indicating the common presence of such posts in the online environment.

Social media users' perceptions of content and behavior differ between men and women, which has implications for how platforms tailor recommendations and advertisements. Men are more likely to perceive deception and bullying on social media, while women are slightly more inclined to see kindness and support.  Specifically, [6] indicates that men are somewhat more likely than women to witness bullying and deceptive behavior on social media platforms. This is further supported by [1], where 24% of men report more often seeing deceptive behavior compared to 13% of women.

![Men are more likely than women to perceive deceptive or bullying content on social media.](image4)

However, it is important to note that majorities of both genders still perceive an equal mix of positive and negative behaviors. [1] states that 58% of men and 67% of women see an equal mix of deception and correction of misinformation. Similarly, [3] mentions that 52% of men and 56% of women see an equal mix of supportive and bullying behavior.  This suggests that while there are statistically significant differences in perception based on gender, the overall experience for most users involves a balanced exposure to various types of content and interactions.

Social media platforms collect vast amounts of user data to deliver targeted content [7].  Users' comfort with this data usage is context-dependent [12]. While majorities across genders find it acceptable for platforms to use their data to recommend local events [2], there is less acceptance for other uses of data.  For instance, older users are less accepting of data being used to recommend people they might know [5].

![Acceptability of social media sites using personal data varies by age group and purpose.](image8)

These differing perceptions and comfort levels suggest that social media platforms should consider gender and potentially other demographic differences when tailoring content recommendations and advertisements. While a one-size-fits-all approach might be partially acceptable due to the large proportion of users seeing a mixed environment, understanding and accounting for gendered perceptions of negative content could lead to more effective content moderation and personalized user experiences.

In conclusion, men and women exhibit some differences in their perceptions of social media content, with men being more likely to perceive negative behaviors, which, along with varying comfort levels with data usage, suggests that social media platforms could benefit from considering gender and demographic nuances in their personalization strategies.

Based on the provided information, different age groups exhibit varying levels of acceptance regarding how social media platforms utilize their personal data, and user comfort is strongly tied to the specific context of data usage.  Users' comfort with data sharing is not uniform and is heavily influenced by the purpose for which their data is used [5, 9]. For instance, a large majority of users are comfortable if their data is used to suggest events they might be interested in [6].

![Majority of users find recommending events acceptable.](image2)

However, this comfort level significantly decreases when data is used for purposes like political advertising [6].  While a large portion of users across age groups find it acceptable for platforms to use their data to recommend local events [8], opinions diverge when it comes to recommending people to connect with.

![Acceptability of data use varies across age groups and purposes.](image3)

Specifically, younger users are considerably more accepting of platforms using their data to suggest potential friends compared to older users [1, 4].  Two-thirds of social media users under 50 find friend recommendations acceptable, while less than half of users 65 and older share this view [1].  Conversely, older users are significantly less comfortable with platforms using their data for friend recommendations [4].

Users' comfort with social media data usage is highly dependent on the specific way their data is employed, and age plays a significant role in shaping these perceptions, particularly when it comes to friend recommendations.

The public generally views the fairness and effectiveness of algorithmic programs similarly, but there are notable exceptions, especially concerning personal finance scores [1]. Americans are broadly skeptical about the fairness of these systems, with none being viewed as fair by a clear majority [4].  Notably, personal finance scores and video job interview analyses are considered fair by only around one-third of the public [2, 4].

![Personal finance score has the largest positive difference between perceived effectiveness and fairness, while criminal risk score has a negative difference.](image8)

Despite similar effectiveness ratings for personal finance scores and criminal risk scores [8, 9], the public perceives them differently in terms of fairness [8].  Only 32% of Americans find personal finance scores fair, while 50% believe criminal risk scores are fair [8]. This discrepancy is further highlighted by the large difference between perceived effectiveness (54%) and fairness (32%) for personal finance scores, a 22-percentage-point gap, the largest among the scenarios considered [11].  Conversely, video job interview analysis and personal finance scores are deemed unacceptable by two-thirds of Americans [2].

This skepticism and the variance in fairness perceptions across different systems suggest that public trust in algorithmic decision-making is not uniform and is highly context-dependent [6].  While effectiveness is a factor, fairness appears to be a crucial determinant of public acceptance, with personal finance scoring algorithms facing significant public distrust due to perceived unfairness. In conclusion, perceptions of fairness and effectiveness in automated systems diverge, especially with personal finance scores which are seen as effective but unfair, highlighting a potential crisis of public trust in certain algorithmic applications.

The public perception of Donald Trump's ethical standards and trustworthiness is notably lower when compared to previous administrations, with significant partisan divisions influencing these views.  A majority of the public, 59%, rates the ethical standards of top Trump administration officials as "not good or poor," which is lower than the ratings for previous administrations going back to Reagan [5].  Views of ethical standards for Trump officials are at record lows compared to administrations since the 1980s [2].  In contrast, ethical ratings for previous presidents like Clinton, G.W. Bush, Obama, G.H.W. Bush, and Reagan were higher, as shown in the bar chart.

![Bar chart showing ethical standards ratings for presidents from Reagan to Trump, with Trump's ratings being the lowest.](image1)

This negative perception is further highlighted by the fact that 58% of the public say they trust what Trump says less than they trusted previous presidents [3].  Distrust in Trump's statements has also increased since 2017 [8]. However, this general sentiment is heavily influenced by political affiliation.  There is a deep partisan divide, where 90% of Democrats believe the ethical standards of Trump officials are "not good or poor," with 67% saying they are "poor" [1].  On the other hand, 76% of Republicans believe the ethical standards are "excellent or good" [1]. This partisan gap is also evident in trust, where 94% of Democrats trust Trump less than previous presidents, while 58% of Republicans trust Trump *more* [7, 11].

![Bar chart showing that overall, more people trust Trump less than previous presidents, but a majority of Republicans trust him more, while almost all Democrats trust him less.](image4)

This partisan divide in ethical perception has been consistent and even widened over time, as shown in the trend data.

![Bar chart showing partisan divide in ethical standards of top administration officials from Jan 2017 to Jan 2019, with Democrats consistently rating standards lower and Republicans higher.](image6)

In conclusion, public perception of Trump's ethical standards and trustworthiness is generally lower than for previous presidents, marked by a stark partisan divide where Republicans hold significantly more positive views than Democrats.

Public perception of Trump's responsibilities and trustworthiness is notably different from that of previous presidents, often marked by lower trust and significant partisan divides. A majority of the public, $64\%$, believes Trump should release his tax returns, a view strongly supported by Democrats ($91\%$) but less so by Republicans ($32\%$) [10].

![Majority say Trump has responsibility to release tax returns](image4)

This expectation of transparency is contrasted by the overall public trust in Trump's statements, where $58\%$ trust him less than previous presidents [6].  Distrust in Trump's statements has even increased since April 2017 [12].  Partisan divisions are stark here as well.  Democrats overwhelmingly ($94\%$) distrust Trump's statements compared to past presidents [8], while Republicans are more inclined to trust Trump more ($58\%$) [11].

![Public trust in Trump compared to previous presidents](image6)

Furthermore, views on the ethical standards of Trump administration officials are at record lows compared to previous administrations, a trend dating back to the 1980s [4].  This negative perception is not uniform; partisans are deeply divided, with most Republicans ($76\%$) viewing the ethical standards as good or excellent, and a large majority of Democrats ($90\%$) considering them not good or poor [9].

![Views of ethical standards of top Trump administration officials by party](image7)

While overall views of Trump and his administration are critical, there is a slightly more positive view regarding his impact on the economy.  $40\%$ of the public believes Trump's policies improved economic conditions [7]. However, even on economic policies, partisan polarization is evident and has increased since 2017 [3]. Republicans largely believe his economic policies improved conditions, while Democrats have become more negative [3].

![Public views on Trump’s economic policies – Jan 2019 vs Oct 2017](image5)

In summary, public perception of Trump's responsibilities and trustworthiness is generally lower than for previous presidents, characterized by significant partisan polarization across various aspects from ethical standards to economic policies and trust in his statements.

Perceptions of Trump's presidency are significantly divided along political lines, particularly regarding ethical standards and long-term success, and these views are often more polarized and negative compared to previous administrations.  Views on the ethical standards of Trump administration officials are notably lower than those of the past five administrations, marking a record low [1, 10].  A stark partisan divide is evident, with the vast majority of Democrats expressing negative views on the ethical standards, while most Republicans hold positive views, though few deem them "excellent" [3].

![Democrats are overwhelmingly more likely to believe Trump administration officials have lower ethical standards compared to previous administrations.](image6)

While public opinion is largely critical of Trump's administration across various domains, there's a relatively brighter outlook on his economic impact [11].  Specifically, 40% of the public believes Trump's policies have improved economic conditions, exceeding the 28% who think they've worsened them [11]. However, partisan polarization extends to economic perceptions as well, with Republicans increasingly positive and Democrats increasingly negative about Trump's economic policies since 2017 [12].

![In January 2019, a larger percentage of both Republicans and Democrats believe Trump's economic policies have had a greater effect, either positive or negative, compared to October 2017.](image4)

Looking at long-term success, about half of the public anticipates Trump's presidency will be unsuccessful, a more negative outlook than for Obama and George W. Bush at comparable points in their terms [5].  Partisan lines are deeply drawn here too, with most Republicans predicting success and most Democrats predicting failure [7].  Notably, fewer people believe it's "too early to tell" about Trump's success compared to his predecessors, indicating a more decisive public opinion, especially among partisans [2, 5].

![In January 2019, predictions of presidential success are more polarized for Trump than for Obama and Bush at similar points in their presidencies, with fewer people saying it's "too early to tell" for Trump.](image8)

In conclusion, perceptions of Trump's presidency are strongly shaped by political affiliation, showing deep divides in trust, ethical evaluations, and expectations for long-term success, often more pronounced and negative overall when compared to previous presidents.

Based on the provided quotes, perceptions of Trump's presidency are significantly more polarized along partisan lines compared to Obama, Bush, and Clinton.  A large majority of Democrats believe Trump will be an unsuccessful president [1], with 80% holding this view in January 2019, as depicted in the 'Trump (Jan 2019)' section of ![Democrats overwhelmingly view Trump as unsuccessful](image2). Conversely, most Republicans, around 65%, anticipate Trump's success in the long run [6], which is also visualized in the 'Trump (Jan 2019)' section of ![Republicans largely expect Trump to be successful](image2).  This partisan divide is starker for Trump than for previous presidents at comparable points in their terms, as shown in the overall comparison in ![Partisan views on presidential success for Trump, Obama, Bush, and Clinton](image2).

Furthermore, public opinion on Trump's long-term success is more negative than it was for Obama, Bush, and Clinton during similar periods.  Nearly half of Americans (47%) predicted Trump would be unsuccessful long-term, a higher percentage than for his predecessors [5], and this is visually supported by the 'Trump' column being the tallest in the 'Unsuccessful' segment in ![Comparison of long-term presidential success predictions across Clinton, Bush, Obama, and Trump](image3).  Moreover, fewer people believe it is "too early to tell" about Trump's success compared to Obama, Bush, and Clinton at similar stages [3], a trend highlighted by the shorter 'Too early to tell' segment for Trump in ![Comparison of 'too early to tell' responses across presidents](image3).

Partisan polarization is also evident in views on economic policies.  Republicans overwhelmingly believe Trump's economic policies improved conditions, increasing from 63% in October 2017 to 79% in January 2019 [9], a rise illustrated by the 'Rep/Lean Rep' bar for 'Better' becoming taller from 'Oct 2017' to 'Jan 2019' in ![Republican views on Trump's economic policy improving conditions increased over time](image1).  Conversely, Democrats have become more negative about Trump's economic policies [9], and as shown in ![Democratic views on Trump's economic policy worsening conditions increased over time](image1), almost half of Democrats in January 2019 felt his policies worsened economic conditions.

In summary, perceptions of Trump's presidency are characterized by strong partisan divides, a more decisively negative overall long-term outlook compared to his predecessors at similar points, and increasing polarization, especially concerning economic policies.

The perceptions of President Trump's potential success are strongly divided along partisan lines, and these perceptions are mirrored in the confidence levels regarding the Mueller investigation.  Views on both Trump’s handling of matters and the Mueller investigation are deeply partisan [2].  Republicans are more inclined to believe Trump will be successful, as evidenced by the fact that 65% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents anticipated Trump's success in January 2019 ![Republicans' view on Trump's success in Jan 2019](image6).

Conversely, Democrats largely anticipate Trump will be unsuccessful, with a significant 80% holding this view [9]. This partisan divide is further illustrated when compared to views on past presidents; partisans are now more likely to express a view on Trump's success than they were for prior presidents [3]. For example, views on Obama's potential success in 2011 were less definitively split along party lines than views on Trump's success in 2019 ![Views on Obama's potential success in Jan 2011](image6).

Similarly, confidence in the Mueller investigation is also significantly influenced by partisanship.  A large majority of Democrats, 72%, express confidence in the fairness of Mueller's investigation [10], while a larger share of Republicans, 58%, are not confident in Mueller [10].  This partisan split is visualized in confidence levels in Mueller’s investigation, showing Democrats having higher confidence than Republicans ![Partisan confidence in Mueller investigation](image7).  Moreover, confidence in Trump's ability to handle the investigation appropriately is low overall [11], and particularly low among Democrats, with 92% expressing a lack of confidence [5], as shown by the stark partisan divide in confidence in Trump handling the investigation ![Partisan confidence in Trump handling investigation](image8).

In conclusion, partisan affiliation strongly dictates perceptions of Trump's presidential success and confidence in the Mueller investigation, with Republicans being more optimistic about Trump's success and less confident in Mueller, and Democrats holding the opposite views.

Perceptions of economic conditions and job availability are significantly divided along partisan lines.  Currently, a notable partisan gap exists in views of job availability, with  $71\%$  of Republicans stating there are plenty of jobs available, while only $53\%$ of Democrats share this view [1, 6]. This partisan divide is also evident in personal financial situations, where Republicans are more likely to rate their financial situation as excellent or good compared to Democrats [3].

![Republicans are more likely than Democrats to say plenty of jobs are available.](image4)

This partisan gap in job availability views has been a consistent trend, but positive views on job availability have increased overall since 2017 [2].  As shown in the graph, Republicans’ perception of job availability is consistently higher than Democrats’, and this gap widens particularly after 2016 [9].  Notably, current public perception of local job availability is at its most positive in the last two decades across both parties [4, 8].

![The graph shows the trend of "Plenty of jobs available" for Republicans and Democrats over the years, indicating a partisan gap that widens after 2016.](image2)

Furthermore, Republicans are more optimistic about their financial future, with a larger percentage expecting their finances to improve over the next year compared to Democrats [7].  This is visually represented in the graph below, showing the trend of expecting finances to improve, where Republicans consistently show higher percentages than Democrats.

![Republicans are consistently more likely than Democrats to expect their finances to improve in the next year.](image8)

In summary, there is a clear partisan divide in the perceptions of economic conditions and job availability, with Republicans consistently holding more positive views than Democrats, although overall perceptions of job availability have become more positive across both parties over time.

Perceptions of job availability are significantly divided along partisan lines.  Currently, 71% of Republicans say there are plenty of jobs available, compared to 53% of Democrats [4, 6]. This partisan gap is also evident in personal financial ratings, where Republicans are more likely to rate their financial situation as excellent or good (62% vs. 44% for Democrats) [9]. This partisan divide is visually represented in ![Line chart showing Republicans consistently more optimistic about job availability than Democrats from 2001 to 2019](image1), illustrating the diverging trends between the two parties over time.

Over time, public views on local job availability have become increasingly positive, reaching their most positive point in decades [2, 3].  This positive shift is reflected in the rise in the percentage of Americans saying there are plenty of jobs, from 50% in October 2017 to 60% currently [11, 1]. This increase is particularly pronounced among Republicans, with their positive views rising from 58% in October 2017 to 71% currently [6, 5].  ![Line chart showing Republican optimism about economic conditions increasing sharply since 2017](image2) and ![Line chart showing a general increase in perceived job availability, especially post-2009](image6) further support this trend of increasing job availability perceptions. The partisan gap and the overall positive trend are also visible in the perception of personal financial situation, as shown in ![Line chart showing Republicans consistently more positive about their financial situation than Democrats](image7).

In conclusion, there is a partisan divide in job availability perceptions, with Republicans consistently more positive than Democrats, and these positive perceptions have increased over time, especially for Republicans.

Public opinion on Wall Street's impact on the economy is significantly divided along partisan lines. Republicans are more inclined to believe that Wall Street benefits the economy, while Democrats are more divided on this issue.  More Republicans (55%) believe Wall Street helps the economy than hurts it [2].  Conversely, Democrats are almost equally split, with 46% saying Wall Street hurts the economy and 41% saying it helps [7].

![Republicans are more likely to say Wall Street helps the American economy, while Democrats are more divided.](image1)

This partisan divergence is further highlighted when comparing satisfaction levels with national conditions.  Overall public dissatisfaction with the state of the nation is high [12], with seven in ten Americans expressing dissatisfaction [5].  However, this dissatisfaction is much more pronounced among Democrats, where a mere 8% are satisfied, and a staggering 90% are dissatisfied [8].  In contrast, Republicans are more evenly split, with 47% satisfied and 47% dissatisfied [1].  Historically, satisfaction levels have fluctuated, but a partisan gap has persisted, especially evident during the Trump presidency where Democratic satisfaction remained consistently low [6].

![Satisfaction with the state of the nation from 2001 to 2019, showing partisan trends.](image3)

![Satisfaction with the state of the nation from 1990 to 2019, showing long-term trends.](image5)

![Satisfaction with the state of the nation under different presidential administrations, highlighting partisan divides.](image7)

In conclusion, public opinion on Wall Street's economic impact and satisfaction with national conditions are strongly influenced by political affiliation, with Republicans generally holding more positive views on both compared to Democrats.

Public satisfaction with the state of the nation has been generally low for over a decade [4], and recently, seven in ten Americans express dissatisfaction [5], a figure that has increased from previous months [11].  This overall dissatisfaction is further highlighted when examining historical trends.

![The graph illustrates the trend of public satisfaction and dissatisfaction, showing a long period where dissatisfaction is higher than satisfaction, particularly after 2007.](image5)

Examining satisfaction through a partisan lens reveals significant divisions. Republican satisfaction, while initially higher, has seen a notable decrease [2], while Democratic satisfaction remains consistently low [3, 10].  This partisan gap is evident in satisfaction levels during the Trump presidency, with starkly contrasting views between Republicans and Democrats [8].

![The graph shows partisan views on national conditions, highlighting the divergence between Republican and Democratic satisfaction levels, particularly during the Trump administration.](image4)

This partisan polarization extends to views on economic matters, such as the impact of Wall Street.  Republicans are more inclined to view Wall Street as beneficial to the economy [6], whereas Democrats are more divided on this issue, with nearly equal proportions believing Wall Street either helps or hurts the economy [7]. This division is also reflected in survey data from January 2019 [8].

![The bar chart illustrates the partisan divide in opinions on Wall Street's impact, with Republicans more likely to see it as helpful and Democrats more split.](image8)

In conclusion, public satisfaction with the nation is low and decreasing, underscored by a significant partisan divide where Republicans and Democrats hold contrasting views on both national conditions and economic factors like Wall Street's influence.

Public confidence in Donald Trump's ability to make good appointments to federal courts is divided, with significant partisan differences and varying levels compared to other responsibilities.  While nearly half of the public expresses some confidence in Trump on federal court appointments, a slightly larger portion lacks confidence [11].

![Public confidence in Trump's ability to handle various issues, showing "Make good appointments to the federal courts" in comparison to other issues such as "Negotiate favorable trade agreements" and "Work effectively with Congress."](image3)

Looking at the breakdown by party, Republicans show much greater confidence in Trump's judicial appointments compared to Democrats.  As shown in the image, the confidence levels vary significantly between party lines for making good appointments to the federal courts.

![Confidence in Trump's abilities across different issues, broken down by party affiliation (Republican/Lean Republican vs. Democrat/Lean Democrat), highlighting "Make good appointments to the federal courts" and comparing it to "Negotiate favorable trade agreements" and "Manage the executive branch effectively."](image7)

Comparing confidence levels across different tasks, for both Republicans and Democrats, confidence in Trump's ability to make good federal court appointments is generally high among Republicans and low among Democrats, similar to the pattern observed for other issues like negotiating trade agreements and managing the executive branch.

In conclusion, Republicans are significantly more confident than Democrats in Trump's ability to make good federal court appointments, a pattern consistent with their differing confidence levels across various presidential tasks such as trade negotiations and executive branch management.

The public is largely not confident that Trump keeps his business interests separate from his presidential decisions, with only 28% being very confident and 13% somewhat confident [8].  A majority (58%) are not too or not at all confident [8]. This lack of confidence is further illustrated in image8, which shows that a large portion of the total public falls into the "Not too" and "Not at all" confident categories.

![A bar chart displaying the public confidence level in Trump keeping business interests separate, categorized as very, somewhat, not too, and not at all confident, showing the majority is not confident.](image8)

However, there is a stark partisan divide in this view.  Most Republicans (55% very and 23% somewhat) are confident that Trump separates his business interests from his presidential decisions [5].  Conservative Republicans are even more confident (66% very confident) [5]. In contrast, Democrats are deeply skeptical, with nearly seven-in-ten (69%) saying they are not at all confident and another 20% not too confident [6]. Liberal Democrats are particularly skeptical, with 83% stating they are not at all confident [6]. Image8 visually confirms this partisan divide, highlighting the contrasting confidence levels between Republican and Democrat leaning groups.

![A bar chart illustrating the partisan divide in confidence levels regarding Trump separating business interests, with Republicans showing higher confidence and Democrats showing lower confidence.](image8)

Interestingly, while confidence in Trump separating business interests is divided along party lines, the perception of his responsibility to release tax returns also shows a partisan split, but with a different majority view within each party.  A majority of the public (64%) believes Trump has a responsibility to release his tax returns [9].

![A bar chart showing that 64% of the public believes Trump has a responsibility to release his tax returns, and 32% believes he does not.](image2)

However, most Republicans (64%) do not think Trump has a responsibility to release his tax returns, while only 32% of Republicans believe he does [10].  This contrasts with the general public's view and highlights a key difference in partisan opinions on financial transparency versus confidence in conflict of interest management.

![A bar chart depicting the partisan divide on whether Trump has a responsibility to release tax returns, with most Republicans saying no and most Democrats saying yes.](image2)

In conclusion, confidence in Trump separating his business interests from presidential decisions is low overall, with a strong partisan divide where Republicans are largely confident and Democrats are highly skeptical, and this contrasts with the public's view that he should release his tax returns, a view not shared by the majority of Republicans.

Partisan divides significantly influence perceptions of the effectiveness of the COVID-19 response and trust in institutions, creating starkly different viewpoints across the political spectrum.  Democrats and Republicans diverge considerably in their assessments of various aspects of the pandemic response. For instance, views on public health officials such as the CDC differ greatly along partisan lines, with Democrats expressing much higher confidence than Republicans.  ![Democrats are more likely to have positive views of public health officials such as those at the CDC compared to Republicans.](image1)  As shown in the image, 72% of Democrats and Democratic leaners say public health officials are doing well in responding to the outbreak, compared to 53% of Republicans and Republican leaners. [9] This partisan gap in the perception of public health officials has widened over time, primarily due to a decline in positive assessments among Republicans.  ![The percentage of Republicans giving positive ratings to public health officials such as those at the CDC has decreased significantly from March to August.](image4)  Initially, in late March, 84% of Republicans rated public health officials positively, but this dropped to 53% by August [12].

Furthermore, partisan divides are evident in how Americans perceive the U.S. response to COVID-19 compared to other wealthy nations.  ![Democrats are significantly more likely than Republicans to say the U.S. response to the coronavirus has been less effective than other wealthy countries.](image7)  A large majority of Democrats and Democratic leaners (87%) believe the U.S. response has been less effective than that of other wealthy countries, whereas only 22% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents share this view [8].  These partisan differences extend to the perceived reasons for the continued outbreak.  ![Democrats are much more likely than Republicans to view the federal government's response as inadequate and lifting COVID-19 restrictions too quickly as major reasons for the continued outbreak.](image8)  A significant 82% of Democrats consider the federal government's response to be inadequate as a major reason for the outbreak's continuation, compared to only 21% of Republicans [2].

In conclusion, partisan affiliation is a major factor shaping public opinion on the effectiveness of the COVID-19 response and trust in institutions, leading to substantial differences in how Democrats and Republicans perceive the handling of the pandemic and the performance of various officials and organizations.

Partisan divisions significantly shape perceptions of the COVID-19 outbreak response, particularly concerning public health officials and Donald Trump.  There are considerable partisan differences in how public health officials are viewed, with Democrats holding much more positive views than Republicans [7].  This divergence is highlighted by the fact that 72% of Democrats rate public health officials positively, compared to only 53% of Republicans [7].  ![{Democrats view public health officials more positively than Republicans, with 72% vs 53% approval respectively}](image8)

This partisan gap has widened over time due to a substantial decline in positive ratings among Republicans.  Since March, Republican approval of public health officials has plummeted by 31 percentage points, from 84% to 53% [2, 10]. In contrast, Democrats' views have remained largely consistent, with around 74% approval in March and 72% currently [2, 10].  ![{Republican approval of public health officials dropped significantly from 84% in March to 53% in August, while Democrat approval remained stable at around 73%}](image2)

Similarly, partisan lines are deeply drawn when evaluating Donald Trump's response to the pandemic [4].  Democrats are significantly more critical of Trump's handling of the outbreak.  A large majority of Democrats, 82%, rate Trump's response as "poor," a steep increase from 56% in March [3].  Conversely, Republicans are much more likely to view his response favorably, although his overall ratings have declined since March [5].  ![{Democrats overwhelmingly disapprove of Trump's COVID-19 response, with only 6% approval, while Republicans largely approve at 73%}](image8)

Overall assessments of Trump's response have worsened since March, and this decline is reflected across party lines, though more intensely among Democrats [5].  Democrats' negative views have solidified, while Republican support has softened, contributing to a significant partisan divide in appraising both public health officials and the former president's handling of the crisis. Partisan affiliation is a major factor in shaping public opinion on the COVID-19 response by public health officials and Donald Trump.

From March to August, public health officials have experienced a decline in positive ratings, particularly among Republicans [6]. Initially, $84\%$ of Republicans rated public health officials positively, but this figure dropped to $53\%$ by August [1]. This contrasts with Democrats, whose views remained largely stable, with $74\%$ positive ratings in March and $72\%$ in August [1].  ![Republican positive ratings of public health officials significantly declined from March to August, while Democrats remained stable.](image7)

This partisan divergence is further illustrated by the overall decline in positive assessments of public health officials, which decreased from $79\%$ in March to $63\%$ by August [4]. The shift is predominantly among Republicans, with only about half now giving positive ratings [12]. Currently, a substantial partisan gap exists, with $72\%$ of Democrats and those leaning Democratic viewing public health officials favorably, compared to the lower Republican figure [7]. ![Current partisan divide in public health officials' ratings.](image5)

Conversely, Donald Trump's approval for his handling of the coronavirus has also decreased since March [9, 10]. Overall, his approval rating for coronavirus response has fallen by 11 points [9].  ![Donald Trump's coronavirus response rating has declined since March.](image7)  This decline is reflected in the increase in Democrats who rate his response as "poor," rising from $56\%$ in March to $82\%$ in August [8].  Despite the overall disapproval, Trump's job performance remains strongly supported within his party, with $77\%$ of Republicans approving [2].

In conclusion, both public health officials and Donald Trump have seen a decrease in approval ratings from March to August regarding the coronavirus response, with a significant partisan divide where Republican approval notably decreased for public health officials while Democratic disapproval increased for Donald Trump’s handling of the pandemic.

Americans hold more critical views of Trump's COVID-19 response compared to state governments. Evaluations for both have declined since March, but the drop and overall negativity are more pronounced for Trump.  While state government positive evaluations decreased from 70% to 56%, Trump's poor rating has increased to nearly half of Americans [8, 9].

![Americans rate state elected officials' COVID-19 response as net positive at 56% excellent or good, while Donald Trump's response receives only 37% positive ratings.](image8)

This is further evidenced by the fact that nearly half of Americans rate Trump’s response as "poor" [9], and broadly negative assessments exist for the overall U.S. response under his leadership [7].  Although state government ratings have also declined, they remain higher than Trump's, indicating a relative preference for state-level handling of the pandemic [8].

Americans view Trump's COVID-19 response more negatively than state governments, despite declining positive ratings for both.

Americans perceive public health officials more favorably than elected officials in handling the COVID-19 outbreak, although positive evaluations have decreased for both since March.  Public health officials are still viewed more positively than elected officials.  As shown in the bar chart, 63% of Americans rate public health officials' response as excellent or good, which is higher than the ratings for state officials (56%), local officials (60%), and significantly higher than Donald Trump's rating (37%). ![Public health officials are rated more positively than elected officials in COVID-19 response.](image2) However, positive views of public health officials have declined from 79% in March to 63% currently [5]. Similarly, positive evaluations for state and local government officials have also decreased since March [1].

A key factor contributing to the continued coronavirus outbreak, as indicated by a large majority of Americans, is the lack of adherence to public health guidelines.  Three-quarters of Americans believe that the outbreak persists largely because too few individuals are following guidelines on social distancing and mask-wearing [2].  This is further supported by the bar chart, where 75% of respondents identify "Not enough people social distancing and mask-wearing" as a major reason for the continued outbreak. ![Lack of social distancing and mask-wearing is a major reason for continued outbreak.](image8)  Additionally, over half of Americans (58%) consider the premature lifting of restrictions in some areas as a significant factor in the ongoing outbreak [2], as shown in the same chart with "Restrictions have been lifted too quickly in some places" being identified as a major reason by 58% of respondents.

In summary, Americans view public health officials more positively than elected officials in their COVID-19 response, but both have seen declining approval.  The primary factor contributing to the continued outbreak is perceived to be insufficient public adherence to social distancing and mask-wearing guidelines, followed by the premature lifting of restrictions.

The public is notably divided on which level of government should take the primary role in managing policies to control the spread of COVID-19 [3].  While a slight majority, 51%, believes state and local governments should be primarily responsible, a considerable 48% think the federal government should lead [8]. This division is strongly influenced by political affiliation, as Republicans predominantly feel state and local governments should be in charge, whereas Democrats largely believe the federal government should bear the main responsibility [8].

![Republicans believe state and local governments should be primarily responsible for developing and implementing policies to limit the spread of the coronavirus, while Democrats think the federal government should bear most of the responsibility.](image4)

Insufficient adherence to social distancing and mask-wearing is widely recognized as a major factor contributing to the ongoing coronavirus outbreak [5].  This view is held by a large majority across both Democrats (about 90%) and Republicans (57%), although with differing magnitudes [1].  Overall, most Americans (75%) consider insufficient social distancing and mask-wearing as a major reason for the continued spread [12].

![Percentage of Americans who believe each factor is a major reason for the continued coronavirus outbreak in the U.S.](image1)

Looking at the partisan divide, while insufficient social distancing is the top reason cited by both parties, Democrats are significantly more inclined than Republicans to view factors like inadequate federal government response and the premature lifting of COVID-19 restrictions as major reasons for the outbreak's continuation [11].  For instance, 82% of Democrats see inadequate federal response as a major reason, compared to only 21% of Republicans [11].

![Breakdown by party affiliation on major reasons for continued coronavirus outbreak, highlighting the partisan divide on inadequate federal response and lifting restrictions too quickly.](image2)

Political affiliations significantly shape perceptions of government responsibility during the COVID-19 pandemic, and while insufficient social distancing is a commonly cited major reason for the continued outbreak across party lines, partisan divides are evident in the degree of importance attributed to different factors, particularly concerning governmental responses and policy decisions.

Political affiliations significantly shape perceptions regarding the factors prolonging the COVID-19 outbreak, particularly concerning government response and social distancing. Democrats and Republicans diverge considerably in their viewpoints on these critical aspects.

Democrats are substantially more inclined than Republicans to consider the federal government's response as inadequate and the premature lifting of COVID-19 restrictions as major factors in the outbreak's continuation [1]. For instance, a striking $82\%$ of Democrats view an inadequate federal response as a major reason, compared to a mere $21\%$ of Republicans [1].  This partisan divide is further highlighted when considering the lifting of COVID-19 restrictions too quickly, with $82\%$ of Democrats and $31\%$ of Republicans identifying it as a major contributing factor [1].

![Democrats are much more likely than Republicans to consider inadequate federal response and lifting restrictions too quickly as major reasons for continued outbreak.](image2)

Conversely, while a smaller percentage overall believe it's simply impossible to control the virus's spread, Republicans are more likely than Democrats to hold this view [2].  However, insufficient social distancing emerges as a commonly cited major reason across the political spectrum [3, 7].  Notably, a large majority of Americans, irrespective of party lines, recognize insufficient social distancing and mask-wearing as a primary driver of the continued outbreak [3, 5].  Specifically, three-quarters of Americans point to the lack of adherence to social distancing and mask guidelines as a major reason [4, 5].

![Most Americans consider insufficient social distancing and mask-wearing as major reasons for the continuation of the outbreak.](image7)

Even within partisan groups, insufficient adherence to social distancing and mask-wearing guidelines is recognized as a leading reason for the ongoing outbreak.  For example, approximately nine-in-ten Democrats and a narrower majority of $57\%$ of Republicans consider this a major factor [6].

Political affiliation strongly dictates views on the primary reasons for the continued COVID-19 outbreak, with Democrats emphasizing government inadequacies and premature restriction lifting, while both parties acknowledge insufficient social distancing as a major contributing factor.

There is a significant partisan divide in how Americans perceive the federal government's handling of the COVID-19 outbreak.  A large majority of Democrats believe that an inadequate federal response is a major factor in the continued spread of the virus, while a much smaller percentage of Republicans share this view [11].  Specifically,  $82\%$  of Democrats consider the federal government's response to be inadequate as a major reason for the ongoing outbreak, compared to only $21\%$ of Republicans [11].  This partisan gap is highlighted in the survey results, showing a stark contrast in opinions.

![82% of Democrats vs 21% of Republicans believe inadequate federal response is a major reason for continued outbreak](image7)

Conversely, Republicans are less likely to attribute the continuation of the outbreak to an inadequate federal response [2].  In fact, only $21\%$ of Republicans believe this is a reason, with nearly half, $45\%$, stating it is not a reason at all [2].  When evaluating the performance of the federal government, Republicans are more inclined to believe that the government has done a good job in responding to the coronavirus outbreak.

![Republicans are more likely to think state and local government are doing a good job on coronavirus](image8)

Despite these partisan differences, a consensus emerges among most Americans regarding the major reasons for the continued COVID-19 outbreak. Insufficient social distancing and mask-wearing are widely recognized as significant factors [4, 8].  A majority of Americans, across party lines, agree that a lack of adherence to social distancing guidelines is a major reason for the outbreak's continuation [8].  This is further supported by survey data indicating that not enough people social distancing and mask-wearing is considered a major reason by $75\%$ of Americans.

![75% of Americans think not enough people social distancing and mask-wearing is a major reason](image5)

In addition to social distancing, about half of Americans also point to an inadequate federal government response and a lack of timely testing as major reasons for the ongoing outbreak [6].  Specifically, $53\%$ cite inadequate federal response and $49\%$ point to not enough timely testing as major reasons [6].

In summary, Democrats are far more critical of the federal government's COVID-19 response than Republicans, while the general public largely agrees that insufficient social distancing and mask-wearing, along with inadequate federal response and testing, are major factors contributing to the continued coronavirus outbreak.

Democrats and Republicans diverge significantly in their beliefs regarding the causes for the ongoing COVID-19 outbreak. A substantial partisan gap exists in the perception of the federal government's role, with most Democrats viewing an inadequate federal response as a major reason for the continued outbreak, a view held by a much smaller percentage of Republicans [8, 1].  In contrast, Republicans are less likely to attribute the continuation to federal response issues.

![Democrats believe federal response is a major reason for continued outbreak, while Republicans do not.](image8)

This difference extends to the interpretation of rising case numbers. Democrats are more inclined to believe that increased case counts are due to increased infections [2], as visualized in the graph below which shows a significant majority of Democrats attributing the rise in cases to new infections rather than increased testing.

![Democrats attribute rise in cases to new infections, Republicans to increased testing.](image1)

Conversely, a majority of Republicans attribute the increase in confirmed cases primarily to increased testing rather than new infections [3].  The image further breaks down these views by ideology within each party, showing that conservative Republicans are even more likely to attribute the increase to testing compared to moderate and liberal Republicans.  This partisan divergence in explaining case increases highlights a fundamental difference in how each group perceives the outbreak's dynamics.

![Republicans are more likely to attribute case increases to more testing.](image3)

Furthermore, Democrats are significantly more critical of the pace of easing restrictions, with a large majority believing that some places eased restrictions too quickly, contributing to the outbreak's continuation.  This contrasts sharply with Republicans, among whom this view is far less prevalent [7].  In fact, as shown in the subsequent image,  Democrats overwhelmingly believe restrictions were lifted too quickly, while Republicans are more divided on this issue.

![Democrats overwhelmingly believe restrictions were lifted too quickly.](image6)

In summary, partisan beliefs strongly diverge on the reasons for the continuation of the COVID-19 outbreak, with Democrats emphasizing inadequate federal response and premature easing of restrictions, while Republicans are more inclined to attribute rising case numbers to increased testing and less critical of the federal response and pace of reopening.

The perspectives on the reasons for rising COVID-19 cases and the lifting of restrictions differ significantly across political affiliations.  A notable divide exists in the primary reason attributed to the increase in confirmed coronavirus cases.  Many Republicans believe that increased testing is the main driver for the rise in cases, with "roughly two-thirds of conservative Republicans say more testing is primary reason for rise in coronavirus cases" [1].  This view is further quantified as "a 62% majority of Republicans say that 'the increase in confirmed coronavirus cases is primarily a result of more people being tested than in previous months'" [8]. Conservative Republicans particularly hold this belief, as "about two-thirds of conservative Republicans attribute the growth in confirmed cases mostly to increased testing" [8].

In contrast, Democrats overwhelmingly attribute the increase in cases to more infections. "Democrats overwhelmingly attribute the rise in coronavirus cases primarily to more infections, not just more testing (-80% say this)" [10].  This stark difference in perspective is visually represented in the data, where Republicans lean towards increased testing as the cause, while Democrats strongly believe it's due to more infections. ![Republicans are more likely to attribute the rise in cases to increased testing, while Democrats believe it's due to more infections.](image5)

Furthermore, political affiliation influences opinions on the speed of easing restrictions.  A large partisan gap exists regarding whether restrictions have been lifted too quickly.  "82% of Democrats point to some places being too quick to ease restrictions as a major reason for the outbreak continuing, while just 31% of Republicans say this" [2].  In fact, a considerable portion of Republicans are more concerned about restrictions not being lifted quickly enough, with "somewhat more say their greater concern is that restrictions have not been lifted quickly enough (53%) rather than that they have been lifted too quickly (45%)" [3]. This partisan divergence in views on the pace of reopening is evident across the political spectrum. ![Democrats are more concerned that restrictions were lifted too quickly, while Republicans are more divided, with a slight majority concerned about restrictions not being lifted quickly enough.](image1)

In conclusion, political affiliation strongly correlates with differing perspectives on both the reasons for rising COVID-19 cases and the appropriateness of the pace at which restrictions were lifted.

Based on the provided quotes, there's a clear relationship between how different political groups view the causes of increased COVID-19 cases and their opinions on lifting restrictions. Democrats are significantly more inclined to believe that the rise in cases is due to increased infections, while Republicans are more likely to attribute it to increased testing. This difference in perception directly correlates with their views on the pace of lifting restrictions.

Democrats overwhelmingly believe rising coronavirus cases are primarily due to more infections [5, 8].  Liberal Democrats especially hold this view [5]. In contrast, a majority of Republicans attribute the increase to more testing [9].  Overall, most Americans lean towards believing in rising infections as the main cause, but there is a wide partisan divide [12].

![Democrats are more likely than Republicans to attribute the rise in coronavirus cases to new infections rather than increased testing.](image3)

This difference in perceived cause is mirrored in opinions about lifting restrictions.  A large majority of Democrats are more concerned that restrictions have been lifted too quickly [2, 7].  Liberal Democrats and conservative/moderate Democrats share this overwhelming concern [2].  Specifically, overwhelming shares of Democrats, around 82%, consider places being too quick to ease restrictions as a major reason for the continuation of the outbreak [4, 11].

![A large majority of Democrats are concerned that state restrictions have been lifted too quickly, while Republicans are more divided on this issue.](image2)

Republicans, however, are more divided.  While a slight majority express concern that restrictions haven't been lifted quickly enough, a significant percentage are still worried they've been lifted too fast [1].  Conservative Republicans are more likely to want restrictions lifted faster, while moderate and liberal Republicans are more concerned about them being lifted too quickly [1].  This contrasts sharply with Democrats, where concern about lifting too quickly is widespread across all subgroups.

![Democrats are much more likely than Republicans to view lifting restrictions too quickly as a major reason for the continuation of the outbreak.](image8)

The differing views on the cause of increased cases and the pace of lifting restrictions highlight a fundamental partisan divide in approaching the pandemic. Democrats, perceiving increased infections as the primary driver of case increases, are more cautious and worried about restrictions being lifted too quickly.  Republicans, with a significant portion believing increased testing is the main factor, are more divided on restriction lifting, with many desiring a faster pace.

In conclusion, Democrats, who believe rising cases are due to infections, are more concerned about restrictions being lifted too quickly, while Republicans, some of whom attribute rising cases to increased testing, are more divided on the pace of restriction lifting.

Based on the provided quotes, there are notable differences in voting policy preferences, particularly concerning the requirement for government-issued photo identification to vote, and these preferences are indeed influenced by both race and political affiliation.

Generally, a majority of Americans favor policies that ease voting, including the requirement for voters to present photo ID [2, 6].  However, when broken down by political party, a significant partisan divide emerges. Republicans are considerably more inclined to strongly favor photo ID requirements compared to Democrats [11].  In fact, Republicans overwhelmingly support this policy, with support remaining consistently high over time [12]. For example, a large majority of Republicans (93%) support voter photo ID [12].  ![Republicans strongly favor voter photo ID requirements](image1)

While majorities within both parties favor voter photo ID, the intensity of support differs greatly, with 81% of Republicans strongly favoring it compared to only 30% of Democrats [11].  However, within the Democratic party, racial and ethnic differences are evident.  White Democrats show less support for voter ID requirements (54%) compared to Black (65%), Hispanic (72%), and Asian Democrats (71%) [3]. This is further illustrated in the preference for early or absentee voting, where White Democrats are more supportive than Democrats of other races, while the opposite is true for White Republicans compared to Hispanic Republicans [1].  ![Democrats favor voter photo ID, with variations across racial groups](image4)

Interestingly, despite the general trend of minority groups favoring easing voting access, Black, Hispanic, and Asian Democrats express stronger support for voter ID requirements than White Democrats [3]. This nuance suggests that while these groups broadly favor accessible voting, they also see photo ID as a reasonable measure.
