The SnapNTell model's performance is significantly enhanced by incorporating entity detection (ED). Studies show that employing entity detection markedly surpasses models lacking this feature, highlighting its necessity for overall effectiveness [2].

![The table shows that the model with entity detection (w/ ED) outperforms the model without entity detection (w/o ED) across all metrics (ROUGE, BLEU, METEOR, and BELURT).](image7)

Furthermore, retrieval augmentation (RA) plays a crucial role in improving the model's accuracy and reducing hallucinations, especially for long-tail entities. Retrieval augmentation significantly enhances performance across various entity types, with a notable improvement for torso-to-tail entities, effectively mitigating hallucinations associated with long-tailed entities [6]. The architecture of the SnapNTell model explicitly includes retrieval augmentation to source relevant entity information, which is then fed into the LLM to generate knowledgeable answers [11].

![The diagram illustrates the SnapNTell model architecture, highlighting retrieval augmentation as a key component that enhances the LLM's knowledge and answer generation.](image1)

The comparative results demonstrate that a retrieval-augmented multimodal LLM outperforms existing baseline models across all assessed metrics, emphasizing the efficiency of retrieval augmentation in producing entity-centric and informative responses [8].

![The table illustrates that for Head, Torso, and Tail entities, the model with retrieval augmentation (w/ RA) shows higher accuracy and lower hallucination rates compared to the model without retrieval augmentation (w/o RA).](image8)

Inclusion of both entity detection and retrieval augmentation significantly improves the SnapNTell model's accuracy and reduces hallucination rates, particularly for long-tail entities.

The SnapNTell model exhibits superior performance compared to existing baseline models in Visual Question Answering (VQA) tasks [3, 7].  This is visually supported by performance comparisons where SnapNTell demonstrates a higher winning rate in pairwise comparisons against other models.  ![SnapNTell shows a higher win rate compared to other models in pairwise comparisons](image7).  Specifically, when evaluated on the SnapNTell dataset, baseline models show notably lower performance and larger performance disparities compared to traditional VQA datasets, indicating the effectiveness of the SnapNTell dataset in highlighting model capabilities, implying SnapNTell model's strength on this dataset [6]. ![Performance on SnapNTell dataset shows greater performance differences among models compared to other VQA datasets](image2).

The enhanced performance of the SnapNTell model is largely due to its key components: retrieval augmentation and entity detection [7, 2, 8]. The model architecture is designed to incorporate retrieval augmentation, which is crucial for sourcing relevant information about the entity in the image [10].  ![SnapNTell model architecture utilizes retrieval augmentation to enhance knowledge](image1).  This retrieval augmentation is particularly effective in addressing the challenge of hallucinations for long-tailed entities and significantly improves performance, especially for torso-to-tail entities [1]. ![Retrieval augmentation significantly improves accuracy and reduces hallucination, especially for tail entities](image8).

Furthermore, entity detection plays a vital role in the model's effectiveness. Ablation studies reveal that incorporating entity detection significantly boosts performance compared to a variant without this feature, highlighting its necessity for the model's overall success [2].  ![Performance is significantly better with Entity Detection (ED) across various metrics](image6). The SnapNTell model architecture explicitly includes both an Entity Detection Model and an Entity Recognition Model as part of its retrieval augmentation process [10].  ![SnapNTell model architecture includes Entity Detection Model and Entity Recognition Model within Retrieval Augmentation](image3).

In summary, the SnapNTell model outperforms other models in accuracy due to the incorporation of retrieval augmentation and entity detection mechanisms within its architecture.

To assess the impact of entity detection (ED) on the SnapNTell model, an ablation study was conducted, comparing performance with and without the ED component [8]. The results, as shown in the table, indicate a clear improvement when entity detection is incorporated.

![Table comparing model performance with and without Entity Detection](image1)

The table clearly demonstrates that the approach incorporating entity detection outperforms the variant lacking this feature across all metrics, including ROUGE, BLEU, METEOR, and BELURT.  This highlights the crucial role of entity detection in enhancing the model's effectiveness [8].

Inclusion of entity detection significantly improves the performance of SnapNTell across various evaluation metrics.

SnapNTell is evaluated using a range of established NLP metrics, including BLEU, METEOR, ROUGE, and BLEURT, alongside accuracy and hallucination rate metrics [4]. These metrics are essential for assessing the quality and correctness of the generated answers.  ![Table showing performance metrics including ROUGE, BLEU, METEOR, and BELURT for different methods, with SnapNTell showing the highest scores](image6).  As shown in Table 7, SnapNTell exhibits superior performance compared to other methods across ROUGE, BLEU, METEOR, and BELURT scores, achieving a notable $66.5\%$ improvement in BELURT score [2].  The significance of ROUGE and BLEURT is further emphasized by their strong alignment with human judgment, as indicated by Kendall correlation analysis [10, 11]. ![Table showing Kendall correlation coefficient for different evaluation metrics, with ROUGE and BELURT showing high correlation](image7).  This correlation suggests that these metrics are particularly effective in mirroring human assessment of model performance. The strong performance in these metrics underscores SnapNTell's efficiency in producing responses that are rich in entity-centric information [9].

In addition to automated metrics, human evaluation is conducted with a panel of judges to directly assess the quality of SnapNTell's responses [8]. While human evaluations suggest potential for further improvement, noting that SnapNTell's performance, although often near human-level, did not consistently surpass human annotations [3], it still demonstrates competitive results. Figure 2 illustrates a comparison of human evaluation outcomes, categorizing results into "Win," "Tie," and "Lose" for SnapNTell and other models.  ![Bar chart comparing human evaluation results of different methods including SnapNTell, showing SnapNTell has a higher win rate](image5).  The figure indicates that SnapNTell achieves a higher "Win" rate in human evaluations compared to other methods.

In conclusion, SnapNTell outperforms other methods in terms of automated evaluation metrics and achieves competitive, favorable results in human evaluations.

SPECTER demonstrates substantial improvements in document classification and citation prediction tasks when compared to other baseline models [6]. In document classification, SPECTER achieves superior performance compared to baselines, with an F1 score of 86.4 on the MeSH (MAG) dataset, outperforming the next best baseline by a significant margin [12].

![SPECTER outperforms other models in document classification and citation prediction tasks, achieving the highest scores in most categories.](image2)

For user activity prediction, SPECTER also excels, achieving a MAP score of 83.8 on co-view and 84.5 on co-read tasks, again surpassing baselines like Citeomatic [12]. Similarly, in citation prediction, SPECTER outperforms most baselines in both direct citation and co-citation tasks, achieving the best results in co-citation with an nDCG of 94.8 [12].  While SGC shows strong performance in citation tasks due to its access to the citation graph during training and testing, SPECTER remains advantageous as it can embed new, uncited papers, a capability SGC lacks [12].

![SPECTER embeddings show more compact and distinct topic clusters compared to SciBERT embeddings in a 2D projection.](image5)

Visually, SPECTER embeddings exhibit better topical encoding than SciBERT. As shown in the 2D projection, SPECTER's clusters appear more compact and distinct, indicating a clearer separation of topics [10].  For instance, clusters for "Engineering, Mathematics, and Computer Science" are grouped closely, as are "Business and Economics," demonstrating SPECTER's ability to capture cross-topic relatedness [10]. Quantitatively, DBScan clustering on these projections reveals that SPECTER achieves higher homogeneity (0.41 vs 0.19) and completeness (0.72 vs 0.63) values compared to SciBERT, confirming a clear improvement in topic separation [10].

In summary, SPECTER significantly outperforms various baseline models in document classification and citation prediction tasks, and its embeddings visually represent more coherent and well-separated topic clusters compared to SciBERT.

The SPECTER model demonstrates substantial performance improvements compared to other models across a range of document-level tasks.  Specifically, representation learning methods like BERT are limited in document-level representation power because they do not leverage inter-document relatedness, unlike SPECTER [5]. In contrast to models like SGC that rely on citation graphs during training and testing, SPECTER does not require citation information at inference time, making it more practical for embedding new, uncited papers [3, 8]. As shown in the evaluation results, SPECTER achieves an average performance of 80.0 across all metrics and tasks, a 3.1-point absolute improvement over the next best baseline [11].

![Table showing SPECTER outperforms baselines in classification, user activity prediction, citation prediction and recommendation tasks.](image1)

SPECTER outperforms various competitive baselines in document classification, user activity prediction, citation prediction, and recommendation tasks. For example, in document classification on the MeSH dataset, SPECTER achieves an F1 score of 86.4, a significant increase over the best baseline [8].  Moreover, when compared to fine-tuned SciBERT models, SPECTER consistently shows superior performance without requiring task-specific fine-tuning, highlighting its versatility and effectiveness [7, 12].

![Table showing SPECTER outperforms SciBERT fine-tuned on different signals across CLS, USR, CITE, REC and overall average.](image2)

Furthermore, visualized embeddings show that SPECTER excels at encoding topical information more effectively than SciBERT, with more compact clusters and better separation of topics [4].

![SPECTER embeddings show more compact topic clusters compared to SciBERT embeddings.](image3)

Regarding the effect of metadata, removing the abstract significantly decreases SPECTER’s performance, emphasizing the abstract's importance as textual input. Surprisingly, adding authors as input negatively impacts performance, possibly due to the sparsity of author names and suboptimal tokenization [2].  While adding venues slightly decreases overall performance, it improves performance in document classification, suggesting venues can be useful for topic-related tasks [2, 9].  The design of SPECTER is intentionally made to function without author or venue metadata, increasing its applicability in scenarios where such metadata is unavailable, like anonymized submissions or preprints [9].

![Table showing ablation study of SPECTER performance with removal of abstract, addition of venue and author.](image5)

In conclusion, SPECTER generally outperforms other models in document-level tasks, and while abstract is crucial, metadata like author names can negatively affect, and venues can have mixed effects on its performance.

SPECTER generally demonstrates superior performance compared to SciBERT across various tasks [4]. As evidenced in evaluations, SPECTER embeddings outperform SciBERT, even without task-specific fine-tuning [2]. ![SPECTER generally outperforms SciBERT across different tasks in the table.](image1) This is quantitatively supported by the data, showing SPECTER achieving higher scores in document classification, user activity prediction, citation prediction, and recommendation tasks [10, 9]. ![SPECTER outperforms fine-tuned SciBERT in various tasks shown in the table.](image2)  Furthermore, visualizations of their embedding spaces reveal that SPECTER excels at encoding topical information. SPECTER embeddings create more compact and well-separated clusters for different topics compared to SciBERT [3, 8]. ![SPECTER embeddings show more compact and separated topic clusters compared to SciBERT embeddings in the t-SNE projection.](image4) In conclusion, SPECTER outperforms SciBERT in various tasks and provides better topic encoding in its embeddings.

SPECTER, which does not require fine-tuning, is generally superior to fine-tuning SciBERT directly on task-specific signals [5].  Even without additional task-specific fine-tuning, SPECTER outperforms a SciBERT model fine-tuned on end tasks and their multitask combination, demonstrating SPECTER's effectiveness and versatility [8].

![SPECTER outperforms SciBERT fine-tuned on various signals on different tasks.](image3)

As shown in the table, SPECTER consistently achieves higher scores than SciBERT fine-tuned on co-view, co-read, co-citation and multitask settings across CLS, USR, CITE, REC and average metrics.

![SPECTER outperforms SciBERT and other baselines across various document-level tasks.](image2)

The table also illustrates that SPECTER (Ours) achieves the highest scores in classification, user activity prediction, citation prediction and recommendation tasks compared to SciBERT and other baselines.  In summary, SPECTER generally outperforms SciBERT even when SciBERT is fine-tuned for specific document classification tasks.

The enhancements to BERT-MRC models, specifically using Dice-based Sample-Consistent loss (DSC), Focal Loss (FL), and Dice Loss (DL), demonstrate varying degrees of F1-score improvements across different datasets.  DSC generally achieves the highest F1 score improvements compared to DL and FL across various datasets [1]. For English OntoNotes 5.0, the F1 score improvements for BERT-MRC are +0.11 with FL, +0.77 with DL, and +0.96 with DSC, respectively. ![BERT-MRC enhancements on English OntoNotes 5.0 dataset showing DSC with the highest F1 improvement](image1) On the MRPC dataset, BERT+DSC shows the highest F1 improvement of +0.92, compared to +0.43 with BERT+FL and +0.71 with BERT+DL. ![BERT enhancements on MRPC and QQP datasets with DSC yielding the best F1 scores](image2) For Chinese datasets like CTB5, CTB6, and UD1.4, DSC consistently outperforms BERT-tagger by a large margin, achieving improvements of +1.86, +1.80, and +2.19 in F1 score respectively [8].  Dice loss (DL) shows a significant gain on CTB5 but not on CTB6, and focal loss (FL) obtains only minor improvements on CTB5 and CTB6, indicating DSC's robustness across these datasets [8].

In Named Entity Recognition (NER) tasks, DSC also shows superior performance.  On English CoNLL 2003, DSC improves F1 by +0.29, outperforming FL (+0.06) and DL (+0.12). ![BERT-MRC enhancements on English CoNLL 2003 dataset with DSC showing the best F1 improvement](image4) Across NER datasets including CoNLL2003, OntoNotes5.0, MSRA, and OntoNotes4.0, DSC consistently outperforms BERT-MRC, setting new state-of-the-art performances [11]. Specifically, on Chinese OntoNotes 4.0, DSC provides a substantial F1 improvement of +2.36. ![BERT-MRC enhancements on Chinese MSRA and OntoNotes 4.0 datasets highlighting DSC's superior performance](image5)

For Machine Reading Comprehension (MRC) tasks, DSC consistently boosts performance with both BERT and XLNet models [12]. On SQuAD v1.1, DSC improves F1 score by +1.07, compared to +0.35 with FL and +0.96 with DL. On QuoRef, the F1 improvement with DSC is +2.57, significantly higher than FL (+1.24) and DL (+1.93). ![BERT enhancements on SQuAD v1.1, SQuAD v2.0 and QuoRef datasets demonstrating DSC's significant F1 boost](image6)

In summary, Dice-based Sample-Consistent loss (DSC) generally provides the most significant and consistent F1-score improvements for BERT-MRC models across various datasets compared to Focal Loss (FL) and Dice Loss (DL).

The performance of different BERT model variations on English CoNLL 2003 and English OntoNotes 5.0 datasets can be observed with and without DSC enhancement.  On the English CoNLL 2003 dataset, the application of DSC to BERT-MRC results in an improved F1 score. As shown in  ![BERT-MRC+DSC achieves an F1 score of 93.33 on the English CoNLL 2003 dataset, outperforming BERT-MRC, BERT-MRC+FL, and BERT-MRC+DL](image5), BERT-MRC+DSC achieves an F1 score of 93.33.

Similarly, for the English OntoNotes 5.0 dataset, BERT-MRC enhanced with DSC also demonstrates superior performance compared to other variations.  ![BERT-MRC+DSC achieves an F1 score of 92.07 on the English OntoNotes 5.0 dataset, outperforming BERT-MRC, BERT-MRC+FL, and BERT-MRC+DL](image3), BERT-MRC+DSC achieves an F1 score of 92.07 on this dataset. Textual evidence confirms these improvements, stating that "DSC outperforms BERT-MRC... respectively on CoNLL2003, OntoNotes5.0" [12], and sets new state-of-the-art performance on both datasets [12].

In summary, BERT models enhanced with DSC consistently outperform standard BERT and other variations like BERT+FL and BERT+DL on both English CoNLL 2003 and English OntoNotes 5.0 datasets, achieving state-of-the-art results in NER tasks.

The enhancements to BERT-MRC and XLNet models, particularly the use of Dice loss (DSC), have a notable impact on their performance in Named Entity Recognition (NER) tasks across different datasets.  For English CoNLL 2003 dataset, the BERT-MRC model sees incremental improvements with different loss functions.  The F1 score increases from 93.04 with standard BERT-MRC, to 93.11 with Focal Loss (FL), 93.17 with Dice Loss (DL), and reaching 93.33 with DSC loss. ![BERT-MRC with DSC achieves the highest F1 score of 93.33 on English CoNLL 2003 dataset.](image3) Similarly, on the Chinese MSRA dataset, BERT-MRC with DSC achieves the highest F1 score of 96.72, outperforming variants with FL and DL, and the original BERT-MRC model which has an F1 score of 95.75. ![BERT-MRC with DSC achieves the highest F1 score of 96.72 on Chinese MSRA dataset.](image1) Textual evidence corroborates these findings, stating that DSC loss provides a significant performance boost for BERT and XLNet in MRC tasks and outperforms BERT-MRC on NER datasets including CoNLL2003 and MSRA [4, 5].  These results demonstrate that enhancements like DSC loss consistently improve the performance of BERT-MRC and, by extension, XLNet models on NER tasks for both English and Chinese datasets.

In conclusion, enhancements to BERT-MRC and XLNet, specifically using DSC loss, lead to improved performance on both English CoNLL 2003 and Chinese MSRA datasets for NER tasks.

The enhancements FL, DL, and DSC generally improve the performance of BERT and XLNet across various NLP tasks, but their effectiveness varies depending on the task and the specific enhancement used.

For Named Entity Recognition (NER) tasks, DSC consistently outperforms DL and FL, leading to new state-of-the-art performances. As shown in the experimental results on NER datasets, DSC surpasses BERT-MRC by a significant margin [2].  Specifically, on the English CoNLL 2003 dataset, BERT-MRC+DSC achieves the highest F1 score compared to BERT-MRC with FL and DL enhancements, as well as other models like ELMo and CVT. ![BERT-MRC+DSC achieves the highest F1 score on English CoNLL 2003 dataset compared to other models and enhancements.](image1) Similarly, on Chinese NER datasets like MSRA and OntoNotes 4.0, BERT-MRC+DSC also demonstrates superior performance over BERT-MRC and its FL and DL variants. ![BERT-MRC+DSC achieves the highest F1 score on Chinese MSRA and OntoNotes 4.0 datasets compared to other models and enhancements.](image2)  This trend continues on the English OntoNotes 5.0 dataset, where BERT-MRC+DSC again achieves the highest F1 score. ![BERT-MRC+DSC achieves the highest F1 score on English OntoNotes 5.0 dataset compared to other models and enhancements.](image4)

In Machine Reading Comprehension (MRC) tasks, DSC also provides significant performance boosts for both BERT and XLNet models.  On datasets like SQuAD v1.1, SQuAD v2.0, and QuoRef, both BERT and XLNet enhanced with DSC loss outperform their counterparts with FL and DL, achieving higher EM and F1 scores. ![BERT and XLNet with DSC enhancement achieve the highest EM and F1 scores on MRC datasets like SQuAD v1.1, SQuAD v2.0, and QuoRef.](image6)

For paraphrase identification tasks, such as MRPC and QQP, DSC also leads to improvements for both BERT and XLNet, achieving the highest F1 scores compared to FL and DL enhancements. ![BERT and XLNet with DSC enhancement achieve the highest F1 scores on paraphrase identification datasets MRPC and QQP.](image5)

However, for accuracy-oriented tasks like sentiment classification on SST datasets, DL and DSC do not show improvement over the standard Cross-Entropy (CE) loss. In fact, BERT with CE achieves slightly better accuracy than BERT with DL or DSC on SST-2 and SST-5 datasets [5].  This suggests that dice loss, and by extension DSC, is not optimized for accuracy-oriented tasks. ![BERT with CE loss achieves better accuracy than BERT with DL or DSC on sentiment classification tasks.](image3)

In summary, DSC generally provides the most consistent and significant performance enhancements for BERT and XLNet across data-imbalanced NLP tasks like NER, MRC, and paraphrase identification, consistently achieving the highest F1 scores, while for accuracy-oriented tasks like sentiment classification, standard Cross-Entropy loss may be more suitable. The DSC enhancement generally improves performance across data-imbalanced NLP tasks, especially in terms of F1 score, while its effectiveness is less pronounced in accuracy-oriented tasks like sentiment classification.

The performance of BERT and XLNet models and their variants, particularly when enhanced with Dice-based loss (DSC), demonstrates notable improvements in F1 scores across various datasets, although the effectiveness varies depending on the task. For Named Entity Recognition (NER) datasets, DSC consistently outperforms BERT-MRC, setting new state-of-the-art (SOTA) performances. As shown in the results, DSC achieves improvements of  $+0.29$, $+0.96$, $+0.97$, and $+2.36$ on CoNLL2003, OntoNotes5.0, MSRA, and OntoNotes4.0 datasets respectively compared to BERT-MRC [1]. This is visually represented in performance tables across different NER datasets, where BERT-MRC+DSC consistently shows higher F1 scores compared to other methods. For example, on English CoNLL 2003, BERT-MRC+DSC achieves an F1 score of 93.33, outperforming BERT-MRC(Li et al., 2019) which has 93.04. ![BERT-MRC-DSC performance on CoNLL 2003 dataset, showing improved F1 score](image2) Similarly, on Chinese MSRA dataset, BERT-MRC+DSC achieves a high F1 score of 96.72. ![BERT-MRC-DSC performance on Chinese MSRA dataset, showing improved F1 score](image3)  English OntoNotes 5.0 also shows improvement with BERT-MRC+DSC, reaching an F1 score of 92.07. ![BERT-MRC-DSC performance on English OntoNotes 5.0 dataset, showing improved F1 score](image4).

In Machine Reading Comprehension (MRC) tasks, the introduction of DSC loss also brings significant performance boosts for both BERT and XLNet models. For SQuADv1.1, DSC outperforms XLNet by $+1.25$ in F1 score, and for SQuAD v2.0, it achieves an F1 score of 89.51 [2].  On QuoRef dataset, DSC surpasses XLNet by $+1.41$ in F1 score [2]. These results are evident in the table comparing different models on MRC tasks, where BERT+DSC and XLNet+DSC achieve higher F1 scores on SQuAD and QuoRef datasets. ![BERT+DSC and XLNet+DSC performance on SQuAD and QuoRef datasets, showing improved F1 scores](image8).

For paraphrase identification (PI) tasks, DSC also enhances the performance of BERT and XLNet.  Experiments on MRPC and QQP datasets show that BERT+DSC and XLNet+DSC achieve higher F1 scores compared to the baselines. ![BERT and XLNet performance with DSC on MRPC and QQP datasets, showing improved F1 scores](image1).  Furthermore, DSC's effectiveness is particularly pronounced in scenarios with imbalanced datasets.  When tested on the QQP dataset with varying positive-negative ratios, DSC consistently performs the best across all datasets, especially showing significant outperformance on more imbalanced datasets [9]. This is highlighted when comparing the performance of DSC against Dice Loss (DL) and Focal Loss (FL) under different data imbalance conditions. ![BERT performance with DSC, DL and FL on QQP dataset with different imbalance ratios](image5).

However, it's important to note that the benefits of DSC loss are not universally applicable across all task types. For accuracy-oriented tasks like text classification, specifically on the Stanford Sentiment Treebank (SST) datasets, DSC does not provide improvement and even performs slightly worse than the Cross-Entropy (CE) objective [12]. On SST-5, BERT with CE achieves 55.57 accuracy, while BERT with DSC reaches 55.19 accuracy. ![BERT performance with CE, DL, and DSC on SST datasets, showing DSC is not better for accuracy-oriented tasks](image7). This indicates that DSC loss is more aligned with optimizing F1 score directly, making it suitable for tasks where F1 score is the primary evaluation metric, such as NER, MRC and PI, but not for tasks where accuracy is paramount.

In conclusion, DSC loss significantly improves the F1 scores of BERT and XLNet models on tasks like NER, MRC, and paraphrase identification, often achieving state-of-the-art results and demonstrating robustness, especially on imbalanced datasets. However, for accuracy-focused tasks like sentiment classification, DSC is not beneficial, suggesting its objective alignment with F1 score optimization rather than accuracy. The Dice-based loss effectively narrows the gap between training objective and the F1 score evaluation metric, making BERT and XLNet variants with DSC a potent combination for relevant NLP tasks.

The data augmentation techniques, such as '+positive' and '+negative', significantly alter the balance of datasets, which in turn affects the performance of BERT models.  For instance, using '+positive' augmentation aims to create a more balanced dataset, leading to better performance compared to the 'original' dataset, while '+negative' augmentation results in an imbalanced dataset and underperforms the 'original' model [1]. The '-negative' augmentation, despite creating a balanced dataset, leads to performance decrease due to the reduction in training data size [1]. The '+negative' data augmentation technique involves selecting negative training examples as templates, resulting in a training set with a significant negative class imbalance (79% negative vs. 21% positive in one instance) [5].

The impact of these augmentation techniques and the choice of loss function can be observed in the performance metrics across different tasks.  For sentiment classification on SST-2 and SST-5 datasets, BERT fine-tuned with cross-entropy (CE) achieves higher accuracy compared to Dice Loss (DL) and DSC, indicating that dice loss is not optimized for accuracy-oriented tasks [2].  Table 9 shows the accuracy of BERT with CE, DL and DSC on SST-2 and SST-5 datasets. ![Table showing that BERT with CE achieves better accuracy than DL and DSC on SST datasets.](image6)

However, when considering tasks sensitive to data imbalance, such as Named Entity Recognition (NER), DSC loss demonstrates superior performance.  Table 3 shows that on Chinese datasets (CTB5, CTB6, UD1.4), DSC loss significantly outperforms baseline BERT models and other losses like Focal Loss (FL) and DL in terms of F1 score [11].  Specifically, DSC improves F1 score by +1.86 on CTB5, +1.80 on CTB6, and +2.19 on UD1.4 compared to BERT-tagger.

```markdown
![Table showing that DSC loss outperforms other losses on Chinese datasets for NER tasks.](image1)
```

Similarly, on English NER datasets, DSC consistently achieves top performance.  For English OntoNotes 5.0, BERT-MRC with DSC reaches an F1 score of 92.07, outperforming BERT-MRC with DL and FL [Image7]. For English CoNLL 2003, BERT-MRC with DSC achieves the highest F1 score of 93.33 [Image8].

```markdown
![Table showing that BERT-MRC with DSC achieves the highest F1 score on English OntoNotes 5.0 dataset.](image7)
```

```markdown
![Table showing that BERT-MRC with DSC achieves the highest F1 score on English CoNLL 2003 dataset.](image8)
```

For paraphrase identification tasks like QQP, DSC also shows performance gains.  Table 9 shows that BERT+DSC achieves an F1 score of 92.11 on QQP, which is higher than BERT+FL (91.86) and BERT+DL (91.92) [Image3]. This indicates that DSC is effective in handling data imbalance in paraphrase identification as well.

```markdown
![Table showing the F1 scores of BERT with different loss functions on MRPC and QQP datasets.](image3)
```

The Dice Similarity Coefficient (DSC) loss is particularly effective in situations with data imbalance because it is a soft version of the F1 score and helps to mitigate the dominating influence of easy-negative examples, which is a common problem in imbalanced datasets [8].  While Dice loss (DL) may offer some improvements, DSC consistently performs best across various datasets and augmentation scenarios, especially on more imbalanced datasets [9].

In summary, different data augmentation techniques impact BERT model performance by altering dataset balance.  DSC loss consistently improves performance, especially on imbalanced datasets and across NER and paraphrase identification tasks, as measured by F1 score, while for accuracy-oriented sentiment classification tasks, cross-entropy loss may be more suitable.

The performance of BERT models is significantly influenced by both data augmentation techniques and the choice of loss function across different datasets.  Augmenting the original training data with positive examples to create a balanced dataset (`$^+$ positive`) generally improves performance compared to the original dataset, as shown in the results obtained using the MLE objective [4]. Conversely, augmenting with negative examples (`+negative`) can lead to inferior performance because it creates a more imbalanced dataset [4].  However, down-sampling negative examples to balance the dataset is also employed as an augmentation strategy [1].

![BERT performance with different augmentation techniques on QQP dataset, showing positive augmentation improves performance, and DSC consistently performs well.](image2)

Different loss functions also impact BERT's performance.  The Dice-based loss (DSC) is proposed to bridge the gap between the training objective and the evaluation metric, particularly the F1 score [3]. Experimental results demonstrate that DSC loss provides a significant performance boost with both BERT and XLNet models on MRC tasks [2]. For instance, on SQuADv1.1, DSC outperforms XLNet by +1.25 in F1 score, and on QuoRef, it surpasses XLNet by +1.46 in EM [2].  Across various datasets like MRPC and QQP, BERT+DSC consistently achieves higher F1 scores compared to BERT with Focal Loss (FL) or Dice Loss (DL) alone, as shown in the table.

![BERT performance with FL, DL, and DSC loss on MRPC and QQP datasets, highlighting DSC's superior performance.](image1)

Furthermore, DSC loss consistently performs best across different datasets, especially showing significant improvement over DL for the `+negative` dataset, which is more imbalanced [5]. This suggests that DSC is particularly effective in scenarios with imbalanced data [5]. While FL and DL's performance can fluctuate across datasets, DSC maintains consistent and superior results [5].  However, it is important to note that DSC loss is not accuracy-oriented and may not be suitable for tasks where accuracy is the primary metric.  Experiments on sentiment classification tasks (SST-2 and SST-5) reveal that BERT with Cross-Entropy (CE) achieves better accuracy than BERT with DL or DSC [10].

![BERT performance with CE, DL, and DSC loss on SST-2 and SST-5 datasets, showing CE is better for accuracy-oriented tasks.](image8)

In summary, BERT model performance varies based on augmentation strategies and loss function choices; positive augmentation and DSC loss tend to enhance performance on tasks like MRC, while for accuracy-focused tasks like sentiment classification, cross-entropy loss may be more effective.

COMET-RANK, a novel neural framework, demonstrates superior performance compared to traditional metrics like BLEU in evaluating machine translation quality across various language pairs. BLEU, a classic metric, relies on n-gram matching and often fails to capture semantic similarity beyond the lexical level [7]. In contrast, COMET metrics are designed to optimize correlation with human judgments and have shown promising results [1]. BLEU and CHRF are considered baseline metrics, while COMET models consistently outperform them, often by significant margins, across different language pairs where English is the source language, as shown in Table 1 [4].

![Table 1 shows COMET models outperforming BLEU and CHRF across eight language pairs with English as source.](image1)

Figure 3 illustrates that across language pairs with English as a target language, COMET models perform better or are competitive with other metrics like BLEURT and BERTSCORE, while exceeding the performance of metrics when English is the source [8].

![Figure 3 shows COMET models performing better than BLEU and other metrics in language pairs with English as target and source.](image5)

Table 2 further confirms the strong correlations of COMET-RANK with human judgments, outperforming even the English-specific BLEURT metric in most language pairs with English as the target language [11].

![Table 2 shows COMET-RANK outperforming BLEU, CHRF, YISI-1, BERTSCORE and BLEURT in seven to-English language pairs.](image6)

While BLEU remains popular for its lightweight and fast computation, COMET metrics, particularly COMET-RANK, offer a more robust and accurate evaluation of MT quality by better aligning with human judgments, as evidenced by their consistently higher performance across diverse language pairs. COMET-RANK exhibits superior translation evaluation performance compared to BLEU across different language pairs.

The DS-Picklist model generally achieves higher joint accuracy compared to the DS-DST model, especially when a full ontology is accessible [6].  DS-Picklist leverages a full ontology and treats all domain-slot pairs as categorical slots, predicting values directly from candidate lists [5]. In contrast, DS-DST uses a dual strategy to handle both non-categorical and categorical slots [4].

The joint accuracy of DS-DST and DS-Picklist compared to other models are shown in the table. DS-Picklist achieves the highest joint accuracy of 53.30%, while DS-DST achieves 51.21%, both outperforming BERT-DST and ToD-BERT.

```markdown
![Table showing Joint Accuracy of different models including DS-DST and DS-Picklist](image6)
```

However, the advantage of DS-Picklist is more pronounced in slot accuracy for specific slot types.  As shown in the slot-level accuracy table, DS-Picklist and DS-DST show significant improvements over DS-Span for slots like `hotel-type`, `attraction-type`, `attraction-name`, `hotel-internet`, and `hotel-parking` [3]. This is because these slot values are often not directly extractable from the dialog context, making span-based methods like DS-Span less effective [7]. DS-DST and DS-Picklist, by treating these slots as categorical and predicting from candidate lists, achieve better accuracy [3].

```markdown
![Table comparing slot-level accuracy of DS-Span, DS-DST and DS-Picklist for various slots](image2)
```

The error analysis reveals that DS-DST and DS-Picklist dramatically reduce errors for slots like `attraction-type`, `hotel-internet`, and `hotel-parking`, indicating the effectiveness of treating them as categorical slots [7]. Although DS-Picklist often outperforms DS-DST, accessing a full ontology in real-world scenarios might be challenging [6].

In summary, DS-Picklist generally provides better joint and slot accuracy by utilizing a full ontology and treating all slots as categorical, but DS-DST offers a robust alternative without requiring a full ontology while still significantly improving upon span-based methods, particularly for categorical slots. DS-Picklist achieves a higher overall accuracy due to its access to a full ontology, but DS-DST provides a balance between leveraging categorical and non-categorical slot handling.

The DS-DST and DS-Picklist models show different performance levels on the MultiWOZ 2.1 dataset, particularly when considering slot-level accuracy.  Overall, DS-Picklist tends to outperform DS-DST, especially when a full ontology is accessible. [6]

Looking at the joint accuracy on the MultiWOZ 2.1 test set, DS-Picklist achieves a higher score of 53.30% compared to DS-DST's 51.21%. ![DS-Picklist outperforms DS-DST in terms of joint accuracy on MultiWOZ 2.1 dataset.](image1) This indicates that leveraging a full ontology in DS-Picklist provides an advantage in overall performance. [6]

Examining slot-level accuracy reveals specific slots where DS-DST and DS-Picklist show significant improvements over DS-Span, as highlighted in Table 4. Slots like 'hotel-internet' and 'hotel-parking' demonstrate substantial gains with DS-DST and further improvement with DS-Picklist. ![DS-DST and DS-Picklist show significant accuracy improvements over DS-Span for slots like hotel-internet and hotel-parking.](image2)  This is because these slots often have values that are not directly extractable from the dialog context, making categorical approaches in DS-DST and DS-Picklist more effective. [7]  However, time-related slots such as 'taxi-leave at' and 'train-arrive by' remain challenging for both DS-DST and DS-Span, although DS-Picklist can reduce errors when ontology is available. [2]

In conclusion, DS-Picklist generally performs better than DS-DST on the MultiWOZ 2.1 dataset, achieving a higher overall joint accuracy and showing improvements across various slots, especially those with categorical values, while both DS-DST and DS-Picklist significantly outperform DS-Span for specific slot types.

The DS-Picklist model generally outperforms both DS-DST and DS-Span, particularly when considering joint accuracy.  Looking at the joint accuracy on the MultiWOZ 2.1 test set, DS-Picklist achieves a higher score compared to DS-DST and DS-Span [8].

```markdown
![Table showing joint accuracy comparison of BERT-DST, DS-DST, BERT-DST-Picklist, ToD-BERT and DS-Picklist models.](image7)
```

This improvement in DS-Picklist is further supported by the observation that jointly using both categorical and non-categorical approaches is beneficial in multi-domain DST, and when the model accesses the full ontology, DS-Picklist shows further performance improvement [1].  However, it's noted that in real-world scenarios, having access to the full ontology might be challenging [1].  Despite this, DS-Picklist consistently performs better than BERT-DST and BERT-DST-Picklist, and even surpasses strong models like ToD-BERT, highlighting the importance of strong interactions between slots and dialog context in the proposed models [9].

When examining slot-level accuracy, DS-DST and DS-Picklist show significant improvements over DS-Span for certain slot types. Slots like 'hotel-type', 'attraction-type', 'attraction-name', 'hotel-internet', and 'hotel-parking' see considerable gains [12].

```markdown
![Table showing slot-level accuracy on MultiWOZ 2.1 test set for DS-Span, DS-DST and DS-Picklist.](image6)
```

These are often categorical slots where values have varied expressions and are not easily extracted from the dialog context using span-based methods like DS-Span [12]. In contrast, DS-DST and DS-Picklist can predict these values directly from candidate value lists, leading to better performance [12].  Error analysis also reveals that DS-DST and DS-Picklist dramatically reduce errors for slots like 'attraction-type', 'hotel-internet', and 'hotel-parking' compared to DS-Span, which struggles to extract ground-truth strings for these slots [3].

```markdown
![Table showing top-10 slots with highest ratio of ground-truth slot values not found through span matching for DS-Span, and comparison with DS-DST and DS-Picklist.](image2)
```

However, for time-related slots like 'taxi-leave at' and 'train-arrive by', which are span-based, both DS-Span and DS-DST do not perform well due to the lack of span matching in the dialogue context. DS-Picklist, with ontology access, can further reduce error rates for these slots by predicting values from candidate lists [3].

In summary, DS-Picklist achieves the highest joint accuracy and demonstrates improved slot accuracy, particularly for categorical slots, compared to DS-DST and DS-Span, leveraging ontology information for enhanced performance.

The performance of the DeClarE model varies across different datasets and configurations. On the Snopes and PolitiFact datasets, which focus on credibility classification, DeClarE (Full) generally outperforms baseline models.  For instance, on the PolitiFact dataset, DeClarE shows a  $7.9\%$  AUC improvement over baselines [8]. You can see these results in the table below.

![Table showing the performance of different models on Snopes and PolitiFact datasets for credibility classification, measured by True Claims Accuracy, False Claims Accuracy, Macro F1-Score, and AUC.](image1)

Specifically, on the Snopes dataset, DeClarE (Full) achieves high accuracy in classifying both true and false claims, with a Macro F1-Score of 0.79 and an AUC of 0.86 [11]. However, its performance is slightly lower than the Distant Supervision configuration on Snopes, although DeClarE has the advantage of not relying on handcrafted features [11].

In contrast, when considering credibility regression on the NewsTrust dataset, DeClarE (Full) again demonstrates superior performance. It achieves the lowest Mean Squared Error (MSE) of 0.29, outperforming all baseline models, including LSTM-text and Distant Supervision, with a $17\%$ decrease in MSE compared to the best baselines [2]. The MSE comparison is shown in this table.

![Table showing the comparison of MSE values for different models on the NewsTrust dataset for credibility regression.](image6)

On the SemEval dataset, which involves tweet credibility classification and confidence score prediction, DeClarE (Full) also outperforms other approaches like NileTMRG and IITP, achieving a Macro Accuracy of 0.57 and an RMSE of 0.604 [12]. This is detailed in the following table.

![Table showing the performance of different models on the SemEval dataset for credibility classification and confidence score prediction, measured by Macro Accuracy and RMSE.](image2)

Overall, DeClarE (Full) consistently performs strongly across all datasets, whether for credibility classification (Snopes, PolitiFact, SemEval) or regression (NewsTrust), generally outperforming baseline models and demonstrating its effectiveness in harnessing external evidence [3]. The performance metrics and tasks differ across datasets, with classification accuracy and AUC used for Snopes, PolitiFact and SemEval, and MSE for NewsTrust [4, 6].  DeClarE's full configuration, including attention and source embeddings, consistently enhances performance compared to the plain version [2, 8].

In summary, DeClarE (Full) exhibits robust performance across Snopes, PolitiFact, NewsTrust, and SemEval datasets, consistently outperforming baselines in both credibility classification and regression tasks, although the specific metrics and tasks vary between these datasets.
