The NMRC Dining Out is a significant event rooted in Naval tradition, designed to celebrate camaraderie and honor the history and future of Navy Medicine research and development. The event follows a strict Naval protocol, tracing back to Viking and British Navy customs, while uniquely highlighting Naval Medical research history [1]. This tradition is underscored by the formal setting at the U.S. Naval Academy, where NMRC hosts this annual Mess Night [2, 12, 5].

![Attendees in formal attire at the NMRC Dining Out event.](image2)

Key elements of the Dining Out include established traditions such as an invocation, the parade of beef for presidential approval, and formal toasts [1, 9, 11].  The evening is structured around Naval protocol, with specific toasts dedicated to the Commander-in-Chief, the U.S. Navy, Marine Corps, and sister services [9]. A particularly poignant element is the remembrance of fallen comrades, symbolized by the Prisoner of War/Missing in Action table, serving as a "heartfelt tribute to all fallen or lost comrades" [6].

![Dining Out event setting with naval flags and participants at tables.](image4)

Furthermore, the Dining Out is not just about tradition; it actively engages with the present and future of Navy Medicine.  Senior leaders like Rear Adm. Bruce A. Doll, head of Bureau of Medicine and Surgery research and development, are present, with the President of the Mess introducing Doll to speak about the history of Navy Medicine research and development [11, 10]. Junior officers are encouraged to participate by presenting "poems and odes" about the research accomplishments of their Naval predecessors, fostering an appreciation for history and inspiring future leadership in the field [1, 10]. This event serves as a platform to recognize the contributions and sacrifices within Navy Medicine research and development, reinforcing its mission and supporting those dedicated to preserving freedoms [8].

The NMRC Dining Out event is a formal, tradition-rich occasion that celebrates Naval heritage while emphasizing the critical importance of Navy Medicine research and development, fostering a sense of community and inspiring future generations in this vital field.

NAMRU-3 and NSMRL make significant contributions to medical and scientific research through various initiatives, directly supporting U.S. military operations by enhancing medical capabilities and focusing on the health and performance of naval personnel.  U.S. Naval Medical Research Unit No. 3 (NAMRU-3) is actively involved in building medical research capacity in countries recovering from conflict, such as Liberia, which faced a brutal civil war that damaged its infrastructure [1]. This effort extends to Afghanistan, where NAMRU-3 partners with the Defense Threat Reduction Agency (DTRA) to strengthen Ministry of Health laboratories [3]. This collaboration aims to improve the efficiency of U.S. biodefense and disease surveillance efforts in the region [3].  ![People in lab coats working in a lab](image7). NAMRU-3 also provides essential training, conducting workshops for laboratory and administrative staff on proper procedures, quality control, and biosafety, ensuring reliable laboratory operations [5]. In Afghanistan, NAMRU-3 trained 160 scientists and technicians in laboratory operations, diagnostic procedures, and research ethics [9], developing comprehensive training plans based on identified needs [10].

The Naval Submarine Medical Research Laboratory (NSMRL) focuses on operational medicine for the submarine force, addressing human factors related to submariner health and performance [6]. This includes medical, psychological, and human performance research, as well as developing innovative concepts for the submarine force using human technology [6]. NSMRL's work is directly aligned with the Commander, Submarine Forces (CSF), making it CSF's primary human technology laboratory [6].  ![Naval officer in uniform](image2). NSMRL's research extends to diving medicine and unique capabilities, such as a hyperbaric chamber that can simulate conditions from depth to high altitude, relevant to special operations forces [6].

Both NAMRU-3 and NSMRL conduct research and capacity building that directly aligns with U.S. military operations by improving global health security and ensuring the readiness and effectiveness of naval forces.

The NMRC significantly contributes to international medical initiatives through humanitarian missions and capacity building programs. For instance, the USNS Mercy, associated with NMRC, conducts annual Pacific Partnership missions that began in 2004 as a response to the Southeast Asia tsunami [4]. These missions extend medical care to host nations like Indonesia, the Philippines, Vietnam, and Cambodia, where over 49,000 patients received treatment, including surgeries and screenings [1].  ![Cmdr. Charmagne Beckett, a NMRC physician researcher, volunteered to deploy on the hospital ship USNS Mercy](image3). These efforts involve various medical and non-medical projects, such as subject-matter expert exchanges on public health topics and community service donations [1]. ![Group of medical personnel, including Cmdr. Charmagne Beckett, likely part of a USNS Mercy mission team](image6).

Furthermore, NAMRU-3 has been instrumental in building medical capacity internationally, particularly in Afghanistan since 2006 [8].  They have partnered with organizations like DTRA to enhance disease surveillance and biodefense efforts [2]. NAMRU-3 established laboratories, including virology and bacteriology labs, and provided training to Afghan scientists and technicians on laboratory operations and diagnostic procedures [3, 5].  ![People working in a lab setting, possibly Afghan scientists trained by NAMRU-3](image8). This includes developing comprehensive training plans and modules covering various laboratory disciplines [6].

On the local front, the NMRC's Bone Marrow Research Directorate advances medical capabilities through research and support for military contingencies [10].  The C.W. Bill Young DoD Marrow Donor Program, under NMRC, facilitates bone marrow donation and transplantation, essential for treating marrow toxic injuries [12, 10].  Donor drives, like those at Marine Corps Base Hawaii, collect oral swabs for genetic testing to match donors with patients [12]. ![A Marine taking an oral swab, likely for the DoD Marrow Donor Program](image1).

In conclusion, the NMRC advances global health through international humanitarian missions and capacity building, while also fostering local medical advancements through specialized research and programs like bone marrow donation.

U.S. Naval Medical Research Units (NAMRUs) actively support both military personnel and local communities through a range of activities, including disease surveillance, research, and capacity building initiatives. For military personnel, NAMRUs focus on assessing and mitigating health risks, such as rickettsial diseases, to maintain force readiness [2, 12]. This involves training individuals in regions endemic to these diseases to better understand and manage the threats [2].  ![Rickettsial Diseases Research Program trains individuals to assess health risks](image2)

Moreover, NAMRUs develop tools like the Patient Condition Occurrence Frequency (PCOF) tool, which helps in military medical planning by predicting disease and injury probabilities in various operational scenarios [8, 11]. This tool is crucial for planning healthcare simulations and ensuring appropriate medical resources are available during military operations, including humanitarian assistance and disaster relief efforts [11].

For local communities, NAMRUs engage in collaborative projects that enhance public health infrastructure and capabilities.  In Liberia, for example, NAMRU-3 has been working with the Liberian Institute of Biomedical Research (LIBR) to strengthen disease vector surveillance and detection, particularly for vector-borne viral pathogens like malaria [3, 5]. This collaboration not only aids the Liberian Armed Forces but also benefits the entire Liberian population by expanding disease surveillance and control capabilities [3].  ![Group photo of scientists, potentially from NAMRU and LIBR, collaborating on research and capacity building in Liberia](image4)  The training and resources provided by NAMRU-3 have been recognized for significantly improving Liberia's ability to protect its soldiers and families from diseases [9].

These activities are often conducted in collaboration with various international and local partners, showcasing a commitment to global health security.  For instance, scientists from Kazakhstan received training at the Naval Medical Research Center (NMRC) on molecular assays, fostering international scientific collaboration [6].  ![Military personnel participating in disease surveillance possibly involving sample collection](image3)  Furthermore, the U.S. Naval Medical Research Unit No. 2 (NAMRU-2) PACIFIC, highlights the regional presence of NAMRUs, indicating their broad reach in addressing health challenges across different geographic areas [image1]. ![Logo of U.S. Naval Medical Research Unit-2 PACIFIC, indicating regional focus](image1)

NAMRUs activities benefit both military personnel and local communities by focusing on disease prevention, health capacity building, and collaborative research efforts.

The Patient Condition Occurrence Frequency (PCOF) tool plays a vital role in military operations by significantly improving medical mission planning [3]. Moving away from rule-of-thumb estimates, PCOF offers a repeatable, organized, and robust method for generating patient condition estimates [3, 5]. This tool is effective and accurate, utilizing standardized and documented methods to adjust baseline distributions for generating these estimates [5].

The PCOF tool's function is to produce tables that detail the probability of different types of diseases and injuries typically encountered in a contingency within a population at risk [6]. These tables cover casualty categories such as wounded in action, non-battle injuries, disease, and outpatient visits across the spectrum of military operations, including combat and humanitarian missions [6]. It uses data from past operations, like Operation Enduring Freedom and humanitarian assistance missions, to populate these tables [12]. By using mission-centric PCOF data, planners can tailor it to fit anticipated missions more precisely, informing decision-makers about potential patient conditions during a contingency [7].  The PCOF tool is designed to be the approved Joint patient occurrence generating application [9].

![Soldiers in military uniform sitting inside a transport aircraft, possibly heading to a military operation](image2)

In summary, the PCOF tool is crucial for military operations as it provides an accurate, data-driven method to estimate patient conditions, thereby enhancing medical mission planning and preparedness for various scenarios.

The USNS Mercy Pacific Partnership 2012 and the DoD Bone Marrow Program serve distinct but equally critical humanitarian objectives. The USNS Mercy Pacific Partnership 2012 was a mission focused on delivering medical care and humanitarian aid across multiple nations. Setting sail from San Diego in May 2012, the USNS Mercy, staffed by a diverse crew including medical professionals and NGO personnel, aimed to provide care to host nations and foster international collaboration [1].  Over 56 days, the mission extended to Indonesia, the Philippines, Vietnam, and Cambodia, where they delivered medical, dental, and vision care to over 49,000 patients.  Additionally, over 900 surgeries were performed and veterinary services were provided to more than 7,000 animals, alongside engineering projects and community service initiatives [10].

![USNS Mercy underway, signifying its mission to provide medical aid and support in the Pacific region.](image8)

In contrast, the DoD Marrow Donor Program, operated by the Navy and Georgetown University, focuses on building and maintaining a registry of marrow donors to support both military and civilian patients in need of transplants [2]. This program is crucial for individuals with life-threatening diseases treatable by marrow transplants and also provides military contingency support for marrow toxic injuries from radiation or chemical agents [3].  The program conducts donor drives, like the one at Marine Corps Base Hawaii, where service members volunteer by providing oral swabs for genetic testing to be listed as potential donors [4].  The diversity of HLA types necessitates a large registry to find matches for the 70 percent of patients who lack a family match [7].

![A Marine participating in a marrow donor registration drive by swabbing his cheek.](image1)

![Service members participating in a marrow donor program by providing oral swabs.](image3)

While the Pacific Partnership delivered broad, immediate medical relief and fostered international cooperation through direct engagement and subject matter exchanges [10], the DoD Marrow Donor Program builds a critical infrastructure for long-term, life-saving treatments for individuals with specific diseases [12]. Both initiatives demonstrate a significant humanitarian impact, with the Pacific Partnership offering wide-reaching direct aid and the Marrow Program providing a specialized, life-saving resource for those in need of marrow transplants.

The USNS Mercy Pacific Partnership 2012 provided broad medical assistance and fostered international relations, while the DoD Bone Marrow Program established a vital resource for marrow transplants, both significantly contributing to humanitarian aid in distinct ways.

As an Internist and Infectious Diseases Officer, she provided Subject Matter Expert Exchanges (SMEE) on infection control and disease management to healthcare personnel in host nations [1, 6, 9].

Beckett's expertise extended to real-time disease outbreak management.  She investigated a gastroenteritis outbreak on the USNS Mercy, affecting 64 crew members, and utilized the Naval Health Research Center molecular diagnostics laboratory to confirm norovirus as the cause [1]. This highlights the direct application of naval research capabilities to improve onboard medical practices and outbreak response within the USNS Mercy.

NAMRU units significantly contribute to international health and defense through medical research, capacity building, and force health protection.  For instance, U.S. Naval Medical Research Unit No. 3 (NAMRU-3) plays a vital role in Liberia, a nation recovering from civil war, by enhancing its medical research capabilities [11]. The Minister of Health and Social Welfare in Liberia has expressed strong appreciation for NAMRU-3's capacity building efforts, particularly at the Liberian Institute for Biomedical Research (LIBR), hoping for continued collaboration and attracting further partnerships [3, 7].

![Minister of Health and Social Welfare praised NAMRU-3's capacity building engagements in Liberia.](image7)

NAMRU-3's engagements extend to military-to-military collaborations with the Armed Forces of Liberia (AFL), focusing on vector control training in partnership with LIBR [4]. This training, along with equipment provided, has notably improved Liberia's ability to protect its soldiers and families from diseases, as acknowledged by Nador [12].

![Military personnel conducting vector control training, indicating efforts to prevent disease.](image2)

These projects in Liberia directly support warfighters by reducing disease risks, exemplified by the insecticide spraying and geospatial mapping initiative by NAMRU-3 and the Navy Entomology Center of Excellence (NECE). This initiative successfully eliminated malaria infections among U.S. troops in the area, showcasing the effectiveness of combining environmental vector controls with anti-malarial prophylaxis [8].  Furthermore, NAMRU-3 aims to leave behind knowledge and tools to ensure Liberia’s self-sufficiency in maintaining these health protections [6].

![Group photo of collaborators, possibly including NAMRU-3 team members and Liberian officials, signifying international cooperation.](image1)

In addition to field operations, the Expeditionary Medicine Modeling, Simulation, and Analysis group at the Naval Health Research Center (NHRC) developed the Patient Condition Occurrence Frequency (PCOF) tool. This tool provides crucial data for military medical planning by estimating the probabilities of various disease and injury types in different operational scenarios, enhancing the accuracy of healthcare simulations [1, 5].

![Logo of U.S. Naval Medical Research Unit No. 2 PACIFIC, illustrating the existence of different NAMRU units with potentially varying geographical or functional focuses.](image6)

Ultimately, NAMRU units contribute to both international health and defense by building local medical capacity, conducting critical research, and developing tools that protect military personnel from health threats in diverse operational environments.

NAMRU-3 has been actively involved in bolstering medical research capabilities in Liberia, especially as the country recovers from a prolonged period of civil unrest [7].  This engagement is primarily focused on building capacity within the Ministry of Public Health (MoPH) laboratories [9].

NAMRU-3's efforts in Liberia involve key collaborations, particularly with the Liberian Institute of Biomedical Research (LIBR) [6].  These collaborations aim to enhance Liberia's ability to independently conduct vector-borne disease surveillance and detection, which benefits both the Liberian Armed Forces and the general population [6]. The Minister of Health and Social Welfare has expressed strong appreciation for NAMRU-3's capacity-building initiatives at LIBR, anticipating future collaborative projects [11].  ![Group photo of officials, possibly including representatives from NAMRU-3, LIBR, and the Liberian government, signifying their collaborative efforts.](image1)

One significant area of collaboration is in vector control. NAMRU-3 is working with LIBR on projects focused on disease vector surveillance, detection of vector-borne viral pathogens like malaria, and implementing vector control strategies [6].  This includes providing vector control training to the Armed Forces of Liberia (AFL) in partnership with LIBR [3].  A notable project involves insecticide spraying and geospatial mapping to control malaria-transmitting mosquitoes, which has successfully eliminated malaria infections among U.S. troops in the area [2]. This project exemplifies the effectiveness of combining environmental vector controls with preventative measures [2].  ![Group photo in front of a building that reads "HEADQUARTERS ARMED FORCES OF LIBERIA MINISTRY OF NATIONAL DEFENSE", highlighting the military collaboration aspect.](image3)

Through these collaborations and activities, NAMRU-3 significantly contributes to building local medical research capacity in Liberia by enhancing disease surveillance, detection, and control capabilities, particularly for vector-borne illnesses.

The Naval Medical Research Center (NMRC) and its affiliated teams, particularly NAMRU-3, play multifaceted roles encompassing medical research, capacity building, and direct humanitarian aid.  NAMRU-3 has been instrumental in enhancing public health capabilities in various countries, especially Afghanistan, since 2006 [10]. Their initial efforts in Afghanistan focused on assessing the capacities of the Ministry of Public Health (MoPH) and the Afghan Public Health Institute, particularly the Central Public Health Laboratory (CPHL) in Kabul, later expanding to other facilities [11].

To bolster diagnostic capabilities, NAMRU-3 established several specialized laboratories within the CPHL, including virology, bacteriology, and serology labs [1]. They have also provided crucial training for diagnostic laboratories, strengthening local expertise [1]. This commitment to training is further evidenced by workshops like the bacteriology training hosted for Afghan trainees from Kabul's Central Public Health Laboratory [2].

![Researchers are working in a biosafety lab, indicating laboratory research and training.]()

NAMRU-3 researchers developed comprehensive training plans and modules covering diverse fields such as parasitology, bacteriology, bioscience facility management, and laboratory quality management systems [3].  This extensive training also included ethics in research and management, particularly concerning U.S. select agents, equipping Afghan scientists and technicians with essential skills [5, 6]. In 2011 alone, 160 Afghan scientists and technicians received such training [5, 6]. This capacity building initiative is a collaborative effort, with NAMRU-3 partnering with the Defense Threat Reduction Agency (DTRA) to enhance biodefense and disease surveillance in Afghanistan [7].

![People in lab coats are working at lab benches, suggesting laboratory operations and training.]()

Beyond laboratory capacity building, NMRC teams like those aboard the USNS Mercy engage in direct humanitarian missions. The USNS Mercy Pacific Partnership missions, initiated in 2004, are annual humanitarian deployments aimed at strengthening international relations and providing critical medical care [9].  These missions offer a wide range of services, including adult and pediatric medical care, dental and vision screenings through Medical and Dental Civic Action Programs (MEDCAPS) [4].

![A group of medical personnel and volunteers pose for a photo, representing a humanitarian medical team.]()

Moreover, specialized surgical teams (SURGCAPs) perform a variety of surgeries, and veterinary teams (VETCAPs) treat livestock and domestic animals, addressing both human and animal health needs [4].  These missions also incorporate subject-matter expert exchanges (SMEEs) covering vital topics like first aid, nutrition, public health, and disaster response, extending their impact beyond direct medical treatment [4]. Cmdr. Charmagne Beckett, a physician researcher from NMRC, volunteered on the USNS Mercy, highlighting the personal commitment of NMRC personnel to these humanitarian endeavors [9].

![A naval officer in uniform stands on a ship, possibly USNS Mercy, indicating involvement in humanitarian missions.]()

In a different capacity, the NMRC Bone Marrow Research Directorate provides critical military contingency support, focusing on casualties suffering from marrow toxic injury due to radiation or chemical agents. The Kazakh scientists visited NMRC for training on molecular assays to enhance their skills in identifying and assessing the risk of rickettsial diseases. The Rickettsial Diseases Research Program at NMRC is responsible for assessing the risk of rickettsial diseases to military and civilian personnel globally and provides training to individuals from regions where these diseases are common [6, 11]. Four scientists from Kazakhstan received training at NMRC on molecular assays, particularly multi-locus sequencing typing (MLST) [8]. This training was part of a collaboration with the Defense Threat Reduction Agency's (DTRA) Cooperative Biological Engagement Program (CBEP) [8]. The training included using genus-specific tick assays to identify ticks prevalent in Kazakhstan and learning methods for quantitative real-time PCR, standard and nested PCR, sequencing, data analysis, and BLAST searches [9].  ![A group of people standing together in front of a building, possibly including the Kazakh scientists who visited NMRC.](image6)  Upon returning to their laboratories in Kazakhstan, these scientists are expected to apply their newly acquired skills to analyze local tick samples, identify rickettsial and tick species, and better evaluate the risk of rickettsial diseases in their country [9]. The Kazakh scientists' visit to NMRC aimed to train them on molecular assays for rickettsial diseases risk assessment in Kazakhstan.

Military research collaborations are essential in addressing global health challenges by combining expertise and resources across different regions and sectors [3]. These collaborations facilitate technology transfer and resource leveraging, ultimately benefiting both military personnel and the general population [1]. For example, collaborations like Cooperative Research and Development Agreements (CRADAs) are key business vehicles for Navy biomedical scientists, fostering partnerships between the Navy and other institutions [11].  ![A medical professional in blue gloves examines a child's foot, possibly illustrating medical assistance in a global setting.](image1) Such partnerships enable the Naval Medical Research Center (NMRC) to excel in technology transfer, moving biomedical developments from laboratories to practical applications for warfighters and civilians alike [3, 8].

One significant example of global collaboration is the training provided to scientists from Kazakhstan at the Naval Medical Research Center (NMRC) on rickettsial diseases [4]. This training, part of a collaboration with the Defense Threat Reduction Agency (DTRA), directly enhances the capacity of international partners to combat specific health threats in their regions [4, 10].  ![A group of diverse individuals stand together, potentially representing international research collaboration.](image5) These collaborations often focus on diseases prevalent in specific geographic areas, such as malaria.  Lt. Roxanne Burrus's collaboration with Duke University, for instance, evaluates the impact of changing demography and land use on malaria transmission, a critical issue in developing countries and for deployed military personnel [7].  ![Diagram illustrating CD8+ T cell response to malaria parasite in liver cells.](image6) Another malaria-focused collaboration uses mass spectrometry to identify potential vaccine candidates, demonstrating the diverse approaches being taken to combat this disease [7].

Moreover, military medical research in combat environments, while strictly adhering to ethical and regulatory requirements [5, 9], can lead to accelerated medical advances [6].  ![A group photo of military personnel in front of a building in Liberia, possibly representing a global health partnership.](image8) These advances, driven by the urgent needs of military medicine, often have broader applications, decreasing morbidity and mortality associated with various injuries and diseases in both military and civilian contexts [6]. The potential outcomes of these global collaborations include enhanced global health security, development of new medical technologies, and improved healthcare outcomes for both military and civilian populations.

Global military research collaborations effectively combat specific health challenges by fostering international partnerships, leveraging diverse expertise, and accelerating medical innovation, leading to improved health outcomes worldwide.

The Naval Submarine Medical Research Laboratory (NSMRL) is primarily an operational medicine laboratory with a focus on the submarine force and human factors within that force [10]. NSMRL's role is to serve as the primary human technology laboratory for the Commander, Submarine Forces (CSF), covering all physical and mental aspects of submariner health and performance [10]. This includes conducting medical, psychological, and human performance research to support the submarine force.  ![Logo of U.S. Naval Medical Research Unit-2 PACIFIC](image1) NSMRL is also involved in diving medicine investigations and has acquired advanced diving systems to enhance underwater research capabilities, particularly in underwater communications [9]. This allows for real-time communication with divers during experiments, improving the quality and efficiency of underwater investigations [9].

In summary, NSMRL's role is to conduct operational medical research focused on submariner health and human performance, as well as diving medicine, to support the Navy, particularly the submarine force.

NAMRU-3 has been actively involved in enhancing Afghanistan's public health capabilities since 2006 [5]. Initially, their focus was on assessing the laboratory capacity and support facilities within the Ministry of Public Health (MoPH) and the Afghan Public Health Institute, starting with the Central Public Health Laboratory (CPHL) in Kabul and later expanding to other facilities [9].  To improve the laboratory infrastructure, NAMRU-3 established several laboratories within the CPHL, including virology, bacteriology, and serology labs, along with five hospital laboratories [10].

NAMRU-3 conducted various training activities to build local expertise. In 2011, they trained 160 Afghan scientists and technicians in critical areas such as laboratory operations, diagnostic procedures, and research ethics [3, 12].  A bacteriology training workshop was specifically hosted for nine trainees from Kabul's Central Public Health Laboratory [2].  Furthermore, training extended to laboratory and administrative staff through workshops covering proper laboratory procedures, inventory management, quality control, and biosafety protocols [6].  These training initiatives are visually represented in laboratory settings. ![People in lab coats are working in a laboratory setting.](image5)

For 2012, NAMRU-3 developed a comprehensive training plan based on identified needs and gaps. This plan included nine modules covering a wide range of essential laboratory skills, such as parasitology, bacteriology, bioscience facility management, clinical epidemiology, biomedical equipment repair, laboratory quality management systems, serology, molecular biology, and virology [1, 3].  Notably, NAMRU-3 tailored their training materials to suit the Afghan context, taking into account cultural practices to ensure effective knowledge transfer [8].  These efforts were also conducted in partnership with the Defense Threat Reduction Agency (DTRA) Cooperative Biological Engagement Program (CBEP), enhancing the synergy of biodefense and disease surveillance initiatives [11].

NAMRU-3 conducted various training activities in Afghanistan, encompassing laboratory operations, diagnostic procedures, research ethics, and specific laboratory disciplines to enhance public health capacity.

Evidence suggests that Naval Medical Research Center (NMRC) is actively involved in malaria research and vaccine development [1].  The NMRC malaria research program is at the forefront of malaria investigation, particularly focusing on the liver stage of infection as a vaccine target [1, 5]. The immune system's response to malaria, as illustrated, involves a targeted cellular mechanism.

![Illustration of CD8+ T cell targeting malaria-infected liver cell](image5)

The illustration depicts how CD8+ T cells recognize and target liver cells infected with malaria parasites.  A liver cell infected with Pf schizont presents Pf peptide via Class I MHC, which is recognized by the CD8 receptor on a CD8+ T cell. This interaction triggers the CD8+ T cell to release Perforin and Granzymes, leading to apoptosis and the death of the parasite inside the liver cell.

The immune system targets malaria parasites by utilizing CD8+ T cells to induce apoptosis in infected liver cells.

The Naval Medical Research Center (NMRC) actively engages in "technology transfer and commercialization" to translate research findings into practical applications, primarily aiming to benefit the warfighter [1]. This process inherently fosters a bridge between military research and civilian healthcare because the discoveries and inventions are brought "to market", suggesting broader availability beyond military use.

One significant example of this collaboration is in malaria research.  NMRC is involved in multiple collaborations focused on malaria, a disease relevant to both military personnel deployed in endemic regions and civilian populations worldwide.  For instance, Lt. Roxanne Burrus from U.S. Naval Medical Research Unit No. 6 in Lima, Peru, is collaborating with Duke University to study malaria transmission influenced by demographic and land-use changes [3].  This research not only aims to protect deployed warfighters but also contributes to the global understanding and control of malaria, a major public health concern in developing countries. Further highlighting the depth of malaria research, Dr. Villasante is mentioned as Head of the Malaria Department at NMRC [10].  The complexity of this research is visualized in the immune response diagram.

![Diagram illustrating the immune response to malaria with CD8+ T cells and liver cells.](image7)

The diagram illustrates the cellular mechanisms involved in the body's defense against malaria, a fundamental aspect of vaccine development and understanding the disease.  This kind of basic research, while crucial for military force health protection, has broad implications for civilian vaccine development and therapeutic strategies for malaria.

Furthermore, the Deployed Combat Casualty Research Team (JC2RT) exemplifies the rapid advancement of medical knowledge in military settings that can translate to civilian benefits [7]. Initially deployed in Iraq in 2005 and later transitioning to Afghanistan [8], JC2RT's mission is to systematically record, collect, validate, and analyze data during combat to accelerate medical advances [7].  This focused, high-stakes environment pushes the boundaries of medical innovation in areas like trauma care, hemorrhage control, and traumatic brain injury, all of which are also critical concerns in civilian emergency and critical care medicine.  JC2RT’s work in the field is visually represented.

![A team of military personnel in front of a helicopter, possibly representing a JC2RT team in a deployed environment.](image6)

The image shows a team of medical personnel, likely in a deployed setting, indicating the operational aspect of military medical research and its direct relevance to real-world scenarios.

Ultimately, NMRC’s technology transfer mechanisms, like Cooperative Research and Development Agreements (CRADAs) [4], and the inherent nature of military medical research to address pressing health challenges, ensure that innovations developed for the warfighter also hold "considerable potential for these new sources of information and technologies to benefit the general population" [11].  This symbiotic relationship is driven by leveraging resources and expertise across public and private sectors [12].

In conclusion, NMRC’s initiatives in medical and technological advancements, especially in areas like malaria vaccine research and the JC2RT team's efforts, exemplify a strong collaborative synergy between military research and civilian healthcare progress, leading to innovations that benefit both military personnel and the broader public.

The Joint Combat Casualty Research Team (JC2RT) is a forward deployed unit under the U.S. Central Command (USCENTCOM) [4, 6]. This team comprises military research scientists and clinicians. Their mission involves overseeing, coordinating, facilitating, and conducting combat-relevant research within a deployed environment like Afghanistan [6].  Since 2010, JC2RT members have been integrated with medical resources across Afghanistan, succeeding the Deployed Combat Casualty Research Team (DC2RT) which was initially active in Iraq [2].

![JC2RT members in military uniform standing in front of a helicopter, indicating their deployed environment and potential medical research activities.](image6)

The role of the JC2RT team in Afghanistan is to conduct and coordinate combat-relevant medical research in a deployed environment.

To register for the C.W. Bill Young Department of Defense Marrow Donor Program, service members use a cotton swab to rub the inside of their cheek, collecting cell samples [8]. This process is part of a basewide drive to register service members in the program [8].

![A Marine is using a cotton swab to collect cell sample from inside his cheek for marrow donor program](image7)

The collected oral swabs with cell samples, along with donor consent forms, are then sent to the Donor Center and Laboratory, which is part of the Naval Medical Research Center’s (NMRC) Bone Marrow Research Directorate [9].

![A person is using a cotton swab to collect cell sample from another person's mouth during a marrow donor program registration drive](image8)

Genetic testing is performed on the cells from the oral swabs to match potential donors with patients who need marrow transplants [9]. This information from the swab is entered into the National Marrow Donor Program registry [3].

Therefore, the cotton swab in the DoD Bone Marrow Program serves the purpose of collecting cell samples for genetic testing to identify potential marrow donors and register them in the national registry.

Based on the data from 2005 to 2006, the healthcare IT sector experienced shifts in both major challenges and the adoption of key applications. Security and implementation barriers were prominent concerns, while the adoption of various IT applications saw increased momentum.

One significant challenge was **security concerns**, particularly internal breaches and HIPAA compliance, which became more pronounced in 2006 compared to 2005. As shown in the chart depicting top security concerns, the percentage for internal breach of security increased from 51% in 2005 to 56% in 2006, and HIPAA compliance concerns rose from 18% to 35% in the same period. ![Security concerns like internal breach and HIPAA compliance increased from 2005 to 2006](image5).

Furthermore, **barriers to implementing IT** also saw some changes.  While financial support remained a top barrier, the vendor's inability to effectively deliver products became a more significant concern in 2006, increasing from 12% to 18%. ![Barriers to IT implementation like financial support and vendor issues increased from 2005 to 2006](image8).

Despite these challenges, there was a notable increase in the **adoption of various IT applications** within healthcare.  Technologies like Electronic Medical Records (EMR), bar-coded medication management, and Computerized Practitioner Order Entry (CPOE) all demonstrated higher adoption rates in 2006 compared to 2005.  For instance, EMR adoption increased from 61% to 62%, bar-coded medication management from 58% to 55%, and CPOE from 52% to 50%. ![Adoption of Electronic Medical Records, Bar Coded Medication, and CPOE increased from 2005 to 2006](image6). Similarly, technologies like single sign-on, barcode technology, and speech recognition also saw increased adoption. ![Adoption of technologies like single sign-on, barcode, and speech recognition increased from 2005 to 2006](image2).

In summary, while security and implementation barriers remained critical challenges, the healthcare IT sector in 2006 demonstrated a positive trend in the increased adoption of various IT applications compared to 2005.

To classify images containing either a dog or a cat, an algorithm needs to be created [1, 3]. The process involves using a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) to extract features from an input image. For instance, running an image of a cat wearing google glasses through a CNN yields a feature vector [2, 11].

```markdown
![A grey cat wearing google glasses is used as an input image for CNN.](image2)
```
The image depicts a dog with a human-like face, which is humorous but still represents a dog.

This feature vector is then fed into a Deep Belief Network (DBN) for prediction.  The output determines whether the image contains a "WOOF!" (dog) or a "MEOW!" (cat) [2].

```markdown
![A split image with a cat on the left and a dog on the right, labeled "CAT vs DOG".](image4)
```
This image clearly illustrates the two animal types in question.

The ultimate question is whether the algorithm can accurately distinguish between CAT or DOG [12].

```markdown
![A person with a cat's head is holding a cat.](image8)
```
This image further emphasizes the presence of cats.

The types of animals that appear in the PPT are dogs and cats.

The process of transforming data into business value follows an "analytics value chain," starting from data collection and progressing through analysis to decisions and actions, ultimately aiming for impact [3].  ![The analytics value chain starts from data and progresses through reporting, analysis, action to value](image1).  This value chain aligns with different "levels of analytics" [9].  Initially, the chain focuses on "Reporting" which is descriptive and backward-looking, answering "What happened?" and transforming data into information  ![Reporting is descriptive, backward-looking and raises questions](image2). As the chain progresses to "Analysis," it becomes more prescriptive and forward-looking, answering "Why?" and generating insights [image2].  Higher levels of analytics like predictive modeling and optimization, shown in the levels of analytics diagram, are crucial for maximizing business value. ![Levels of analytics increase in degree of intelligence and business value, starting from standard reports to optimisation](image8).  According to Zynga, analytics is truly about impact, and insights alone without action and change yield zero credit [4].

The transformation of data into business value is a process that requires pushing data through the entire analytics value chain and leveraging increasing levels of analytical sophistication to drive action and achieve a tangible impact.

The Disciplined Agile (DA) framework emphasizes the importance of exploring the initial scope during the Inception phase of a project. Disciplined Agile framework suggests strategies like stakeholder participation and JIT model storming, and considerations covering level of detail, view types, modeling and requirement types to effectively explore the initial scope of a project.

The Analytics Value Chain and Levels of Analytics are complementary frameworks crucial for transforming raw data into actionable insights and tangible business value. The **Analytics Value Chain** outlines the essential steps to ensure data analysis translates into real-world impact. As quote [1] emphasizes, it's about pushing data through the entire chain: "collection, analysis, decisions, action, and finally to impact. Partway along chain doesn't count" [1]. This holistic view is echoed by quote [2], highlighting that "Analytics is about impact...if you have brilliant insight and you did great research and no one changes, you get zero credit" [2]. The importance of this complete chain is visually represented in image2, which shows the progression from 'Data' through 'Reporting', 'Analysis', and 'Action' to ultimately reach 'Value'.

![The image shows the Analytics Value Chain, starting from data collection, moving through reporting and analysis, leading to action and finally to value creation.](image2)

Complementing this process-oriented view, **Levels of Analytics** define the depth and sophistication of the analysis performed. Image7 illustrates the progression of analytics from basic 'Standard Reports' and 'Ad-hoc Reports' to more advanced stages like 'Statistical Analysis', 'Forecasting', 'Predictive Modelling', and 'Optimisation'.  Each level builds upon the previous one, increasing in analytical complexity and business value.

![The image depicts the levels of analytics, ranging from standard reports to optimization, illustrating an increasing degree of intelligence and business value.](image7)

Image5 further elaborates on the distinction between basic reporting and deeper analysis.  Reporting is 'Descriptive', 'Backward-looking', and 'Raises questions', primarily focusing on transforming 'Data → Information'. In contrast, Analysis is 'Prescriptive', 'Forward-looking', and 'Answer questions', aiming to generate 'Data + Information → insights' and provide 'Findings, Recommendation, story telling'.

![The image contrasts Reporting and Analysis, highlighting that reporting is descriptive and backward-looking, while analysis is prescriptive and forward-looking, aiming to generate insights and recommendations.](image5)

Therefore, the Analytics Value Chain provides the roadmap for ensuring that analytical efforts translate into action and impact, while the Levels of Analytics define the depth and type of analysis conducted within the 'Analysis' stage of this chain to generate increasingly valuable insights. Both frameworks are essential; a robust value chain without sophisticated analysis may yield limited insights, and advanced analytics without a focus on action and impact may not deliver business value.

In conclusion, the Analytics Value Chain and Levels of Analytics work in tandem, with the Value Chain providing the framework for action-oriented data utilization and Levels of Analytics offering a spectrum of analytical approaches to generate increasingly insightful and valuable outputs at each stage of the chain.

Evidence Selection:
- Text Quote 1: "Chromosomes coil and become compact -Homologous chromosomes come together as pairs by syn apsis  $-$  Eachpair,with four chromatids,is called a tetra d Non sister chromatids exchange genetic material by crossing over" - This is related to Prophase I, but mentions tetrad formation which is relevant to Metaphase I.
- Text Quote 5: "During meiosis  ${\tt I},$  homologous chromosomes separate The chromosome number is reduced by half" -  This highlights homologous chromosome separation in Meiosis I, crucial for understanding Metaphase I's purpose in the overall process.
- Text Quote 6: "A mitotic spindle is required to divide the chromosomes The mitotic spindle iscomposed of microtubules" -  Mitotic spindle is essential for chromosome movement in Metaphase I.
- Image Quote image6: Shows stages of meiosis I, clearly labeling "Metaphase Plate" and "Sister chromatids remain attached" and "Homologous chromosomes separate".
- Image Quote image2:  States "MEIOSIS I: Homologous chromosomes separate".

Answer Construction:
During Metaphase I of meiosis, homologous chromosomes, which have paired to form tetrads, align at the metaphase plate. This tetrad formation was initiated in prophase I when homologous chromosomes paired up [1].  ![Homologous chromosomes align at the metaphase plate during Metaphase I](image6). A mitotic spindle, composed of microtubules, is crucial for chromosome division and is active during this phase [6].  It's important to note that during meiosis I, homologous chromosomes are destined to separate [5], but in Metaphase I, sister chromatids remain attached together, while homologous pairs align at the metaphase plate to prepare for separation. ![Sister chromatids remain attached during Metaphase I while homologous chromosomes prepare to separate](image6).  The key features of Metaphase I are the alignment of homologous chromosome pairs (tetrads) at the metaphase plate and the attachment of microtubules to kinetochores, setting the stage for homologous chromosome separation in the subsequent Anaphase I. In Metaphase I, homologous chromosome pairs align at the metaphase plate, with sister chromatids remaining attached, preparing for homologous chromosome separation.

The transition from business intelligence (BI) to business analytics (BA) marks a significant enhancement in how organizations handle data and generate insights. Business intelligence primarily focuses on reporting and understanding "what happened" by using historical data, whereas business analytics delves deeper to understand "why it happened" and "what will happen next," ultimately driving impactful actions and strategic decisions.  This shift is clearly illustrated in the progression of analytical capabilities.

The evolution from BI to BA represents a move from basic reporting to more sophisticated analysis and prediction, leading to greater business value. As depicted in the diagram, the levels of analytics progress from standard reports to optimization, with business intelligence encompassing the lower levels and business analytics the higher levels.  This progression signifies an increasing "Degree of Intelligence" and "Business Value" derived from data.
![Levels of business intelligence and business analytics with increasing degree of intelligence and business value](image8)

BI is often associated with "Reporting," which is descriptive, backward-looking, and raises questions, primarily transforming data into information. In contrast, BA is more aligned with "Analysis," which is prescriptive, forward-looking, answers questions, and transforms data and information into insights through storytelling and recommendations.  This distinction highlights how BA moves beyond simply describing past events to providing actionable insights for future decisions.
![Comparison of Reporting and Analysis highlighting the shift from descriptive to prescriptive and from information to insights](image7)

This enhancement is further emphasized by the concept of the "analytics value chain."  While BI might focus on data collection, reporting, and perhaps some initial analysis, BA pushes data through the entire chain, ensuring that insights are not just generated but also translated into decisions, actions, and ultimately, business impact.  This complete value chain approach ensures that the full potential of data is realized.
![Data analytics value chain from data collection to value creation through reporting, analysis, and action](image3)

As text quote [12] states, "Push data through 'analytics value chain' from collection, analysis decisions, action, and finally to impact. Partway along chain doesn't count."  This highlights that the full value of analytics is only realized when it leads to tangible impact, a core principle of business analytics. Furthermore, text quote [1] emphasizes that in a data-driven environment, "Analytics is about impact...if you have brilliant insight and you did great research and noone changes, you get zero credit." This underscores the action-oriented nature of business analytics, where insights are valued for their ability to drive change and create impact, going beyond the descriptive nature of traditional business intelligence.

In conclusion, the transition from business intelligence to business analytics enhances data handling and insights generation by moving from descriptive reporting to prescriptive analysis, focusing on the entire data value chain to ensure insights drive actionable decisions and create tangible business impact.

Here's an explanation of the steps involved in binary fission in prokaryotic cells, based on the provided quotes:

Binary fission in prokaryotes is a process where one cell divides into two identical daughter cells. This process is essential for reproduction in prokaryotic organisms [2, 3]. It begins with the duplication of the prokaryotic chromosome [5, 7], which is typically a single circular chromosome [1, 7].

![Prokaryotic cell with duplicated chromosomes starting to separate](image3)

As the chromosome duplicates, the copies start to separate from each other [7]. `image3 shows a prokaryotic cell where the duplicated chromosomes are visibly moving apart`. Simultaneously, the cell begins to elongate [7, 10].

![Prokaryotic cell undergoing division into two daughter cells](image8)

The cell continues to elongate, and the duplicated chromosomes move further apart [10]. Finally, the plasma membrane grows inward at the midpoint of the cell to divide it into two daughter cells, each containing a copy of the chromosome [7]. `image8 illustrates the division of a prokaryotic cell into two daughter cells, each with its own chromosome`.

In summary, binary fission in prokaryotic cells involves three main steps: chromosome duplication and separation initiation, cell elongation and chromosome separation continuation, and cell division.

During the telophase and cytokinesis stages of cell division, several key changes occur in the cellular structures. Cytokinesis, the division of the cytoplasm, often overlaps with telophase, the final stage of mitosis [8, 2]. Cytokinesis is the process where the cell physically divides into two daughter cells [2]. In animal cells, this often involves the formation of a cleavage furrow, as depicted in the diagram ![Cleavage furrow forming during cytokinesis, eventually leading to two daughter cells.](image6). This furrow pinches the cell membrane inward, eventually separating the cytoplasm and creating two distinct cells.  ![Diagram showing metaphase plate, cleavage furrow, and nuclear envelope forming during cell division.](image2) shows the cleavage furrow formation as part of cytokinesis.  While not explicitly mentioned for telophase in the text quotes provided, image2 indicates the reformation of the nuclear envelope during this stage as well.  Cytokinesis concludes the cell division process, resulting in two separate daughter cells from a single parent cell.

Cellular structures undergo cytoplasmic division and cell separation during telophase and cytokinesis.

Based on the concept of diminishing marginal utility, the utility derived from each hot dog decreases as more are consumed.  As shown in the table, the first hot dog provides a utility of +6, but by the third hot dog, the utility drops to 0.  Continued consumption leads to negative utility, as seen with the fourth hot dog yielding a utility of -2. ![Table depicting diminishing marginal utility of hot dogs.](image8)  This principle suggests that the enjoyment or satisfaction from each additional hot dog diminishes.  As text quote states, "Variety is important because diminishing marginal utility changes preferences. When enjoyment drops we should switch to another choice" [12]. The Analytics Value Chain is a process that systematically converts raw data into tangible business value by progressing through distinct stages. This process starts with data collection and moves through analysis to culminate in action and impactful results [2]. It's crucial to ensure data moves through the entire chain, as partial progression doesn't fully realize the potential value [2].

The process begins with **data**, which is then transformed through **reporting** to become **information**. Reporting is descriptive, answering "what" happened and is backward-looking, primarily raising questions based on the data [image2].  ![Reporting transforms data into information by describing what happened](image2)

Next, **analysis** takes the information and transforms it into **insights**. Analysis is prescriptive, answering "why" things happened, forward-looking, and aims to answer questions, ultimately leading to findings and recommendations [image2].  ![Analysis transforms information into insights by explaining why and offering recommendations](image2) This stage is visually represented in the value chain flow as the point where data is examined to find meaningful patterns [image4]. ![The analytics value chain progresses from data through reporting and analysis](image4)

These insights then drive **decisions** and **actions** [2].  The insights gained from analysis are put into practice, leading to concrete actions within the business [image4]. ![Action is taken based on the insights derived from analysis](image4)

Finally, these actions generate **impact** and **value** for the organization [2]. The ultimate goal of the Analytics Value Chain is to create measurable value from data, tying back to strategic objectives and demonstrating a return on investment [1, image4]. ![Action results in value, completing the analytics value chain](image4)

In conclusion, the Analytics Value Chain is a step-by-step process that transforms raw data into actionable insights and ultimately business value through stages of reporting, analysis, and action, ensuring data is leveraged to its fullest potential.

Mendelian inheritance explains the phenotypic and genotypic ratios in the F2 generation of pea plants through the principles discovered by Gregor Mendel in his experiments with garden peas [1]. Mendel's work revealed that parents pass heritable factors, now known as genes, to their offspring [4]. In a monohybrid cross, like the one Mendel performed with purple and white flowers, the parental generation (P) consists of true-breeding plants – purple flowers crossed with white flowers ![Parental generation of true-breeding purple and white flowers in a monohybrid cross](image4).

The first filial generation (F1) resulting from this cross showed all plants with purple flowers ![F1 generation showing all purple flowers](image4). This observation led Mendel to propose that one trait (purple flower) is dominant over the other (white flower), which seemed to disappear in the F1 generation [11].

When Mendel allowed the F1 generation to self-fertilize, the second filial generation (F2) exhibited a reappearance of the white flower trait, with a phenotypic ratio of approximately 3 purple flowers to 1 white flower [11].  This 3:1 phenotypic ratio in the F2 generation is a hallmark of Mendelian inheritance in a monohybrid cross and is visually represented in the cross diagram ![Diagram showing the monohybrid cross from P to F2 generation with phenotypic and genotypic ratios](image1).

The diagram illustrates that the purple flower trait (P) is dominant and the white flower trait (p) is recessive. The parental purple plants have a homozygous dominant genotype (PP), while the white plants are homozygous recessive (pp). The F1 generation, resulting from the cross, is heterozygous (Pp), displaying the dominant purple phenotype. In the F2 generation, the segregation of alleles during gamete formation in the F1 hybrids leads to a genotypic ratio of 1 PP : 2 Pp : 1 pp and the corresponding phenotypic ratio of 3 purple (PP and Pp) : 1 white (pp) ![Explanation of homozygous dominant, homozygous recessive and heterozygous genotypes](image8).

In conclusion, Mendelian inheritance explains the 3:1 phenotypic ratio and 1:2:1 genotypic ratio in the F2 generation through the principles of dominant and recessive alleles, gene segregation, and random fertilization, all demonstrated in Mendel's pea plant experiments.

In a monohybrid cross, as described by Mendel, the parental generation with purple and white flowers results in an F1 generation where all plants have purple flowers. However, in the F2 generation, the trait that seemed to disappear reappears in one-quarter of the offspring, while the other three-quarters display the dominant trait [3]. This observation leads to a phenotypic ratio of 3:1, meaning for every three plants with purple flowers, there is one plant with white flowers.

![The image shows a monohybrid cross, indicating a phenotypic ratio of 3 purple to 1 white and a genotypic ratio of 1 PP : 2 Pp : 1 pp in the F2 generation.](image3)

The image visually confirms these ratios, showing the phenotypic ratio of 3 purple to 1 white and the genotypic ratio of 1 PP : 2 Pp : 1 pp in the F2 generation.

The phenotypic ratio observed in the F2 generation is 3:1 (purple to white), and the genotypic ratio is 1:2:1 (PP:Pp:pp).

The minimum separation distance required for a transmitter can be calculated using the formulas provided in the images. For a transmitter operating at 500 MHz, which falls within the 80 MHz to 800 MHz range, we can use the formula:

$d = \left[\frac{3.5}{E_1}\right] \sqrt{P}$

From Image2, we can see a table that provides pre-calculated separation distances for different power levels and frequency ranges. For the frequency range of 80 MHz to 800 MHz, when the rated maximum output power (P) is 1 W, the separation distance (d) is 1.2 m. Let's use this information to verify the constant $\left[\frac{3.5}{E_1}\right]$.

When P = 1 W, d = 1.2 m, so:
$1.2 = \left[\frac{3.5}{E_1}\right] \sqrt{1}$
$1.2 = \left[\frac{3.5}{E_1}\right]$

Now we can use this constant to calculate the separation distance for a transmitter with a rated maximum output power of 10 W operating at 500 MHz:
$d = 1.2 \times \sqrt{P}$
$d = 1.2 \times \sqrt{10}$
$d \approx 1.2 \times 3.162$
$d \approx 3.7944$

Rounding to two decimal places, we get $d \approx 3.79$ meters.

According to Image2, for a transmitter with a rated maximum output power of 10 W in the 80 MHz to 800 MHz frequency range, the recommended separation distance is 3.8m, which is consistent with our calculation.

The electromagnetic environment and the separation distances are important for ensuring the normal operation of the M270TF-XXX / M320TF-XXX monitor in the presence of RF disturbances [12]. It's also important to note that these guidelines may not apply in all situations due to factors like absorption and reflection [2].

```markdown
To calculate the minimum separation distance for a 500 MHz transmitter with a 10 W output, we use the formula applicable to the 80 MHz to 800 MHz frequency range, as shown in Image2, which is derived from Image4. The formula is $d = 1.2 \times \sqrt{P}$, where P is the power in watts and d is the distance in meters.

![Separation distance per frequency of transmitter](image2)

Given P = 10 W, we calculate:
$d = 1.2 \times \sqrt{10} \approx 3.79 \;\text{m}$

Therefore, the minimum separation distance required is approximately 3.79 meters.

The minimum separation distance required for this transmitter is 3.79 m.
```

The ValueEdge framework is structured into three main sections designed to streamline the software development lifecycle and enhance value stream management [10, 4]. These sections are crucial for organizations aiming to optimize their product delivery and align business goals with development resources [2, 4].

The first section is **ValueEdge Insights**, which focuses on providing data-driven analytics to measure and manage flow efficiency. This section allows organizations to gain instant visibility into development velocity, project duration, and quality, enabling them to proactively address bottlenecks and accelerate time to market [6].

The second section comprises **Acceleration Modules**. These modules are designed to enhance specific stages of the software development lifecycle, from planning to running operations. Examples include modules for Agile management, quality assurance through functional testing, release management, and operations (Ops) [2, 7, 1, 12]. These modules work with Agile and DevOps methodologies to optimize software delivery and ensure comprehensive functional testing for improved application quality [3, 7].

The third section is **Services**, which underpin the entire ValueEdge framework by providing essential functionalities such as traceability, data lake capabilities, integration with various tools, security, and orchestration. These services ensure that ValueEdge can be seamlessly integrated into existing development environments and toolchains [5].

![ValueEdge framework is divided into ValueEdge Insights, Acceleration Modules, and Services.](image6)

ValueEdge integrates with a wide array of supporting tools, including Agile tools like ALM Octane, Broadcom Rally, Atlassian Jira, and others, as well as DevOps tools [2, 4]. This integration ensures a unified and flexible approach to managing value streams across the entire SDLC [4, 9]. The platform's modular and cloud-based nature allows organizations to start with a single service or leverage multiple modules to augment their existing toolchain based on their specific needs [5].

In summary, the ValueEdge framework is organized into ValueEdge Insights, Acceleration Modules, and Services, which collectively integrate with various Agile and DevOps tools to provide a comprehensive value stream management solution.

In Disciplined Agile Delivery (DAD), understanding and responding to stakeholder needs is paramount, and this is addressed through different strategic approaches throughout the project lifecycle [1]. 'Needs Exploration' and 'Elicitation Methods' are two such strategies, each playing a distinct but complementary role in gathering and managing stakeholder requirements.

'Needs Exploration' is positioned within the 'Inception' phase of DAD, focused on broadly understanding the initial scope and direction of the project.  As visualized in ![Needs Exploration is part of the Inception phase in Disciplined Agile Delivery](image6), 'Explore initial scope' is a key activity during inception. This phase employs strategies to define high-level requirements and ensure active stakeholder participation from the outset, as shown in ![Needs Exploration includes active stakeholder participation and high-level requirements specification](image2).  The goal here is to establish a foundational understanding of stakeholder needs before moving into detailed development.

'Elicitation Methods', in contrast, are more focused on the ongoing and iterative process of gathering and refining requirements, particularly during the 'Construction' phase and as stakeholder needs evolve.  As highlighted in ![Elicitation Methods are used to address changing stakeholder needs through techniques like JIT model storming and demos](image4), 'Address Changing Stakeholder Needs' is a key objective during construction.  'Elicitation Methods' provide a toolkit of techniques like 'Just-in-time (JIT) model storming', 'Look-ahead modeling', and 'demos' to actively engage stakeholders and uncover detailed requirements throughout the development process [Image4].  These methods are designed to be flexible and adaptable, allowing for continuous feedback and adjustments based on stakeholder input.

Both 'Needs Exploration' and 'Elicitation Methods' are essential for effectively addressing stakeholder requirements in agile management. 'Needs Exploration' sets the stage by establishing initial understanding and broad scope, while 'Elicitation Methods' provide the continuous mechanisms to delve deeper, refine, and adapt to evolving stakeholder needs throughout the project.  This iterative approach ensures that the final product remains aligned with stakeholder expectations and delivers value, reflecting the 'solution focused' and 'people-first' nature of DAD [3].

In essence, 'Needs Exploration' initiates the journey of understanding stakeholder needs, while 'Elicitation Methods' guide the ongoing exploration and refinement of these needs throughout the agile development process. They both contribute to answering the question of "How does agile analysis work?" [9, Image5] by providing structured and iterative ways to engage with stakeholders and translate their needs into actionable development steps.

In conclusion, 'Needs Exploration' and 'Elicitation Methods' are complementary strategies; 'Needs Exploration' broadly defines initial stakeholder needs, while 'Elicitation Methods' provide ongoing, iterative techniques to refine and adapt to stakeholder needs throughout the agile project.

Based on the provided figures, structured markup errors and meta description issues can significantly hinder SEO performance.  [10]

Firstly, let's consider structured markup. Text quote [12] highlights the importance of `Markup Validation Service Check the markup （HTML,XHTML,...)of Web document`. This implies that valid markup is crucial for SEO. Image7, titled "Structured Markup," reveals a table detailing structured markup data types and errors.  ![Structured markup errors are present in blog and article data types.](image7)  Notably, for "Blog" and "Article" data types using `schema.org` markup, there are a substantial number of "Items with Errors" (72,441 and 49,222 respectively).  These errors in structured markup can prevent search engines from properly understanding and indexing the content, potentially leading to reduced visibility in search results.

Secondly, meta description issues also play a critical role. Image3 provides insights into "Meta description" problems.  ![Duplicate meta descriptions are a significant issue.](image3)  As depicted, "Duplicate meta descriptions" are prevalent, with 2,215 pages affected.  Additionally, there are "Short meta descriptions" (1,450 pages) and "Missing title tags" (10 pages) and "Duplicate title tags" (621 pages). These meta description and title tag issues can negatively impact click-through rates (CTR) from search engine results pages (SERPs). If meta descriptions are duplicate, missing, or poorly written, they fail to entice users to click on the link, even if the page ranks well.

In conclusion, both structured markup errors and meta description issues can negatively impact SEO performance by hindering search engine understanding and reducing user engagement, respectively.

The smartwatch is equipped with a color touchscreen that is highly responsive to touches and can be operated with swiping gestures [4]. The functions of these swiping gestures are detailed as follows:

![Touching the screen is for choosing and confirming.](image2) Touching the screen allows you to choose and confirm actions.

![Touching and holding on the home screen allows changing the watch face.](image2) Touching and holding on the home screen lets you change the watch face.

![Swiping up on the home screen allows viewing notifications.](image2) Swiping up on the home screen opens the notification center where you can view notifications. In fact, to view unread messages, you can swipe up on the home screen to enter the unread message center [12].

![Swiping down on the home screen allows viewing the shortcut menu.](image2) Swiping down on the home screen opens the shortcut menu [2].

![Swiping left or right on the home screen allows viewing watch feature cards.](image2) Swiping left or right on the home screen allows you to view different watch feature cards. For example, swiping right on the watch home screen enters HUAWEI Assistant·TODAY [6].

![Swiping right allows returning to the previous screen.](image2) Swiping right generally allows you to return to the previous screen. However, it's important to note that swiping right on the watch screen during a measurement will interrupt the process [7], and swiping right on the screen in flashlight mode closes the Flashlight app [11].

In summary, swiping gestures on the smartwatch are versatile, enabling users to navigate menus, access features, and manage notifications.

Geographical distributions of data can be visually represented using maps. For example, the geographical distribution of volcanoes across the world is visually represented on a map using red dots to indicate the locations of volcanoes, showing clusters in regions like the Americas, Africa, and Asia.  ![A world map showing red dots clustered in the Americas, Africa, and Asia, representing volcano locations.](image4)

Similarly, the geographical distribution of public library branches in the Netherlands is also visually represented on maps. A basic flat map displays the locations of these library branches within the Netherlands. ![A map of the Netherlands showing red dots indicating the locations of public libraries.](image2) These maps can be further enhanced by layering data based on postal codes or provinces to show different densities or categories of libraries [3, 9, 10]. For instance, maps can be layered by postal code zones [3].

The underlying data for creating these maps, such as for public library branches in the Netherlands, can be accessed and queried using services like the Wikidata Query Service [5, 9]. A query example is provided to retrieve data about public library branches in the Netherlands [1], which can then be visualized on a map interface using the "Map" option in the query service. ![The Wikidata Query Service interface showing a query for public library branches and the "Map" visualization option selected.](image3)

Both volcano and public library distributions are visually represented on maps, but the volcano map offers a global perspective while the library maps provide a regional view with potential for more detailed, layered data presentation.

Geographical distributions of volcanoes globally and public libraries in the Netherlands are both visually represented on maps, with volcano maps showing a global distribution and library maps providing a regional and potentially more detailed view.

The adoption of an integrated customer management approach faces significant hurdles within organizations, primarily stemming from a siloed organizational structure. As highlighted, a siloed approach acts as the greatest impediment to embracing customer management strategies [4]. This is further substantiated by survey data, revealing that **no single ownership of customer experience, leading to siloed operations and misaligned objectives, is the most frequently cited barrier at 52%** ![No single ownership of customer experience is the biggest barrier due to siloed approach and misaligned goals.](image6).

Adding to this organizational fragmentation, companies often operate in silos defined by business lines, products, or brands, which was reported as a barrier by 46% of respondents ![Being too siloed by business line, product, or brand is a barrier for customer management adoption.](image6). This internal division hinders a unified view of the customer and impedes coordinated customer interactions.  Furthermore, the challenges are not merely structural; they are also deeply rooted in management and organizational culture [11].  Successfully implementing customer management requires strong leadership commitment and guidance to foster sustainable growth across processes, infrastructure, and the organizational culture itself [8].

Beyond organizational issues, practical limitations such as resource constraints and technical infrastructure gaps also pose barriers, with 36% and 28% respectively identifying these as obstacles ![Lack of resources and technical infrastructure are barriers to customer management adoption.](image6).  Additionally, the inability to effectively measure the impact of marketing activities on customer behavior, noted by 27% of respondents ![Inability to measure the influence of activities on customer behavior is a barrier to customer management adoption.](image6),  underscores the struggle to quantify and justify investments in customer management initiatives.

In conclusion, the primary barriers to adopting an integrated customer management approach are organizational silos, lack of unified ownership of customer experience, management and cultural issues, and limitations in resources, infrastructure, and measurement capabilities.

The Consulting department at PwC operates across various industries and offers diverse services to both public and private sectors, helping them optimize and transform their businesses [3]. They focus on digital transformation and IT markets, especially in the GCC region, by formulating digital strategies and enhancing customer engagement [4]. The Consulting team works across 12 offices in 9 countries with 1816 employees. ![Consulting team members are collaborating in an office setting, with data showing 12 offices, 9 countries and 1816 employees](image2)  They also provide services in financial sectors, addressing risks, regulations, and digital innovations [5]. Furthermore, the Consulting department offers a rotational programme to build core skills and explore different consulting business areas, emphasizing solving client problems with deep industry expertise [6].

On the other hand, the Deals department, which can be considered under Assurance in a broader context, focuses on mergers, acquisitions, and disposals, advising clients throughout the deal lifecycle [9]. This department supports private equity firms, investment funds, and corporate clients, aiding in strategic valuation decisions for business deals and restructurings [10].  The Deals department has a significant international presence with 20 offices across 12 countries and a large team of 1914 employees. ![Two colleagues are reviewing documents at a desk, with data showing 20 offices, 12 countries and 1914 employees](image1)  They also handle under-performing companies, providing restructuring and refinancing advice [11], and assist clients in navigating major financial events and business crises [12].  The Edge graduate program within PwC Deals EMEA further highlights their international environment and focus on developing careers in Deals [1].

In summary, while both departments have a global presence, the Deals/Assurance department appears to have a larger office presence and employee base compared to the Consulting department, with Deals operating in 20 offices across 12 countries and Consulting in 12 offices across 9 countries, although Consulting also has a substantial reach.
